item.title: 12.11.2024: ubuntu-security, ubuntu-meeting
item.description:
# UBUNTU-SECURITY

=== Juesto is now known as Juest
=== Juesto is now known as Juest

# UBUNTU-MEETING

[15:32] o/
[15:32] good morning
[15:33] o/
[15:33] do we have any MIR quorum today?
[15:34] it's looking like no, heh
[15:34] o/
[15:34] classic irc, say something, and there's a counterexample immediately :)
[15:35] haha, not sure if c_paelzer is around... let me get this started.
[15:35] :D
[15:35] #startmeeting Weekly Main Inclusion Requests status
[15:35] Meeting started at 15:35:12 UTC. The chair is sarnold. Information about MeetBot at https://wiki.ubuntu.com/meetingology
[15:35] Available commands: action, commands, idea, info, link, nick
[15:35] Ping for MIR meeting - didrocks joalif slyon sarnold cpaelzer jamespage ( eslerm dviererbe )
[15:35] #topic current component mismatches
[15:35] Mission: Identify required actions and spread the load among the teams
[15:35] #link https://people.canonical.com/~ubuntu-archive/component-mismatches-proposed.svg
[15:35] #link https://people.canonical.com/~ubuntu-archive/component-mismatches.svg
[15:35] wow so much qt6
[15:36] I pushed some seed changes to hopefully get rid of the qt5 & qt6 trees earlier today.
[15:36] woot
[15:36] Also I cleaned up the sbuild->mmdebstrap and investigated libgit2 (more about this in AOB)
[15:36] there was a request for an archive admin to demote new gpgme binaries for qt6
[15:36] tmux to jemalloc, server team ..
[15:36] jbicha: do you have a reference?
[15:37] I added extra includes for the new libqgpgme* packages
[15:37] i'm always skeptical of packages that "need" a fancy malloc, I hope this can be cleaned up. (nothing against jemalloc..)
[15:37] *extra-excludes
[15:37] slyon: https://irclogs.ubuntu.com/2024/11/03/%23ubuntu-release.html#t18:38
[15:37] thx
[15:37] cpaelzer: should investigate/delegate tmux
[15:38] libgit2 -> node-undici looks to be foundations, too? perhaps the http parser gizmo has a new requirement? I had the impression that there might be a good replacement for the http gizmo they were using, so there might be a very nice outcome there..
[15:39] python-osprofiler -> python-jaeger-client looks like openstack, is that one for jamespage to either file MIRs (my guess) or remove the dep?
[15:39] sarnold: Yes, I updated the attached MIR bug report. lining out 3 options, and would like to get some security team insights about the different approaches
[15:39] slyon: oh sweet :)
[15:39] plucky kernel seed feels like an aa thing to handle, another one for cpaelzer in a free moment?
[15:40] python-pint -> flexcache and flexparser, feels like another jamespage thing to drive
[15:40] ack, or maybe the kernel team themselves? Not sure who handles those usually, but they tend to go away after a while :)
[15:40] slyon: lol yes :)
[15:40] logcheck->esmtp feels like it'd be nice to take off the graph this cycle, through whatever means :)
[15:41] sarnold: probably - I'll take a look this week
[15:41] jamespage: thanks :)
[15:42] so .. that leaves the various unapproved MIRs .. we should probably try to figure out where each one of those is at, and see if they need assignment, or a poke, etc
[15:42] https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/jpeg-xl/+bug/2070882 and https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/highway/+bug/2070807 -- looks like these are back to jbicha for the moment
[15:42] -ubottu:#ubuntu-meeting- Launchpad bug 2070882 in jpeg-xl (Ubuntu) "[MIR] jpeg-xl" [Undecided, New]
[15:42] ACK, we probably want the original MIR reviewer to validate/update the case
[15:42] -ubottu:#ubuntu-meeting- Launchpad bug 2070807 in highway (Ubuntu) "[MIR] highway" [Undecided, New]
[15:43] https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/libgit2/+bug/2080872 is looking for advice, so please everyone give this a look and advise :) https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/libgit2/+bug/2080872
[15:43] -ubottu:#ubuntu-meeting- Launchpad bug 2080872 in node-undici (Ubuntu) "replace unmaintained http-parser dependency with llhttp" [Undecided, New]
[15:43] I believe jpeg-xl & highway are ready. architecture-properties also
[15:43] https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/architecture-properties/+bug/2080965
[15:43] -ubottu:#ubuntu-meeting- Launchpad bug 2080965 in architecture-properties (Ubuntu) "[MIR] architecture-properties" [Low, New]
[15:44] joalif: can you double-check jpeg-xl
[15:44] ?
[15:44] jbicha: could you add comments to the bugs with the current states? I thought jpeg-xl might still be waiting on security review? (but I haven't really looked in N weeks)
[15:44] I will double-check highway
[15:44] and I will double-check architecture properties
[15:45] architecture-properties confuses me, there's a bunch of i386 discussion there, but I thought this package was mostly about indicating 64 bit in general, or which flavor of amd64 instruction sets it supports?
[15:46] well, I might as well put that in the bug, I may not be the only one curious :)
[15:47] sarnold: I think it also provides some "is-32bit" / "is-64bit" (or alike) conditions
[15:47] so would be good to have on i386
[15:47] slyon: oops, jpeg-xl is blocked for security review, which means highway doesn't need to be promoted yet
[15:48] ok. Let's assign it to ubuntu-security then
[15:48] cool cool
[15:48] https://people.canonical.com/~ubuntu-archive/component-mismatches.svg
[15:48] all covered
[15:48] ack
[15:48] maybe we ought to swap the order of these links? heh
[15:49] #topic New MIRs
[15:49] Mission: ensure to assign all incoming reviews for fast processing
[15:49] #link https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/?field.searchtext=&orderby=-date_last_updated&field.status%3Alist=NEW&field.status%3Alist=CONFIRMED&assignee_option=none&field.assignee=&field.subscriber=ubuntu-mir
[15:49] looks like all four covered already
[15:49] #topic Incomplete bugs / questions
[15:49] Mission: Identify required actions and spread the load among the teams
[15:49] #link https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/?field.searchtext=&orderby=-date_last_updated&field.status%3Alist=INCOMPLETE_WITH_RESPONSE&field.status%3Alist=INCOMPLETE_WITHOUT_RESPONSE&field.subscriber=ubuntu-mir
[15:49] I created tracking bug #2087937
[15:50] -ubottu:#ubuntu-meeting- Bug 2087937 in sbuild (Ubuntu) "[MIR] mmdebstrap" [Undecided, In Progress] https://launchpad.net/bugs/2087937
[15:50] nothing actionable for us. I downgraded the Recommends in sbuild
[15:51] is ther any appetite for considering a switch to mmdebstrap? I understand it's way faster than debootstrap, and if this unshare mode is nice it might also be an improvement over chroots?
[15:51] I remember some recent discussion in Foundations about using it in ubuntu-image, which was rejected
[15:51] (I can dig up the details, if needed)
[15:52] it might be nice, I'm probably not the only one curious :)
[15:52] I'll add a link to the LP bug
[15:52] @slyon @jbicha wrt to jpeg-xl it needs a sec review plus highway to promoted
[15:53] https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/lenovo-wwan-unlock/+bug/2058192 is coming along nicely, it looks like they made some changes https://github.com/lenovo/lenovo-wwan-unlock/commit/255ec187a428a99710d0e44b165ee95436952830 so that's probably on me to review
[15:53] -ubottu:#ubuntu-meeting- Launchpad bug 2058192 in OEM Priority Project "[MIR] lenovo-wwan-unlock" [Critical, Confirmed]
[15:53] -ubottu:#ubuntu-meeting- Commit 255ec18 in lenovo/lenovo-wwan-unlock "An unconfined execute permission is too broad.(#31) (#32)"
[15:54] https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/linuxptp/+bug/2071717 looks like it's "back to ther reporter to handle this"? probably we can skip looking at the rest of this list
[15:54] -ubottu:#ubuntu-meeting- Launchpad bug 2071717 in linuxptp (Ubuntu) "[MIR] linuxptp" [Undecided, Incomplete]
[15:54] nothing new in here ^ needs more work by the OEM team
[15:54] #topic Process/Documentation improvements
[15:54] Mission: Review pending process/documentation pull-requests or issues
[15:54] #link https://github.com/canonical/ubuntu-mir/pulls
[15:54] #link https://github.com/canonical/ubuntu-mir/issues
[15:55] I seriously wish for a date from github on most recent change to a thing; anyway it feels like these are fine
[15:55] #topic MIR related Security Review Queue
[15:55] Mission: Check on progress, do deadlines seem doable?
[15:55] Some clients can only work with one, some with the other escaping - the URLs point to the same place.
[15:55] #link https://bugs.launchpad.net/~ubuntu-security/+bugs?field.searchtext=%5BMIR%5D&assignee_option=choose&field.assignee=ubuntu-security&field.bug_reporter=&field.bug_commenter=&field.subscriber=ubuntu-mir
[15:55] #link https://bugs.launchpad.net/~ubuntu-security/+bugs?field.searchtext=[MIR]&assignee_option=choose&field.assignee=ubuntu-security&field.bug_reporter=&field.bug_commenter=&field.subscriber=ubuntu-mir
[15:55] Internal link
[15:55] - ensure your teams items are prioritized among each other as you'd expect
[15:55] - ensure community requests do not get stomped by teams calling for favors too much
[15:55] #link https://warthogs.atlassian.net/jira/software/c/projects/SEC/boards/594
[15:55] hmm importance sort is probably not the best (it never is)
[15:57] well, here's hoping that this cycle is more effective than last cycle.. it's sad seeing last cycle's stuff on here :(
[15:58] I'm concerned about fdk-aac-free -- that code felt pretty abandoned :(
[15:58] otherwise i'll try to get some traction on these
[15:59] please do make sure the items in the jira are prioritised appropriately -- we can't always handle them in priority order, since we also try to match who is available with what is available with the time available, etc..
[15:59] but it certainly helps
[15:59] so..
[15:59] #topic Any other business?
[15:59] sarnold: I'd like you input on option A/B/C in https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/node-undici/+bug/2080872/comments/2 â doesn't need to be ad-hoc, but maybe as a comment on LP
[15:59] -ubottu:#ubuntu-meeting- Launchpad bug 2080872 in node-undici (Ubuntu) "replace unmaintained http-parser dependency with llhttp" [Undecided, New]
[16:00] slyon: ack, thanks for the reminder :)
[16:00] basically, we have no proper libllhttp package, so should consider how to vendor it
[16:00] oh dang, I was hoping it was "replace it with something less weird" :)
[16:01] well... its typescript being transpiled to C and then vendored as a shared object... tell me about weird :)
[16:01] *shudder*
[16:02] if that's it...
[16:02] #endmeeting
[16:02] Meeting ended at 16:02:04 UTC. Minutes at https://ubottu.com/meetingology/logs/ubuntu-meeting/2024/ubuntu-meeting.2024-11-12-15.35.moin.txt
[16:02] thanks all :)
[16:02] thanks sarnold for running the meeting today!
[16:02] thanks all :)
=== nicoz- is now known as nicoz

item.title: 11.11.2024: ubuntu-security, ubuntu-meeting
item.description:
# UBUNTU-SECURITY

=== JanC is now known as Guest8898
=== JanC is now known as Guest2142
=== JanC is now known as Guest8255

# UBUNTU-MEETING

=== JanC is now known as Guest8898
=== JanC is now known as Guest9427
=== JanC is now known as Guest2142
[15:59] \o
[15:59] hello there
[16:00] bdrung: alive but slow to type due to phone
[16:00] o/
[16:02] o/
[16:03] do we have quorum?
[16:04] Looks like we do?
[16:04] should i start?
[16:04] yep
[16:05] schopin has a public holiday today
[16:05] but remember my typing is slower since i'm here with my phone not my computer ;)
[16:05] okeydoke
[16:05] bdmurray: hey, if you're around :)
[16:05] its also technically a holiday here in the states - veterans day - and my office is closed for it
[16:05] tsimonq2: you too^
[16:06] #startmeeting Developer Membership Board
[16:06] Meeting started at 16:06:04 UTC. The chair is utkarsh2102. Information about MeetBot at https://wiki.ubuntu.com/meetingology
[16:06] Available commands: action, commands, idea, info, link, nick
[16:06] i'm gonna do the application first
[16:06] Agenda @ https://wiki.ubuntu.com/DeveloperMembershipBoard/Agenda
[16:07] #topic Ubuntu Core Dev Applications
[16:07] #subtopic Danilo Egea Gondolfo
[16:07] #link https://wiki.ubuntu.com/danilogondolfo/CoreDeveloperApplication
[16:07] danilogondolfo: hey! please introduce yourself whilst we go through your application
[16:09] sure :) Hi, I'm Danilo. Been around for 2 years. Until 3 weeks ago I used to work in the Foundations team, mainly in Netplan-related things. I just got transferred to the OCTO team.
[16:09] I'm still working on Netplan in my new team
[16:10] o/
[16:10] danilogondolfo: are you applying for core-dev directly? :)
[16:10] Do you have any examples of having done Ubuntu package merges that aren't simply carrying forward existing delta that didn't conflict?
[16:11] (ie. more than what MoM produces)
[16:11] utkarsh2102, yes, my friends managed to convince me I should go for core-dev after doing a lot of distro working during these years :)
[16:12] hm, okay
[16:12] danilogondolfo: also, have you done any SRU apart from netplan*?
[16:12] rbasak, let me see my list of merges...
[16:13] danilogondolfo: there doesn't seem to be a list on your application page?
[16:14] I've been digging through your full sponsorship miner report but I couldn't immediately see any that match the filter I suggest above
[16:15] rbasak, yeah I might not have worked on super complicated merges yet apparently
[16:16] err, I don't think those qualify as super complicated :)
[16:16] they're just not trivial.
[16:16] danilogondolfo: also, have you done any SRU apart from netplan*?
[16:16] On SRUs, I had the same question as utkarsh2102
[16:16] The first non-netplan SRU I found has https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/ipvsadm/+bug/2071949/comments/18
[16:16] -ubottu:#ubuntu-meeting- Launchpad bug 2071949 in ipvsadm (Ubuntu Noble) "[SRU] Missing frame pointers on Noble" [Undecided, Fix Released]
[16:16] utkarsh2102, yes I worked on network-manager SRUs and the ipvs one related to frame-pointers
[16:17] but indeed, most of them are netplan related
[16:17] I looked at the ipvsadm SRU and that one looks good to me
[16:17] For a direct to core dev application I'd expect to see _excellent_ examples of prior work, and that SRU comment suggests to me that you included unexpected additional changes without explanation, which is the opposite of that.
[16:18] It's OK if that was just one amongst many SRUs, but I can't really count the netplan ones because they are excepted from most usual SRU requirements.
[16:19] this^
[16:19] rbasak, yes, I included some changes I initially though would be useful, those were some improvements in the rules file
[16:20] danilogondolfo: have you done seed changes before? d'you understand how seed/germinate/metapackages work?
[16:20] well, to be fair not all my netplan SRUs are version updates
[16:21] danilogondolfo: but with no SRU documentation though
[16:21] utkarsh2102, no, I have not. I believe I know those work
[16:22] rbasak, not sure if I followed
[16:22] I've always done all the paperwork correctly as far as I know
[16:22] danilogondolfo: your extra changes werent documented or explained as part of that SRU. Which is opposite of expectations
[16:23] thats what Robie is saying
[16:23] danilogondolfo: can you explain what is Task-Key, Task-Seeds, etc?
[16:23] danilogondolfo: not all my netplan SRUs are version updates> fair enough - I found https://launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/netplan.io/0.107-5ubuntu0.1 that lgtm
[16:24] danilogondolfo: http://launchpadlibrarian.net/739652449/ipvsadm_1%3A1.31-1build3_1%3A1.31-1ubuntu0.1.diff.gz is your initial (sponsored) upload that led to https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/ipvsadm/+bug/2071949/comments/18. AFAICT, that change came with no SRU justification or explanation except in that changelog entry, contrary to SRU expectations.
[16:24] utkarsh2102, I'm familiar with the terms from past conversation but I'm afraid I don't remember right now what they are exactl
[16:24] -ubottu:#ubuntu-meeting- Launchpad bug 2071949 in ipvsadm (Ubuntu Noble) "[SRU] Missing frame pointers on Noble" [Undecided, Fix Released]
[16:25] danilogondolfo: if I'm mistaken, then please do correct me though!
[16:25] rbasak, fair enough
[16:25] (stepping away for 3 minutes because i have a call i have to take)
[16:26] danilogondolfo: so we didn't find an example of a non-trivial merge, so let me ask about them instead.
[16:27] danilogondolfo: if you add a delta to a package in Ubuntu (eg. for +1 maintenance for some package in universe), what's your process for ensuring that the package doesn't languish in the future?
[16:29] rbasak, unless it is a very ubuntu specific delta, the patch should be sent to Debian and we should communicate with the maintainer to have it incorporated there. This way we can just sync the whole package back in the future
[16:30] Would you hold up proposed migration in Ubuntu while you wait on a response from a maintainer in Debian?
[16:31] (let's say you have a patch ready, and it doesn't have wider implications to just apply in Ubuntu)
[16:32] rbasak, no, waiting for a response can take a unknown amount of time. My experience is that the core-dev will accept merges with the condition we'll keep an eye in the package. For these cases we'll keep an LP bug opened for tracking
[16:33] fixing the thing on Ubuntu while we wait for Debian might unblock many other things that were waiting on that migration
[16:33] OK, so let's say that happens, and the package migrates. What do you expect to happen in the future such that the package can be synced in the future, as you suggest above?
[16:34] (returned, sorry for my disappearance)
[16:34] I'm asking specifically about your process to detect that situation when it occurs
[16:34] ...so that you know to act.
[16:39] rbasak, I'd track the Debian bug in the LP bug and/or keep an eye on the merge proposal periodically. If there is a new package to be sync while the development window on Ubuntu is opened I'd request a sync. If we are at feature freeze and the thing it not critical I'd wait until the next release. In any case, when a new package is available with the patch, we'll see it in merge-o-matic so we would see it and
[16:39] investigate the status
[16:40] OK
[16:41] how would another person doing the package merge know about all of this?
[16:42] Possibly the same question: "we would see it" -> who is "we"? What's the process for ensuring that such a package does get attention?
[16:44] utkarsh2102, well it's a good practice to look at LP bugs when working on a merge. Like, when I start the merge and see a delta I will check if it could be dropped, ideally there will be an LP bug about it with all the details. At least the changelog should point me to the bug report so I can investigate the delta
[16:45] danilogondolfo: I'm not really seeing the answer I'm looking for, so let me rephrase: how is it that someone doing a package merge for a package in universe where the delta got added as part of +1 maintenance actually ended up looking to merge that package in the first place?
[16:46] that's pretty much giving it away, Robie :)
[16:46] I agree it'll show up in MoM. But what's the process for getting from a package being listed in MoM, to someone actually merging it?
[16:46] Who is responsible?
[16:46] rbasak, some teams, such as Foundations, have weekly meeting to deal with the archive. It's a collective effort to ensure that things will migrate, FTBFSs are fixed. We also assign bug to teams so people will look at them every week.
[16:47] danilogondolfo: AFAIK, that doesn't apply to packages in universe though?
[16:47] danilogondolfo, and for universe packages?
[16:49] for packages in universe whoever is doing the +1 shift will, eventually, look at them
[16:49] ok, we're nearing the time limit - I am ready to vote.
[16:49] so am I
[16:49] rbasak, bdrung?
[16:49] danilogondolfo, imagine you found a bug in glibc while working on netplan and you developed a patch for it. What would be your next steps?
[16:50] Given the time, I agree we need to move to voting.
[16:50] (I had no time to place my question)
[16:50] go on, we'll wait for you :)
[16:51] given Danilo replies quickly enough ;)
[16:51] ok, should I answer that one?
[16:51] ok
[16:51] should I answer that one? > yes
[16:53] bdrung, well, I'd first reach out to the maintainer on Ubuntu as glibc is super important. If the patch is accepted I'd work with them to get it merged in the package and submitted upstream.
[16:53] danilogondolfo, thanks.
[16:53] I am ready to vote.
[16:54] woot
[16:54] #voters bdrung, rbasak, teward, utkarsh2102
[16:54] Current voters: bdrung, rbasak, teward, utkarsh2102
[16:54] -1 reasons to follow
[16:55] #vote Danilo to get Core Dev rights
[16:55] Please vote on: Danilo to get Core Dev rights
[16:55] Public votes can be registered by saying +1, -1 or +0 in channel (for private voting, private message me with 'vote +1|-1|+0 #channelname')
[16:55] try that again rbasak :P
[16:55] rbasak was toooooo eager, tch tch
[16:55] -1 reasons to follow
[16:55] -1 reasons to follow received from rbasak
[16:55] Sorry, busy writing up my rationale!
[16:58] -1; for a person going to core dev directly, I expect them to be excellent in at least knowing most of the things/terminologies/processes about Ubuntu and demonstrating experience in some of them (ideally, all of them). In your particular case, I didn't see any merges, regular SRUs, etc and also not the answers we were looking for. I think the
[16:58] -1; for a person going to core dev directly, I expect them to be excellent in at least knowing most of the things/terminologies/processes about Ubuntu and demonstrating experience in some of them (ideally, all of them). In your particular case, I didn't see any merges, regular SRUs, etc and also not the answers we were looking for. I think the received from utkarsh2102
[16:58] right path foward would be, at least, MOTU -> Core Dev (unless you want to start by netplan PPU). Anyway, we appreciate your work and I'd really like to see you get core-dev soon but I'm afraid there's quite a lot of work needed to get there. Apologies it didn't work out this time.
[16:59] I need to go very soon so I'll post my rationale now.
[16:59] -1 (short rationale to follow)
[16:59] -1 (short rationale to follow) received from teward
[17:00] +0 on the plus side: he knows the processes and when to talk to people (glibc example); on the downside: the initial ipvsadm SRU patch were not in the minimal needed version, the amount of packages touched outside of netplan are less widespread than what i like to see on a coredev application.
[17:00] +0 on the plus side: he knows the processes and when to talk to people (glibc example); on the downside: the initial ipvsadm SRU patch were not in the minimal needed version, the amount of packages touched outside of netplan are less widespread than what i like to see on a coredev application. received from bdrung
[17:00] #endvote
[17:00] Voting ended on: Danilo to get Core Dev rights
[17:00] Votes for: 0, Votes against: 3, Abstentions: 1
[17:00] Motion denied
[17:01] I am not confident in that you have the requisite understanding of package processes and policies. I also don't see requisite experience in merges, standard SRUs, etc. nor answers to questions asked. I agree with utkarsh2102 that you need to go with the path of MOTU -> Core Dev, or just apply for netplan PPU, and show more experience in SRUs, merges, etc. before we can give you unrestricted upload rights.
[17:01] unfortunately the vote is not quorate, so we require the vote to be continued to the ML for secondary voting
[17:01] In general the work that you have done seems excellent. Please keep it up!
[17:01] I'm not sure you're ready for core dev yet though, which (unfortunately, today) means unsupervised access to upload to the Ubuntu archive.
[17:01] I'm concerned that you're missing the overall picture of how Ubuntu delta maintainence works. It appears that if you were left unsupervised uploading +1 fixes then these would build up and languish, and Ubuntu users would find packages in releases that are on old versions because they weren't synced or merged when a sync was available.
[17:01] We can correct this particular understanding right now, but my concern is that all we're doing is a spot check, and similar gaps might also be present in various other aspects of Ubuntu development that we expect core devs to know.
[17:01] We also didn't see evidence of non-trivial merges, and your recent SRU history is mixed, possibly because your non-exception SRU work is fairly thin.
[17:01] I was initially on +1, but I changed it to +0 after seing the -1 to make the vote quorate
[17:01] Unfortunately the necessary discussion there meant that I didn't manage to consider the other aspects I usually look for (https://wiki.ubuntu.com/RobieBasak/DMB/CoreDev).
[17:01] For a direct to core dev application I expect a particularly strong application. I'm sorry I don't think that's the case here.
[17:01] Next steps: I don't think there's anything in particular you need to change about what you're doing, except to continuing gaining experience across the archive. What'd I'd like to see in a re-application is a wider and deeper track record of uploads to the main archive component that are more impactful and required deeper review. I appreciate that you're doing this kind of work for netplan already,
[17:02] but for a core dev application, I think it needs to be much wider than this.
[17:02] bdrung: if you're +0 and the three of us are -1, there's still 3 members who can vote +1 and then it ends in a tie. So we need to have input from the other DMB members to finalize the vote.
[17:02] #action utkarsh2102 to reply to the thread with the conclusion
[17:02] ACTION: utkarsh2102 to reply to the thread with the conclusion
[17:02] teward: I'm not sure about netplan PPU - see the ML thread on "core packages". The question remains open, including on whether netplan would be considered "core" or not. But I don't want to set danilogondolfo up for a netplan PPU only to be blocked by that :-/
[17:02] teward: i don't think so, it's never going to be quorate
[17:02] yeah that's cool. I appreciate all the comments
[17:03] teward, no, we would need to reach +1 in sum (but we can only reach +0 if all 3 remaining members would vote +1)
[17:03] the max we could get with 3 votes is 0, with -3 right now
[17:03] rbasak: good point, but I think if they primarily work with netplan and that's their primary focus, that could be an Exception as they're also on Foundations but you're right.
[17:03] teward: I would suggest that in the case of a tie, the motion isn't passed and the status quo would remain.
[17:03] rbasak: i agree, but that needs defined in our operational spec/docs
[17:04] operations / procedures *
[17:04] I desperately need more coffee. *goes to brew some*
[17:04] anyway, anyway, we're at time. I'll close the meeting now formally.
[17:04] informal discussions can still happen.
[17:04] but i'll wait 10 seconds unless someone has some thing they'd like to speak about
[17:04] 5
[17:04] 4
[17:04] 3
[17:04] 2
[17:05] 1
[17:05] #endvote
[17:05] No vote in progress
[17:05] crap :P
[17:05] Thank you all for your time :)
[17:05] #endmeeting
[17:05] Meeting ended at 17:05:09 UTC. Minutes at https://ubottu.com/meetingology/logs/ubuntu-meeting/2024/ubuntu-meeting.2024-11-11-16.06.moin.txt
[17:05] ye i think you meant that one utkarsh ;)
[17:05] danilogondolfo: thank you, see you soon! :)
[17:05] teward: hehe yeah :)
[17:06] ok, i ought to drop
[17:06] see y'all o/
[17:06] :wq!
[17:06] This meeting reminds me to respond on the PPU for "core packages" ML thread.

item.title: 06.11.2024: ubuntu-security, ubuntu-meeting
item.description:
# UBUNTU-SECURITY

[10:11] ebarretto: hello, we are again in the same boat as last week, the OVAL CVE data was last updated on 2024-11-02T00:37:02
[10:16] mpiano: yep, I triggered a manual build an hour ago and it is in the last steps
[10:18] thanks for the context, I'll keep monitoring the situation on our side then
=== sespiros_ is now known as sespiros
[15:24] Good day. CVE-2023-40548 looks to have a version error in it. It mentions "Fixed 15.8-0ubuntu1" but the actual version is "1.58+15.8-0ubuntu1". Should the version in the CVE not match the deb package version, not the Microsoft upstream shim version? https://ubuntu.com/security/CVE-2023-40548
[15:24] -ubottu:#ubuntu-security- A buffer overflow was found in Shim in the 32-bit system. The overflow happens due to an addition operation involving a user-controlled value parsed from the PE binary being used by Shim. This value is further used for memory allocation operations, leading to a heap-based buffer overflow. This flaw causes memory corruption and can lead to a crash or data integrity ...
[15:24] We have an issue for this (with discussion) on our vulnerability data. https://github.com/anchore/vulnerability-match-exclusion-database/issues/229
[15:25] hi popey!
[15:25] one sec, let me check
[15:26] popey: the source package version seems to be 15.8-0ubuntu1 https://launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/shim
[15:26] where are you seeing 1.58+15.8-0ubuntu1?
[15:27] I can't access that github link
[15:27] https://launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/shim-signed
[15:27] oh, sorry.
[15:28] this is one of those idiotic debian packaging particularities...the source package doesn't have the same version as the binary packages
[15:28] the source package is in fact versioned as 1.58, while the binary packages do in fact seem to be versioned as 1.58+15.8-0ubuntu1
[15:29] Oh dear.
[15:29] Ok, thanks for looking.
[15:29] we track source packages in our cve tracker
[15:29] so, your tooling may need to be modified to handle this type of weird case, unfortunately
[15:30] .oO( I wonder how many of these weird cases there are )
[15:31] I've seen it perhaps 2-3 times that I can remember, definitely not common
[15:31] I think we do try to get the source version in Grype, but it depends on the available metadata in the analysis
[15:31] Ok. Thank you.
[15:32] np!
[16:11] mdeslaur sorry - if 1.58 (as you say) is the source version, why does the CVE tracker show 15.8 for both shim and shim-signed? https://git.launchpad.net/ubuntu-cve-tracker/tree/active/CVE-2023-40548#n62
[16:11] -ubottu:#ubuntu-security- A buffer overflow was found in Shim in the 32-bit system. The overflow happens due to an addition operation involving a user-controlled value parsed from the PE binary being used by Shim. This value is further used for memory allocation operations, leading to a heap-based buffer overflow. This flaw causes memory corruption and can lead to a crash or data integrity ...
[16:12] popey: those are two different source packages
[16:12] popey: and they are versioned like that
[16:12] https://launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/shim
[16:12] https://launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/shim-signed
[16:12] one sec, let me look again
[16:13] oh you are totally right
[16:13] my bad
[16:13] Que? One is 1.59 (1.58 in LTS) and the other is 15.8. The shim-signed is 1.58 but in the CVE it's 15.8
[16:13] one sec, I'll fix
[16:15] popey: https://git.launchpad.net/ubuntu-cve-tracker/commit/?id=c758006a7f9b00d92ce91c1aa4c3e07e7a3fe2e7
[16:15] -ubottu:#ubuntu-security- Commit c758006 in ubuntu-cve-tracker "fix wrong versioning in shim-signed CVE HEAD master"
[16:15] sorry for the confusion
[16:16] Nice one. There may be more... :)
[16:16] also, where are my glasses?
[16:16] yeah, there are more, let me search for the others
[16:16] I would post an 'old age' skull emoji, but we're on irc. So y'know.
[16:17] CVE-2023-40546 shim-signed < 15.8CVE-2023-40547 shim-signed < 15.8CVE-2023-40548 shim-signed < 15.8CVE-2023-40549 shim-signed < 15.8CVE-2023-40550 shim-signed < 15.8CVE-2023-40551 shim-signed < 15.8
[16:17] -ubottu:#ubuntu-security- A flaw was found in Shim when an error happened while creating a new ESL variable. If Shim fails to create the new variable, it tries to print an error message to the user; however, the number of parameters used by the logging function doesn't match the format string used by it, leading to a crash under certain circumstances.
[16:17] -ubottu:#ubuntu-security- A remote code execution vulnerability was found in Shim. The Shim boot support trusts attacker-controlled values when parsing an HTTP response. This flaw allows an attacker to craft a specific malicious HTTP request, leading to a completely controlled out-of-bounds write primitive and complete system compromise. This flaw is only exploitable during the early boot p...
[16:17] -ubottu:#ubuntu-security- A buffer overflow was found in Shim in the 32-bit system. The overflow happens due to an addition operation involving a user-controlled value parsed from the PE binary being used by Shim. This value is further used for memory allocation operations, leading to a heap-based buffer overflow. This flaw causes memory corruption and can lead to a crash or data integrity ...
[16:17] -ubottu:#ubuntu-security- An out-of-bounds read flaw was found in Shim due to the lack of proper boundary verification during the load of a PE binary. This flaw allows an attacker to load a crafted PE binary, triggering the issue and crashing Shim, resulting in a denial of service.
[16:17] -ubottu:#ubuntu-security- An out-of-bounds read flaw was found in Shim when it tried to validate the SBAT information. This issue may expose sensitive data during the system's boot phase.
[16:17] -ubottu:#ubuntu-security- A flaw was found in the MZ binary format in Shim. An out-of-bounds read may occur, leading to a crash or possible exposure of sensitive data during the system's boot phase.
[16:17] sorry mr bot
[16:18] https://git.launchpad.net/ubuntu-cve-tracker/commit/?id=20f316be9ad7db4696f7e2ef58953b42f3c943d7
[16:18] -ubottu:#ubuntu-security- Commit 20f316b in ubuntu-cve-tracker "fixed more shim-signed wrong versions HEAD master"
[16:19] Yay! Thanks!
[16:19] np :)

item.title: 05.11.2024: ubuntu-security, ubuntu-meeting
item.description:
# UBUNTU-SECURITY

=== Juesto is now known as Juest
[16:24] mdeslaur_: other than the random piece of toilet paper on your foot, can you prod IS / Web and tell them they have some major HTTP 500 errors on the CVE search page
[16:28] teward: I prodded them a year when those errors started
[16:28] well they're back,.
[16:29] making CVE searching unusable. Do you know if this is an API level outage or something else?
[16:29] no idea, sorry
[16:29] no worries. You might want to remove that toilet paper ;) *hands you your original nick back*
[16:30] the search here? https://ubuntu.com/security/notices
=== mdeslaur_ is now known as mdeslaur
[16:30] heh, was wondering what you were talking about :)
[16:31] kind of looks like it's working for me now...
[16:31] at least it didn't explode when I typed in firefox
[16:32] * mdeslaur -> lunch
[16:33] heh firefox must be a hot topic lately 'cause i kept mentioning it in -devel xD
[16:34] hmm you're right it looks like its working *now*. IS must be breaking things
[17:00] the packages.u.c site often gets 500 errors too, I wonder if that's related...
[17:07] JanC: wouldn't be surprised
[17:11] ah, it's broken now
[17:11] * mdeslaur screams swear words while mashing retry button like a maniac
=== Someguy96 is now known as TooManyHats96
[19:50] I reported 500s in here on the 30th too, for reference, and filed https://github.com/canonical/ubuntu.com/issues/14454 at the same time.
[19:50] -ubottu:#ubuntu-security- Issue 14454 in canonical/ubuntu.com "'500: Server Error' when searching USNs" [Open]
[19:52] And, yeah, the failures were intermittent for me also.
[19:53] (Can't believe Marc hasn't already attended to this personally ;.; /s)
[19:53] * mdeslaur pulls out his "web crap for dummies" book
[19:54] huh, says here the "Information Superhighway" is going to change how business is done
[19:55] I would simply not write a 500 status code to the response stream, it would be easy for me.
[19:55] unfortunately, the screaming I did earlier didn't help at all, but now I need to figure out where the cat is hiding
[19:56] Odd_Bloke: hehe
[19:58] I hear there's a handy Cat Venue Explorer search box on ubuntu.com, that'll probably help
[19:59] oh, it says 500! that's my cat's name!
[19:59] hehe *sigh*
[21:01] ^_^

# UBUNTU-MEETING

=== phckopper5 is now known as phckopper
=== mdeslaur_ is now known as mdeslaur
[20:00] o/
[20:00] hey
[20:01] sil2100 isn't here
[20:01] amurray: around?
[20:01] I suspect Steve is out
[20:02] o/
[20:02] hey :)
[20:02] I don't see any recent ML activity.
[20:04] Looking at IRC logs we skipped the previous meeting on 2024-10-08 as there were only two of us.
[20:04] right
[20:04] Shall we run through everything quickly as it's been a while?
[20:04] At least there are three.
[20:04] +1
[20:05] #startmeeting Ubuntu Technical Board
[20:05] Meeting started at 20:05:02 UTC. The chair is rbasak. Information about MeetBot at https://wiki.ubuntu.com/meetingology
[20:05] Available commands: action, commands, idea, info, link, nick
[20:05] #topic Action review
[20:05] ACTION: vorlon to look into scripting for packages in flavor-specific overlays
[20:05] #actionvorlon to look into scripting for packages in flavor-specific overlays
[20:05] #action vorlon to look into scripting for packages in flavor-specific overlays
[20:05] ACTION: vorlon to look into scripting for packages in flavor-specific overlays
[20:05] ACTION: seb128 to continue working with AA and Release teams to document their membership process and link to it from https://wiki.ubuntu.com/TechnicalBoard#Team_Delegations
[20:05] carry over please
[20:05] #action seb128 to continue working with AA and Release teams to document their membership process and link to it from https://wiki.ubuntu.com/TechnicalBoard#Team_Delegations
[20:05] ACTION: seb128 to continue working with AA and Release teams to document their membership process and link to it from https://wiki.ubuntu.com/TechnicalBoard#Team_Delegations
[20:05] ACTION: sil2100 to follow up on the Cinnamon 24.04 LTS Qualification to ensure the listed contacts can action the flavor
[20:05] #action sil2100 to follow up on the Cinnamon 24.04 LTS Qualification to ensure the listed contacts can action the flavor
[20:05] ACTION: sil2100 to follow up on the Cinnamon 24.04 LTS Qualification to ensure the listed contacts can action the flavor
[20:06] ACTION: rbasak to document the third party software sources policy somewhere appropriate
[20:06] This one is done.
[20:06] \o/
[20:06] #topic Scan the mailing list archive for anything we missed (standing item)
[20:06] I didn't see anything
[20:06] #info Nothing recent on the mailing list that requires attention
[20:06] #topic Check up on community bugs and techboard bugs
[20:07] #info No open community bugs
[20:07] #info One outstanding techboard bugs on DMB member inactivity causing issues
[20:07] I need to drive that one still.
[20:07] Nothing else that I can see.
[20:07] #topic Select a chair for the next meeting (next from https://launchpad.net/~techboard/+members)
[20:08] #info The next chair will be seb128 with vorlon as backup
[20:08] #topic AOB
[20:08] AOB?
[20:08] o/
[20:08] yes, one, the board expire end of decembre ... is that something we should start doing something about?
[20:09] Ah yes. Good point!
[20:09] like organize elections or something before it's end of year break?
[20:09] Usually the CC run the TB elections IIRC
[20:09] Could you take an action item to contact them about it, please?
[20:09] yes
[20:09] #action seb128 to contact the CC regarding the upcoming TB elections
[20:09] ACTION: seb128 to contact the CC regarding the upcoming TB elections
[20:09] Thanks!
[20:09] thx
[20:09] AOAOB?
[20:09] not from me :)
[20:09] nor from me
[20:10] #endmeeting
[20:10] Meeting ended at 20:10:16 UTC. Minutes at https://ubottu.com/meetingology/logs/ubuntu-meeting/2024/ubuntu-meeting.2024-11-05-20.05.moin.txt
[20:10] Thanks all!
[20:10] thanks!
[20:10] thanks rbasak
[20:10] efficient meeting today, nice job rbasak :-)

item.title: 01.11.2024: ubuntu-security, ubuntu-meeting
item.description:
# UBUNTU-SECURITY

=== Montresor is now known as Unit193
[09:20] listening to this weeks podcast now
[09:59] Hi, do we have any idea when the tomcat10 package for 24.04 will be updated? The package is 11months old and has 4 high scoring CVEs (CVE-2024-24549 CVE-2024-23672 CVE-2024-38286 CVE-2024-34750)
[09:59] -ubottu:#ubuntu-security- Denial of Service due to improper input validation vulnerability for HTTP/2 requests in Apache Tomcat. When processing an HTTP/2 request, if the request exceeded any of the configured limits for headers, the associated HTTP/2 stream was not reset until after all of the headers had been processed.This issue affects Apache Tomcat: from 11.0.0-M1 through 11.0.0-M16, f...
[09:59] -ubottu:#ubuntu-security- Denial of Service via incomplete cleanup vulnerability in Apache Tomcat. It was possible for WebSocket clients to keep WebSocket connections open leading to increased resource consumption.This issue affects Apache Tomcat: from 11.0.0-M1 through 11.0.0-M16, from 10.1.0-M1 through 10.1.18, from 9.0.0-M1 through 9.0.85, from 8.5.0 through 8.5.98. Users are recommended...
[09:59] -ubottu:#ubuntu-security- ** RESERVED ** This candidate has been reserved by an organization or individual that will use it when announcing a new security problem. When the candidate has been publicized, the details for this candidate will be provided.
[09:59] -ubottu:#ubuntu-security- Improper Handling of Exceptional Conditions, Uncontrolled Resource Consumption vulnerability in Apache Tomcat. When processing an HTTP/2 stream, Tomcat did not handle some cases of excessive HTTP headers correctly. This led to a miscounting of active HTTP/2 streams which in turn led to the use of an incorrect infinite timeout which allowed connections to remain ope...
[10:01] This is based off https://tomcat.apache.org/security-10.html
[10:01] 24.10 has a package for 10.1.25 currently, that was available in July
[10:26] I have created a question against that particular package, and can convert to a bug if required.
[10:32] simonb: tomcat10 is in universe, therefore it is community maintained. If you are able, I suggest coordinating with upstream and posting a debdiff for this issue. When a debdiff is available, members of the security team will review it and publish the package. See the following link for more information: https://wiki.ubuntu.com/SecurityTeam/UpdateProcedures
[10:34] This is where Im struggling, as I've been pointed to SRU and told wont fix, then directed to you. I'm happy to get involved, patch, build, or anything that is required. But Im only being directed to other people/teams.
[10:38] simonb: SRU process is not for security updates, that's why the forward you to us. The wiki has some pointers on patching, triaging and so forth. If you want to first create a bug, we can help you along the process of patching and publishing it. I recommend you take some time to go through the wiki as it is a lot of information
[10:45] Thank you. I shall do that.
[10:59] he made bug #2086358
[10:59] -ubottu:#ubuntu-security- Bug 2086358 in tomcat10 (Ubuntu) "Multiple CVE patches, bugfixes, and enhancements availble for 11month old LTS package." [Undecided, New] https://launchpad.net/bugs/2086358
[11:13] thanks lotuspsychje
[11:13] welcome
[13:37] hello I have a question: Im using Ubuntu in safe gfxmode right now, and dmesg gives me LSM: initializing lsm=lockdown,capability,landlock,yama,apparmor,ima,evm
[13:37] which is instruction for kernel_lockdown to free some components from lockdown.
[13:37] Im looking for documentation of these instructions, which parameters are possible
[13:38] where to put in these parameters? because there is nothing in /proc/cmdline about lsm!
[14:48] this man page gives me only a hint, no details: https://man7.org/linux/man-pages/man7/kernel_lockdown.7.html
[15:19] well, these parameters are fixed written into the kernel, in autoconf.h the possible parameters are within kernel docs only: https://docs.kernel.org/userspace-api/landlock.html
=== Juesto is now known as Juest

item.description:
# UBUNTU-SECURITY

=== sam__ is now known as sam_
=== JanC is now known as Guest1081

# UBUNTU-MEETING

=== pushkarnk1 is now known as pushkarnk
=== pushkarnk1 is now known as pushkarnk
[15:00] o7
[15:00] o/
[15:00] o/
[15:00] o/
[15:00] #startmeeting Weekly Ubuntu Foundations team
[15:00] Meeting started at 15:00:54 UTC. The chair is juliank. Information about MeetBot at https://wiki.ubuntu.com/meetingology
[15:00] Available commands: action, commands, idea, info, link, nick
[15:00] #topic Lightning rounds
[15:01] #link https://discourse.ubuntu.com/t/foundations-team-updates-thursday-2024-10-17/
[15:01] o/
[15:01] o/
[15:01] o/
[15:01] o/
[15:01] o/
[15:02] \o
[15:02] o/
[15:02] o/
[15:03] \o
[15:03] o/
[15:04] what are we using LLVM-18 in focal for? that backport is scary
[15:04] mkukri: two words: Firefox Thunderbird
[15:04] \o
[15:04] ah ic that explains it
[15:07] fwiw I'm working on accessing the reports.qa.ubuntu.com but I'm timing out so far
[15:07] But it might be trying https only for now
[15:07] Obviously my firefox is set https-only, and the site doesn't have https
[15:07] juliank: working fine with http
[15:08] But _normally_ there should be a fallback button once it fails to upgrade
[15:08] I'll probably see to enable https this cycle, but sadly won't hack that right now :-)
[15:08] In my report I have a stack overflow link where I had to tweak hsts to get the sponsoring report to load
[15:09] I'll restart my firefox
[15:09] i need to find some time to figure out how to setup letsencrypt with juju
[15:10] for the sponsoring report
[15:11] Oh yes
[15:11] dbungert: Thanks
[15:12] So I guess it turns out ubuntu.com enabled HSTS for all *.ubuntu.com
[15:12] So it's not possible to visit the reports after having been to the web page once
[15:13] #topic Release incoming bugs
[15:13] #link http://reports.qa.ubuntu.com/reports/rls-mgr/rls-oo-incoming-bug-tasks.html#foundations-bugs
[15:13] there isn't HSTS on autopkgtest.ubuntu.com, so no
[15:13] You can try w3m instead
[15:13] works for me
[15:13] It works now after clearing all ubuntu.com data in firefox
[15:13] Skia: I had to remove the inherited value for ubuntu.com
[15:13] There is already a bug in http://reqorts.qa.ubuntu.com/reports/rls-mgr/rls-pp-incoming-bug-tasks.html#foundations-bugs :)
[15:13] oh, okay, I see what you meant now
[15:13] bug 2084208
[15:14] -ubottu:#ubuntu-meeting- Bug 2084208 in ubuntu-release-upgrader (Ubuntu) "do-release-upgrade fails when esm is enabled" [Medium, Confirmed] https://launchpad.net/bugs/2084208
[15:14] afraid that report really doesn't work in w3m ... too much js :)
[15:14] upils: Sigh it's too early!
[15:14] That sounds striaght forward and awkward
[15:14] Let's just take it
[15:14] upils: we've been kicking that down the road for a while :)
[15:15] oh yeah!
[15:15] bug 2083942
[15:15] -ubottu:#ubuntu-meeting- Bug 2083942 in ubuntu-release-upgrader (Ubuntu) "snaps are not upgraded to the latest version before upgrading to the next ubuntu release" [Wishlist, Triaged] https://launchpad.net/bugs/2083942
[15:15] I believe we should take that too
[15:15] juliank: should we just block upgrades if esm is enabled in that case?
[15:15] sorry, I don't think we concluded the previous bug
[15:16] enr0n: We probably need to remove the sources and justu pgrade
[15:17] juliank: hm, I don't have a great understanding of how the ESM stuff works, but it seems to me that this might be unexpected for users
[15:17] enr0n: there is no esm for interim releases so the expectation is for it to be disabled again
[15:18] Otherwise youc an't upgrade
[15:18] juliank: right, I am just wondering if this should be made clear to users who might not realize that. Just a y/n prompt
[15:18] Or you can prompt I suppose
[15:18] this feels like a product-y question
[15:18] Or we could publish empty ESM repositories for non-LTS, shrug
[15:19] That's a question for the Pro team
[15:19] anyways, we can move on I think
[15:20] Yes
[15:20] so snaps, should we refresh them all during release upgrade?
[15:20] They should get refreshed on reboot, and we prompt for reboot
[15:21] We used to actually do the refresh during upgrades, but that caused bugs in some cases, so we changed the logic to do the channel switch if needed
[15:21] And let the next refresh do the work
[15:21] You are saying all snaps are refreshed at boot?
[15:21] My understanding was that snapd had some logic for this, yes
[15:21] But I am not 100% sure actually
[15:21] Well let's add a snapd task
[15:23] #link http://reports.qa.ubuntu.com/reports/rls-mgr/rls-nn-incoming-bug-tasks.html#foundations-bugs
[15:23] bug 2041518 is still with desktop
[15:23] -ubottu:#ubuntu-meeting- Bug 2041518 in gtk+3.0 (Ubuntu) "/usr/share/apport/apport-gtk:5:_g_log_abort:g_log_writer_default:g_log_structured_array:g_log_structured_array:g_log_structured_standard" [Undecided, New] https://launchpad.net/bugs/2041518
[15:23] bug 2078579
[15:23] -ubottu:#ubuntu-meeting- Bug 2078579 in ubuntu-release-upgrader (Ubuntu) "Holding Back libpcap0.8t64:amd64 rather than change libibverbs1:amd64" [Undecided, Triaged] https://launchpad.net/bugs/2078579
[15:24] This is one of those awkward deep deives
[15:25] I can't quite think about that; we need to dive deeper but we don't want to spend a week debugging the solver for this either
[15:26] Let's move on for now
[15:26] bug 2081323
[15:26] -ubottu:#ubuntu-meeting- Bug 2081323 in ubuntu-release-upgrader (Ubuntu) "Local-only mirror disabled; no mirror left" [Undecided, Triaged] https://launchpad.net/bugs/2081323
[15:26] So we had a discussion about a similar issue vorlon but here we have a local mirror that does not work *but* an ESM archive enabled, so it still believes there was a mirror and doesn't produce useful messages or something
[15:27] 2024-09-20 17:57:28,720 ERROR No 'ubuntu-minimal' available/downloadable after sources.list rewrite+update
[15:27] 2024-09-20 17:57:28,720 ERROR 'ubuntu-minimal' was not downloadable
[15:27] This is not really helpful for the user
[15:27] And I *think* without ESM it would use archive.ubuntu.com because it sees no official Ubuntu source?
[15:28] (I don't recall a similar issue I was involved in fwiw)
[15:28] yeah,if the esm archive was not present (i.e. no valid sourcec found) that should be the fallback
[15:28] vorlon: well to be fair it was like 2-3 months ago :D
[15:28] FWIW I think --allow-third-party or whatever also allows local mirrors
[15:28] yeah
[15:29] So we should take this, improve the error message and special case "only ESM is a valid source"
[15:29] ack
[15:30] bug 2083068
[15:30] -ubottu:#ubuntu-meeting- Bug 2083068 in glib2.0 (Ubuntu) "Broken libglib2.0-dev:i386 Depends on python3:i386 < none | 3.12.3-0ubuntu2 @un uH >" [Undecided, Triaged] https://launchpad.net/bugs/2083068
[15:30] glib2.0 is shared so we could take this
[15:30] juliank: I remember stuff around broken local mirrors but not about esm being enabled :)
[15:31] I'll go take the glib2.0 I guess, desktop did not seem interested :D
[15:32] And I assigned it myself to, I need to re-validate the fix
[15:32] bug 2083575
[15:32] -ubottu:#ubuntu-meeting- Bug 2083575 in ubuntu-release-upgrader (Ubuntu) "failed upgrade left apt sources on wrong release" [Undecided, Triaged] https://launchpad.net/bugs/2083575
[15:32] enr0n: this is funny
[15:32] looking
[15:33] I guess we should abort the upgrade or install ubuntu-minimal first
[15:33] Or except KeyError: print("blah")
[15:33] what in the
[15:34] but original sources should always be restored, I guess
[15:34] (on failure)
[15:34] yeah
[15:34] but if you don't have ubuntu-minimal installed, the check fails if all mirrors are disabled
[15:34] if you have ubuntu-minimal installed, an ubuntu-minimal is around even with empty sources.list
[15:34] without it, there is none, and the cache lookup we do fails :D
[15:35] Like I said, this is very funny
[15:35] And the sources are restored in normal control flow but not if an exception happens
[15:35] We could also install a global exception handler that does rollback
[15:35] yeah tag away
[15:36] we definitely want a cleaner, more reliable rollback
[15:36] tagged
[15:37] #link http://reports.qa.ubuntu.com/reports/rls-mgr/rls-jj-incoming-bug-tasks.html#foundations-bugs&ia=web
[15:37] bug 2083529
[15:37] -ubottu:#ubuntu-meeting- Bug 2083529 in networkd-dispatcher (Ubuntu) "networkd-dispatcher: scripts not executed for renamed interfaces" [Undecided, Confirmed] https://launchpad.net/bugs/2083529
[15:37] Who wants to play with networkd?
[15:37] I know it's my package :|
[15:37] I guess me? If it's networkd
[15:38] I guess networkd-dispatcher reads the wrong field from networkd
[15:38] Not that I know what networkd-dispatcher is
[15:38] It's a python script that listens to networkd and dispatches hook scripts
[15:39] It's aaaaaargh
[15:39] Anyway I did tag this
[15:39] Hm okay, I will ask more questions later
[15:39] And that wraps up incoming bugs
[15:39] enr0n: you can pull me in on that if needed
[15:39] Well I guess we can talk about the dbus-broker MIR again
[15:40] slyon: ack thanks
[15:40] slyon: We should just move hook script running into netplan :D
[15:40] Any news about dbus-broker?
[15:40] :P
[15:40] I noticed that there's yet a new dbus broker in town now
[15:40] I remember hearing about it at all systems go
[15:41] busd
[15:41] bug 2015538 fwiw
[15:41] -ubottu:#ubuntu-meeting- Bug 2015538 in dbus-broker (Ubuntu) "[MIR] dbus-broker" [Undecided, Incomplete] https://launchpad.net/bugs/2015538
[15:41] didn't they want to promote varlink too
[15:41] you guys from the past! varlink is the future! ;)
[15:41] Different people doing different things
[15:42] *systemd* is all crazy about varlink
[15:42] Also the main APT author is all crazy about it
[15:42] I think for dbus-broker to be feasible, we still need upstream improvements in gdm (and other greeters?)
=== JanC is now known as Guest1081
[15:42] :D
[15:43] or gdm switching to varlink
[15:43] heh
[15:43] :D
[15:43] We write our own dbus broker
[15:43] It encapsulates dbus messages in varlink
[15:44] I'll watch.
[15:44] (Haven't we already seen the same story regarding REST vs GraphQL?)
[15:44] But alright, nothing new in dbus-broker land
[15:44] GraphQL is *amazing*
[15:44] Amazingly annoying
[15:44] juliank, dpus is has so many issues in the protocol. the implementation cannot fix that.
[15:44] #topic Team proposed-migration report
[15:44] We are going to skip this bit
[15:44] We don't have an archive to work on
[15:44] #topic AOB
[15:45] Anything else?
[15:45] Otherwise we stop at :46 :D
[15:45] 3cpio to rule the world!?
[15:45] yes yes
[15:46] To be fair I just want to ship prebuilt initrd cpio archives and combine those :D
[15:46] but I digress
[15:46] Final call!
[15:46] 3
[15:46] 2
[15:46] 1
[15:46] #endmeeting
[15:46] Meeting ended at 15:46:37 UTC. Minutes at https://ubottu.com/meetingology/logs/ubuntu-meeting/2024/ubuntu-meeting.2024-10-17-15.00.moin.txt
[15:46] you can use 3cpio during prebuilding initrds as well.
[15:46] Thanks everyone
[15:46] thanks juliank!

item.title: 15.10.2024: ubuntu-security, ubuntu-meeting
item.description:
# UBUNTU-SECURITY

=== darosior9 is now known as darosior

# UBUNTU-MEETING

[14:29] uff, really busy in calls
[14:29] can anyone lead the MIR meeting today instead of me or should I double-act to the extend possible?
[14:31] ok, trying ...
[14:32] do we have enough people to bother?
[14:32] let us see
[14:32] #startmeeting Weekly Main Inclusion Requests status
[14:32] Meeting started at 14:32:39 UTC. The chair is cpaelzer. Information about MeetBot at https://wiki.ubuntu.com/meetingology
[14:32] Available commands: action, commands, idea, info, link, nick
[14:32] Ping for MIR meeting - didrocks joalif slyon sarnold cpaelzer jamespage ( eslerm dviererbe )
[14:32] sarnold: and me are around
[14:32] o/
[14:33] please chime in now to see if we have a reasonable consensus
[14:35] ok, three then
[14:35] let us assume we check the queues but not expect much decisions
[14:35] #topic current component mismatches
[14:35] Mission: Identify required actions and spread the load among the teams
[14:35] #link https://people.canonical.com/~ubuntu-archive/component-mismatches-proposed.svg
[14:35] #link https://people.canonical.com/~ubuntu-archive/component-mismatches.svg
[14:35] ooo fancy
[14:37] kernel in there for realtime which they usually handle themselve
[14:38] we have no representative of them here
[14:38] let me raise it in the kernel channel to be sure
[14:38] there's scores of supported kernels, i'm surprised this doesn't come up more often
[14:41] I assume this is due to realtime formerly being a thing of its own
[14:41] but now all in the kernel, so they likely changed from a binary to a meta package or such
[14:41] and that could be new, and thereby start in universe
[14:41] #topic New MIRs
[14:41] I think it's brand new :)
[14:41] Mission: ensure to assign all incoming reviews for fast processing
[14:41] #link https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/?field.searchtext=&orderby=-date_last_updated&field.status%3Alist=NEW&field.status%3Alist=CONFIRMED&assignee_option=none&field.assignee=&field.subscriber=ubuntu-mir
[14:41] which matches my thougth
[14:41] empty queue here - good
[14:42] #topic Incomplete bugs / questions
[14:42] Mission: Identify required actions and spread the load among the teams
[14:42] #link https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/?field.searchtext=&orderby=-date_last_updated&field.status%3Alist=INCOMPLETE_WITH_RESPONSE&field.status%3Alist=INCOMPLETE_WITHOUT_RESPONSE&field.subscriber=ubuntu-mir
[14:44] https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/linuxptp/+bug/2071717 got some action but still waiting for more tasks to be completed
[14:44] -ubottu:#ubuntu-meeting- Launchpad bug 2071717 in linuxptp (Ubuntu) "[MIR] linuxptp" [Undecided, Incomplete]
[14:45] didrocks: commented on https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/lenovo-wwan-unlock/+bug/2058192
[14:45] -ubottu:#ubuntu-meeting- Launchpad bug 2058192 in OEM Priority Project "[MIR] lenovo-wwan-unlock" [Critical, Confirmed]
[14:45] seems not yet complete
[14:45] no action need to be taken now
[14:45] #topic Process/Documentation improvements
[14:45] Mission: Review pending process/documentation pull-requests or issues
[14:45] #link https://github.com/canonical/ubuntu-mir/pulls
[14:45] #link https://github.com/canonical/ubuntu-mir/issues
[14:46] no new entries
[14:46] last update was on https://github.com/canonical/ubuntu-mir/issues/69
[14:46] -ubottu:#ubuntu-meeting- Issue 69 in canonical/ubuntu-mir "Do we benefit from having the dev binary packages promoted?" [Open]
[14:46] where slyon gladly carried our discussion that -dev exclusion should still be a per-case thing
[14:46] no action either AFAICS
[14:46] #topic MIR related Security Review Queue
[14:46] Mission: Check on progress, do deadlines seem doable?
[14:46] Some clients can only work with one, some with the other escaping - the URLs point to the same place.
[14:46] #link https://bugs.launchpad.net/~ubuntu-security/+bugs?field.searchtext=%5BMIR%5D&assignee_option=choose&field.assignee=ubuntu-security&field.bug_reporter=&field.bug_commenter=&field.subscriber=ubuntu-mir
[14:46] #link https://bugs.launchpad.net/~ubuntu-security/+bugs?field.searchtext=[MIR]&assignee_option=choose&field.assignee=ubuntu-security&field.bug_reporter=&field.bug_commenter=&field.subscriber=ubuntu-mir
[14:47] Internal link
[14:47] - ensure your teams items are prioritized among each other as you'd expect
[14:47] - ensure community requests do not get stomped by teams calling for favors too much
[14:47] #link https://warthogs.atlassian.net/jira/software/c/projects/SEC/boards/594
[14:48] sarnold: should https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/openscap/+bug/1877696 get off of that list
[14:48] -ubottu:#ubuntu-meeting- Launchpad bug 1877696 in openscap (Ubuntu) "[MIR] openscap" [Undecided, Incomplete]
[14:48] it is from & to security
[14:48] and oval / openscap no more seems to be the future
[14:48] is it time to eliminate it from the board and reject the launchpad case?
[14:48] cpaelzer: heh, I think oval was given a last-second reprieve, I believe the US Navy something or other is taking it over
[14:48] oh is it
[14:48] I'm curious to learn about that - any link?
[14:49] no action for now
[14:49] excellent question :) I think ebarretto is the one to ask, he may know if it's got an announcement anywhere or not
[14:49] my request for a link is just me being curious
[14:49] Thanks ebarretto just reply here if you have anything to share in that regard
[14:50] it does feel weird to not have this package in main given that we use it :/
[14:51] jorge said he was going to ask the fraunhofer folks about his findings in the fdk-aac-free package, but given that the package is a derivative of a derivative I'm not sure if they'll care
[14:51] wow
[14:52] I'm uneasy about it.
[14:52] about it having no clear owner?
[14:52] on the one hand the feature (forwarding audio from remote hosts when doing gnome-remote-desktop things) seems like a very nice feature
[14:52] but on the other hand, it sure feels like there's zero responsible upstream
[14:52] and codecs .. miserable things.
[14:54] probably no progress on the other mirs :(
[14:54] yeah
[14:54] sorry, i got stuck reading into the case
[14:54] .. and unlikely to see any, for a few weeks
[14:54] but it is licensing - never a quick topic
[14:54] heh, that can happen :)
[14:54] you are right to go on
[14:54] #topic Any other business?
[14:54] nothing from me
[14:54] see you in the hague :)
[14:54] oh, actually, next week's meeting ..
[14:54] \o/
[14:55] i propose we cancel it
[14:56] yeah, there is no way to attend while at sprints
[14:57] I'll cancel the calendar invite ...
[14:57] o/
[14:57] * ebarretto reading
[14:57] do we still have time?
[14:57] I wanted to ask about the Sprint MIR sync
[14:58] it was a MIR sync + office-hours initial. I see its been downgraded to just a "sync" (MIR internal)
[14:58] was that intentional, cpaelzer ?
[14:58] Samir from the Foundations Toolchain squad asked me if we could have MIR office-hours at the sprint, specifically. And was happy to hear that we have something planned.
[14:59] slyon: yes it was intentional as it collided with a plenary while it was at full size
[14:59] ow
[14:59] is it near to the plenary at the start or the end of the day?
[14:59] If you sak me - we can welcome guests, but it will eat from the time we have for ourselves
[15:00] if start .. those things almost always run long
[15:00] no, there is a plenary after lunch
[15:00] which no one expected when planning things early on
[15:00] bonus :-)
[15:00] *middle* of the day? weird
[15:00] which made me shorten our invite
[15:00] slyon: tell samir to come by still
[15:00] okay. Let's see how it goes than. We can invite guests and otherwise I might run a team-local Foundations/MIR office hours session afterwards
[15:00] but let us not do global office hours, but request based - so we know what to expect
[15:01] ack
[15:01] closing ...
[15:01] #endmeeting
[15:01] Meeting ended at 15:01:16 UTC. Minutes at https://ubottu.com/meetingology/logs/ubuntu-meeting/2024/ubuntu-meeting.2024-10-15-14.32.moin.txt
[15:01] thanks cpaelzer, slyon, joalif, ebarretto :)
[15:01] cpaelzer: indeed, oval is not dead, the naval information warfare center (NIWC) is the new maintainer and we do have some updates coming to the oval language itself. For openscap itself and the MIR, at this point I think we might reconsider having a snap version of openscap, as it probably won't be backwards compatible. I will see if I talk to standards next week about what should be done
[15:01] thanks all! (and sorry for being late, I was double-booked)
[15:02] thanks cpaelzer all!
[15:02] thanks ebarretto

item.title: 14.10.2024: ubuntu-security, ubuntu-meeting
item.description:
# UBUNTU-SECURITY

=== Nokaji__ is now known as Nokaji
=== cpaelzer_ is now known as cpaelzer

# UBUNTU-MEETING

=== cpaelzer_ is now known as cpaelzer
[16:00] hello
[16:01] o/
[16:02] o/
[16:03] here but via phone so slow replies are to be expected
[16:06] utkarsh is apparently out for health reasons, and today is a US holiday.
[16:10] Maybe with three of us we can proceed anyway, and fall back to the ML for further votes?
[16:12] I'm rather against it, for a couple of reasons.
[16:13] 1/ the less people are at the meeting the less homogeneous our questions (and thus expectations) are.
[16:14] 2/ It's rather nerve-wracking as a candidate to have to wait for DMB folks to cast their votes (I was in that position for my MOTU application)
[16:14] However if teward feels we should proceed I'm OK bowing to the majority :)
[16:15] The alternative is to wait until next year, since AIUI there are no slots until then :-(
[16:15] I think I would be OK with the ML wait. If I look at the agenda postponing would push this to 2025. I would prefer to wait votes on a ML.
[16:15] (as long as the vote ends before 2025)
[16:15] we could have an impromptu DMB meet via IRC at the Summit but yeah I have no issue postponing
[16:16] but we CAN proceed
[16:16] i defer to you guys for the decisopn
[16:16] i'm good with either decision
[16:16] so we can proceed with 3 people here and ask questions then have ML votes if needed as well as other followups.
[16:17] (yes i know i'm playing both sides here xD)
[16:18] since we're tied i'll say lets have the initial Q/A here now
[16:19] then move the vote to ML
[16:19] * teward fetches more coffee
[16:20] Let's proceed. If the others on the ML want to ask their own questions or request to do that at a meeting, then that's OK, but often they don't. (FTR, I would, if the questions I would want to ask weren't asked already)
[16:22] * schopin grumbly acquiesces
[16:24] #startmeeting Developer Membership Board
[16:24] Meeting started at 16:24:24 UTC. The chair is rbasak. Information about MeetBot at https://wiki.ubuntu.com/meetingology
[16:24] Available commands: action, commands, idea, info, link, nick
[16:24] #topic Ubuntu Core Developer Applications
[16:24] #subtopic Agathe Porte
[16:24] gagath: welcome!
[16:25] o/
[16:29] gagath: have you done any transitions yet?
[16:30] rbasak: in debian, yes. in ubuntu, no.
[16:30] I'm finding it difficult to see the uploads that you've done that aren't kernel (since they're a different process) :-/
[16:30] https://launchpad.net/~gagath/+uploaded-packages
[16:31] I think all of them are on this page ^
[16:31] Just for context, you have been part of the kernel uploader team since last May, right?
[16:32] The plymouth upload FTBFS in https://launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/plymouth/23.360.11-0ubuntu1. What happened there?
[16:32] schopin: yes, this was https://wiki.ubuntu.com/gagath/KernelUploadRightsApplication
[16:34] The first SRU I looked at was bug 2069963 where the SRU verification didn't report the version tested.
[16:34] -ubottu:#ubuntu-meeting- Bug 2069963 in xkeyboard-config (Ubuntu Oracular) "Add Ergo-L layout" [Undecided, Fix Released] https://launchpad.net/bugs/2069963
[16:34] \o sorry, I took the day off and missed that we have the DMB meeting today
[16:34] rbasak: for the upload ftbfs, the issue was dh_install: warning: Cannot find (any matches for) "/usr/usr/lib/systemd/system" (tried in ., debian/tmp)
[16:35] And the next is bug 2073688, where you seem to have flipped the SRU tags with no explanation?
[16:35] -ubottu:#ubuntu-meeting- Bug 2073688 in kitty (Ubuntu Noble) "/usr/lib/kitty/kitty/options/definition.py:4116: SyntaxWarning: invalid escape sequence '\e' long_text='''" [Low, Fix Committed] https://launchpad.net/bugs/2073688
[16:35] gagath: FTBFS> OK, but what went wrong in the process that resulted in you getting sponsorship for an upload that FTBFS? Why wasn't that caught earlier?
[16:37] rbasak: I think the problem was that I and the mentor did not a proper build test of this. The mentor uploaded a 0ubuntu2 that fixed the issue after this was sponsored
[16:37] my mistake was that I did not use a chroot and tested with a wrong version of pkg-config
[16:38] that generated the double /usr
[16:38] for the mentor I guess their mistake could be the same
[16:39] for 2069963 I forgot to add the version tested in my SRU test message. I confirmed the version tested in a later comment on the bug.
[16:41] gagath: you mentioned that you haven't done transitions in Ubuntu yet, but have in Debian. Can you speak of the differences between Debian and Ubuntu on the handling of transitions?
[16:41] and for 2073688 I also forgot to explain what I did and with which version. I really need to focus on that. I performed the test according to the test plan but did not add some logs when changing the tags.
[16:42] We don't need logs as such FWIW. Just confirmation of what tests you performed and what version you tested, and the pass result.
[16:42] ack
[16:42] Because we have other people who have flipped tags without testing anything because they think the tags need flipping and that's it.
[16:43] I see what you are referring to.
[16:43] (and the tests performed need to match the agreed test plan of course)
[16:43] (IOW we believe what you say, but not if you don't say it :-)
[16:44] schopin: in Debian I uploaded my packages that depended on each other to unstable, and when everything was in place britney was able to publish them all at once to unstable
[16:45] for ubuntu, it would be the same mechanism but using -proposed if the transition is for a stable release
[16:46] Not for devel?
[16:47] for devel, you would push directly to the devel as there is no -proposed and -updates yet in place (like debian)
[16:47] mhm, wiat
[16:48] yes. like https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/mofed-modules-24.07/+bug/2080904
[16:48] -ubottu:#ubuntu-meeting- Launchpad bug 2080904 in mofed-modules-24.07 (Ubuntu) "autoconf not installed as dependency of mofed-modules-24.07" [Undecided, Fix Released]
[16:48] the upload was for oracular and the bug got closed directly without SRU involved.
[16:49] (when oracular was devel)
[16:49] gagath: where is the handing of proposed migration documented in Ubuntu, and where would you go to find a list of outstanding blockers for a given package's pending migration?
[16:50] https://github.com/canonical/ubuntu-maintainers-handbook/blob/main/ProposedMigration.md
[16:50] blockers can be found here: https://ubuntu-archive-team.ubuntu.com/proposed-migration/update_excuses.html
[16:51] there is a nicer page with a .fr domain name but I sometime struggle to find it and it is... unofficial
[16:51] gagath: fwiw, that page is about devel-proposed, which is very much a thing!
[16:51] oh
[16:52] a
[16:52] https://ubuntu-archive-team.ubuntu.com/proposed-migration/
[16:53] eg https://ubuntu-archive-team.ubuntu.com/proposed-migration/noble/update_excuses.html for noble
[16:53] We're running low on time.
[16:53] Is everyone ready to vote?
[16:54] I am.
[16:55] #vote Grant gagath core dev
[16:55] Please vote on: Grant gagath core dev
[16:55] Public votes can be registered by saying +1, -1 or +0 in channel (for private voting, private message me with 'vote +1|-1|+0 #channelname')
[16:55] -1
[16:55] -1 received from rbasak
[16:55] (reasons to follow)
[16:57] -1
[16:57] -1 received from bdrung
[16:57] -1 While I don't doubt gagath's packaging skills, I feel there is a lack of understanding surrounding the Ubuntu processes at large, and in particular on the lifecycle of a package during the development cycle.
[16:57] -1 While I don't doubt gagath's packaging skills, I feel there is a lack of understanding surrounding the Ubuntu processes at large, and in particular on the lifecycle of a package during the development cycle. received from schopin
[16:57] teward: vote?
[16:59] the reason for my vote is the same as what schopin wrote.
[16:59] gagath: fwiw, something that helped me a lot to familiar with devel was doing +1 shifts.
[16:59] schopin: I wanted to do that, but could not dedicate a full week since the kernel team is already understaffed.
[17:00] maybe I can ask again.
[17:00] #endvote
[17:00] Voting ended on: Grant gagath core dev
[17:00] Votes for: 0, Votes against: 3, Abstentions: 0
[17:00] Motion denied
[17:00] More information on my vote:
[17:00] Thank you for your contributions to Ubuntu! I especially value that you are a DD already.
[17:00] Unfortunately I think the Ubuntu-specific expectatiosn we have haven't really been demonstrated. These are important when you are uploading unsupervised, and in particular when others ask you to sponsor for them while under pressure.
[17:00] IMHO (other DMB members differ in opinion on this point), a straight to core dev application needs to be exceptionally strong, but so far, wherever I look, there's some issue. This might be made up by experience or an extensive track record, but I don't see that either in Ubuntu (excluding kernel uploads that have a completely separate process). I appreciate that you have extensive experience in
[17:00] Debian, but the challenge then is to ensure that you understand how Ubuntu differs in process, and know what Ubuntu-specific expectations we have. Unfortunately that cannot be demonstrated by your Debian experience.
[17:00] I have my personal expectations documented here: https://wiki.ubuntu.com/RobieBasak/DMB/CoreDev
[17:00] I don't think your application really demonstrates meeting my expectations. I'd like to see good examples across the various topics in the penultimate paragraph. I'd also like to see endorsements commensurate with that.
[17:00] Thank you for working towards core dev, and please do continue! I'd love to see you getting this soon.
[17:01] thanks for your time
[17:02] #topic Outstanding mailing list requests to assign
[17:02] cpete's application is still open for votes on the ML. Please vote! I need to do this too.
[17:03] #info cpete's application is still open for votes on the ML. Please vote!
[17:03] I don't see any other recent ML requests.
[17:03] #info No other recent ML requests.
[17:04] #topic Open TB bugs
[17:04] #info No open TB bugs
[17:04] #topic Select a chair for the next meeting
[17:04] Since there was no chair for this meeting I don't know where to start, so I'll start from after my slot
[17:04] That would be schopin, with tsimonq2 as backup.
[17:05] #info Next chair will be schopin with tsimonq2 as backup
[17:05] #topic AOB
[17:05] AOB?
[17:05] Do we have a script somewhere for the chair to follow?
[17:05] I didn't find it on the wiki.
[17:05] not that i am aware of
[17:07] Beware that I might not be able to make it on the 11th as it is a holiday and I'm out of town. My presence hinges on the punctuality of the train company...
[17:08] rbasak: E:InternetLost
[17:08] stupid airport wifi
[17:09] rbasak: my vote was -1 for the same reasons you stated
[17:09] ack, thanks
[17:09] we can echo that on the ML but that's -4 which is quorate
[17:09] schopin: just the agenda.
[17:09] Alright, fair enough.
[17:09] sorry about random disappearance btw can't do squat about airport wifi going bonkers
[17:09] #action rbasak to handle closing gagath's application
[17:09] ACTION: rbasak to handle closing gagath's application
[17:10] schopin: and you can see the commands by example. There aren't many!
[17:10] If there's no other AOB I'll end the meeting.
[17:10] rbasak: AOB is whether we're having a impromptu DMB meet during the Summit
[17:10] but i think you said that should be emaileid to devel-permissions
[17:10] at least if I read IRC backlogs right :)
[17:10] Someone did and I agree
[17:11] FTR, IMHO it's fine as long as it's quorate, reasonably public and inclusive.
[17:14] #endmeeting
[17:14] Meeting ended at 17:14:17 UTC. Minutes at https://ubottu.com/meetingology/logs/ubuntu-meeting/2024/ubuntu-meeting.2024-10-14-16.24.moin.txt
[17:14] A DMB meeting during the summit would be fine from my side as well
[17:16] thanks rbasak for chairing the meeting!
[17:17] * schopin is off.
[17:20] rbasak: we could hold it as an impromptu session I'm sure we can find a place to hold it with transparency :P
[17:20] * teward goes to fetch lunch
=== pushkarnk1 is now known as pushkarnk
[21:12] gagath: had you announced your application to devel-permissions@? That's required in the instructions at https://wiki.ubuntu.com/DeveloperMembershipBoard/Agenda, and it's difficult for me to reply to the thread when there isn't one :-/

item.title: 11.10.2024: ubuntu-security, ubuntu-meeting
item.description:
# UBUNTU-SECURITY

[01:31] I'm reading OVAL and have a question.
[01:31] When I look at the Ubuntu Security Notice web page, the Source Package is listed in the Update instructions.
[01:31] However, when I read the USN OVAL, there is no information about the Source Package Name, and the usns in the PKG OVAL lists packages that are not related to that package.
[01:31] How can I combine OVALs to reproduce the information on the Ubuntu Security Notice web page?
[07:33] mainek00n: do you have an example ?
[08:03] Hey, any new podcast today and Security updates? or taking a rest after the 24.10 release?
[08:25] Luna_UK: AlexM is on vacation this week and indeed we are all trying to slow down a bit after 24.10, but we will be back next week as usual
[08:30] ebarretto: alright, then i know amurray enjoy vacation and cya for next week then
[08:31] fighting with a 24.04.1 desktop install that crashes in gnome-boxes and cockpit atm
=== mdeslaur_ is now known as mdeslaur
=== Juesto is now known as Juest
[22:01] any idea when Firefox 131.0.2 (fixing the CVE-2024-9680 remote code execution 0-day) is coming to 20.04 focal? it's been like 3 days and every other distro is already patched
[22:01] -ubottu:#ubuntu-security- An attacker was able to achieve code execution in the content process by exploiting a use-after-free in Animation timelines. We have had reports of this vulnerability being exploited in the wild. This vulnerability affects Firefox < 131.0.2, Firefox ESR < 128.3.1, Firefox ESR < 115.16.1, Thunderbird < 131.0.1, Thunderbird < 128.3.1, and Thunderbird < 115.16.0.
[22:26] I've asked for an eta from the desktop team
