item.description:
# UBUNTU-SECURITY

=== crazybyte20 is now known as crazybyte2

# UBUNTU-MEETING

=== pushkarnk1 is now known as pushkarnk
[14:29] o/
[14:30] o/
[14:30] o/
[14:32] let me get this started
[14:32] #startmeeting Weekly Main Inclusion Requests status
[14:32] Meeting started at 14:32:54 UTC. The chair is cpaelzer. Information about MeetBot at https://wiki.ubuntu.com/meetingology
[14:32] Available commands: action, commands, idea, info, link, nick
[14:32] Ping for MIR meeting - didrocks joalif slyon sarnold cpaelzer jamespage ( eslerm dviererbe )
[14:33] last week we expected this one might be quick (so late in the cycle) and we use the time to discuss the blob case in wwan unlock
[14:33] let us see if the assumption holds true
[14:33] #topic current component mismatches
[14:33] Mission: Identify required actions and spread the load among the teams
[14:33] #link https://people.canonical.com/~ubuntu-archive/component-mismatches-proposed.svg
[14:33] #link https://people.canonical.com/~ubuntu-archive/component-mismatches.svg
[14:33] yep, easy as intended
[14:33] good morning
[14:34] #topic New MIRs
[14:34] Mission: ensure to assign all incoming reviews for fast processing
[14:34] #link https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/?field.searchtext=&orderby=-date_last_updated&field.status%3Alist=NEW&field.status%3Alist=CONFIRMED&assignee_option=none&field.assignee=&field.subscriber=ubuntu-mir
[14:34] none
[14:34] #topic Incomplete bugs / questions
[14:34] Mission: Identify required actions and spread the load among the teams
[14:34] #link https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/?field.searchtext=&orderby=-date_last_updated&field.status%3Alist=INCOMPLETE_WITH_RESPONSE&field.status%3Alist=INCOMPLETE_WITHOUT_RESPONSE&field.subscriber=ubuntu-mir
[14:35] nothing super new, and the expected https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/lenovo-wwan-unlock/+bug/2058192 we will try to talk about later
[14:35] -ubottu:#ubuntu-meeting- Launchpad bug 2058192 in OEM Priority Project "[MIR] lenovo-wwan-unlock" [Critical, Confirmed]
[14:35] #topic Process/Documentation improvements
[14:35] Mission: Review pending process/documentation pull-requests or issues
[14:35] #link https://github.com/canonical/ubuntu-mir/pulls
[14:35] #link https://github.com/canonical/ubuntu-mir/issues
[14:35] I worked on https://github.com/canonical/ubuntu-mir/pull/66 today, which should be ready for merging now
[14:35] -ubottu:#ubuntu-meeting- Pull 66 in canonical/ubuntu-mir "Import Rust vendoring document" [Open]
[14:35] rust is old and on slyon who provided https://github.com/canonical/ubuntu-mir/pull/66
[14:36] yeah - the same :-)
[14:36] I only had a glance, but enough others - especially the rust folks said yes
[14:36] so I'm happy to merge if no one wants to stop me
[14:37] I'm now recommending the approach used in s390-tools, using a .orig-rust-vendor.tar.xz tarball for vendored crates
[14:37] providing an example for automation via debian/rules
[14:37] only if upstream is providing that?
[14:37] unrelated to upstream.
[14:37] or also otherwise us creating it in a DFSG repackage kind of step?
[14:38] yes
[14:38] ok with me
[14:38] is mostly us creating it, because upstream/debian doesn't rely too much on vendoring
[14:38] Since you had a closer look slyon, did anyone bring up that the ecosystem is maybe more mature and we should change to no-vendoring or at least reduced-vendoring?
[14:39] No news on this, yet.
[14:39] thanks
[14:39] I'll try to catch a few Toolchain people at the next sprint (again) to discuss this topic
[14:39] ok, I've read through and will merge - we can further improve from here but this is (much) better than what we have - hence a merge is ok
[14:39] given the way versions of crates get locked together, I'd be surprised if that goal is closer than it was before
[14:40] sarnold: me too, but it is worth rechecking such assumptions of the past
[14:40] o/
[14:40] hi doko
[14:40] heya doko
[14:40] merged and thereby bug closed
[14:40] #topic MIR related Security Review Queue
[14:40] thx!
[14:40] Mission: Check on progress, do deadlines seem doable?
[14:40] Some clients can only work with one, some with the other escaping - the URLs point to the same place.
[14:41] #link https://bugs.launchpad.net/~ubuntu-security/+bugs?field.searchtext=%5BMIR%5D&assignee_option=choose&field.assignee=ubuntu-security&field.bug_reporter=&field.bug_commenter=&field.subscriber=ubuntu-mir
[14:41] #link https://bugs.launchpad.net/~ubuntu-security/+bugs?field.searchtext=[MIR]&assignee_option=choose&field.assignee=ubuntu-security&field.bug_reporter=&field.bug_commenter=&field.subscriber=ubuntu-mir
[14:41] Internal link
[14:41] - ensure your teams items are prioritized among each other as you'd expect
[14:41] - ensure community requests do not get stomped by teams calling for favors too much
[14:41] #link https://warthogs.atlassian.net/jira/software/c/projects/SEC/boards/594
[14:41] I don't believe anything currently in flight or yet to start will have any progress this week
[14:42] sarnold: do you happen to know if any still-in-progress are needed for oracular which is extra-soon ?
[14:42] the mad dash to finish roadmap items has consumed everything in its path
[14:42] I can't speak to the consequences for our colleagues for these few stragglers :(
[14:43] If in doubt, those responsibilities (like these MIR reviews) need to be "in the roadmap" to avoid them getting blown out by such a rush
[14:43] Maybe an improvement in planning time allocation to suggest?
[14:43] But nothing to debate now and here
[14:43] #topic Any other business?
[14:44] lenovo wwan thingy
[14:44] I wanted to propose a in-person meeting during the engineering sprint, like some "MIR office hours", with the first half of the meeting with just the MIR team members, followed by the second half where everybody can join and have questions/suggestions. Would that be ok with you?
[14:45] +1 for a in-person MIR meeting at the sprint
[14:46] yes, good idea
[14:46] doko: it was always worthwhile to do, but the calendar keeps filling up ...
[14:46] let me have a look
[14:46] I assume you have scheduling powers, so just find a slot ...
[14:46] I have all power :-)
[14:50] found and sent
[14:51] Monday after lunch
[14:51] ok, not much time
[14:51] let me set the stage
[14:51] ta
[14:51] https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/lenovo-wwan-unlock/+bug/2058192
[14:51] -ubottu:#ubuntu-meeting- Launchpad bug 2058192 in OEM Priority Project "[MIR] lenovo-wwan-unlock" [Critical, Confirmed]
[14:51] The question there is mostly "uncertainty"
[14:51] we rarely have something that wants to go to restricted in the first place
[14:51] so none of us has a lot of "that is how we usually do" feeling
[14:52] Furthermore I've heard many including myself get more and more troubled with such blob cases (had similar with keys) like "How would later one check on an SRU if the change is good/bad/fake"
[14:52] We are asking us the same questions but for introducing it
[14:53] I think restricted exists for just that, the neccessity of reality sometimes forcing us to things like that :-/
[14:53] But still I understand that we all feel not to ok with it
[14:54] But I think we need to look at the pure process, what of the requests in https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/lenovo-wwan-unlock/+bug/2058192/comments/5 are done or still open
[14:54] -ubottu:#ubuntu-meeting- Launchpad bug 2058192 in OEM Priority Project "[MIR] lenovo-wwan-unlock" [Critical, Confirmed]
[14:54] sarnold: can you explain what exactly this is about https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/lenovo-wwan-unlock/+bug/2058192/comments/8 ?
[14:55] to have it follow https://github.com/canonical/ubuntu-mir/blob/main/exceptions/OEM.md ?
[14:56] cpaelzer: we were mostly interested in trying to keep these blobs off unrelated computers
[14:56] ok, discussion moved on - it shall be in the normal archive (comments ~13-end
[14:56] cpaelzer: very few ubuntu users have the oem archives configured in their apt sources
[14:56] lenovo-fccunlock is still shipping a /usr/lib/libmodemauth.so without corresponding .symbols file..
[14:56] cpaelzer: so our thought was putting it in the oem archive might do a better job of restricting it to only people who would benefit
[14:56] I guess that is what didrocks mention in his first required TODO
[14:57] thanks sarnold, but the discussion evovled to ask to target the archive and in there restricted again - right?
[14:57] slyon: I agree - to me it seems this is mostly about checking the needs raised in https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/lenovo-wwan-unlock/+bug/2058192/comments/5 if they are now complete or now
[14:57] -ubottu:#ubuntu-meeting- Launchpad bug 2058192 in OEM Priority Project "[MIR] lenovo-wwan-unlock" [Critical, Confirmed]
[14:58] doing that we will know more clearly what is still open
[14:58] and then there is security
[14:58] ACK. IMO some of them got addressed, but not all
[14:58] Review was held back when it was considered to go to OEM, but since it is back a review is again needed
[14:58] but then, what do you review in a blob?
[14:58] maybe it'd be best for didrocks to take a 2nd look. reconsidering if his requests were resolved?
[14:58] ack slyon, maybe we could ask didrocks to do the official check of his asks what is done and what isn't?
[14:58] we don't review the blob... that's why we put it into "restricted".
[14:59] didrocks: ? (I know you are budy, but please pick that up later if you can)
[14:59] yeah, but in that case is it just "no security review" or would you still do one for where you can sarnold?
[14:59] cpaelzer: yes, the conversation did move, when they were worried that the smaller user base would mean too many users who need it can't get it
[14:59] still we can make sure the packaging is clean, potentially has tests and proper confinement
[14:59] slyon: double +1
[15:00] confinement might be even more important here, considering this is a blob
[15:00] agreeing a lot
[15:00] but ok for the scope of this meeting, back for a check by didrocks what was fulfilled and then back to security to do what "can be done"
[15:00] is that ok as an outcome for now
[15:02] time is up, I consider silence a weak ok for now
[15:02] thanks for having that discussion to get myself and many others to the same level
[15:02] this is not nice, btw: https://git.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/lenovo-wwan-unlock/tree/debian/lenovo-fccunlock.service "User=root" and executing a random binarry blob..
[15:03] I'm not surprised that the driver requires privileges to change something as fundamental as allowed radio frequency ranges
[15:03] indeed sarnold, but that just asks for e.g. apparmor
[15:04] it can have root, but should be limited to do just what and where it is supposed to
[15:04] *nod* I wish it had asked for systemd's seccomp filter lists, too
[15:04] * didrocks is backâ¦logging
[15:04] when introducing the "encourage isolation" rules that the level of enforcement depends on the case
[15:04] sarnold: ack
[15:04] this is a case which is indicating rather strong enforcement to make those required
[15:05] other cases can be weaker and that is fine, but here it is important and we seem to agree on that
[15:05] let me try to conclude the meeting then, as some are already distracted
[15:05] thank you for the discussion
[15:05] makes sense to me. Iâll have a second look at it and see where we stand. I still think even if the blob is binary that we should get the packaging to a certain level
[15:05] thanks didrocks
[15:05] thanks!
[15:05] yes, packaging at minimal level and isolation kind of mandatory in this case
[15:06] #endmeeting
[15:06] Meeting ended at 15:06:03 UTC. Minutes at https://ubottu.com/meetingology/logs/ubuntu-meeting/2024/ubuntu-meeting.2024-10-08-14.32.moin.txt
[15:06] thanks cpaelzer, all :)
[15:06] thanks!
=== utkarsh79 is now known as utkarsh2102
[19:00] * vorlon waves
[19:00] o/
[19:02] Oh, I'm down to chair.
[19:03] Are we going ahead with just the two of us?
[19:05] I wouldn't normally consider that quorate
[19:06] and I guess it's going to mostly be carrying over action items
[19:06] so punt to the next one?
[19:08] OK
[19:15] hey, sorry I overlooked the day/time and didn't see the notification...

[19:59] *starts getting set up for the Ubuntu Membership board meeting*
[19:59] howdy folks :) Ive turned up for my membership interview, not sure how this works but let me know what i need to do when the time is right
[19:59] hi local_optimum
[19:59] Hi local_optimum
[19:59] local_optimum, thanks, we're just getting ready, and we'll get going shortly
[20:00] no worries
[20:01] can the membership board members raise your hands to get a count of active participants before I fire the starting gun
[20:01] Here
[20:01] o/
[20:01] o/
[20:01] here
[20:02] Bashing-om: wake up
[20:02] oops sorry
[20:02] *giggles*
[20:02] Kilos: I am trying to keep up :P
[20:03] hehe
[20:03] I think that's enough for Quorum so we can get going... gimme a second to fire the command
[20:03] #startmeeting Ubuntu Membership Board
[20:03] Meeting started at 20:03:27 UTC. The chair is lucyllewy-. Information about MeetBot at https://wiki.ubuntu.com/meetingology
[20:03] Available commands: action, commands, idea, info, link, nick
[20:03] #chair lucyllewy-
[20:03] Current chairs: lucyllewy-
[20:03] Hello and welcome to the Ubuntu Membership Review Board meeting for 3rd October 2024. The wiki page for the Review Boards is available here: https://wiki.ubuntu.com/Membership/Boards
[20:03] We will attempt to get through all the applicants that have added themselves to that list, or posted a thread to the Ubuntu Discourse, before today's meeting. If we are unable to make it through the complete list due to time constraints, then at the next meeting we will pick up where we left off.
[20:03] The format for the meeting is as follows: We will go through the list of applicants one by one, by date of application (FIFO).
[20:03] Each applicant should introduce themselves (1-5 sentences) and provide links to their Ubuntu Wiki page or Ubuntu Discourse thread. After the introduction, the members of the Membership Review Board will review the pages and, if needed, ask the applicant further questions.
[20:03] During this time, it is encouraged for other members of the community to show their support for the applicant. Do not be alarmed if the members of the Membership Review Board are quiet during this time; they are reading wiki/launchpad/forum/other pages and deciding how they are going to vote.
[20:03] When the board is ready to vote, they will publicly vote in the channel with either +1, 0, or -1 (for membership, abstain, and against membership, respectively). If most of the voting board members vote +1, then the applicant is now an official Ubuntu member! (Feel free congratulate them!)
[20:03] Now, with any further ado, let's get started with the first applicant...
[20:04] First up (only applicant today) is Oliver Smith ( local_optimum ). Hi, Oliver, can you introduce yourself to the board members and share the links to your application post and your launchpad profile
[20:06] Fantastic, thank you very much, it's great to be here finally. It was recently my third anniversary of working on Ubuntu at Canonical and I felt it was well overdue to apply after all this time. I've been an Ubuntu user for a while and joined Canonical because it felt like part of my core values to ensure that a private open source operating system should be able to compete in the mainstream space.
[20:07] I joined as the Product Manager for Ubuntu Desktop, working closely with the engineering teams, expanded my remit to cover Ubuntu Server as well and have since taken over as interim engineering director of the Desktop team. I feel this is a nice endorsement of my engagement with the developers and community to be able to contribute in this way.
[20:07] My membership application is here: https://discourse.ubuntu.com/t/oliver-smith-membership-application/48277
[20:08] launchpad is here: https://launchpad.net/~local-optimum
[20:08] happy to dive into detail on any of these items :) hopefully i am not an unfamiliar face
[20:09] awesome. thank you. While the board members review your application and come up with any questions they want to ask I will make sure the question on the Code of Conduct is asked for formalities...
[20:09] You have signed the Code of Conduct. Do you affirm that you have read and understood the whole document, and do you agree to be bound by the terms for the duration of your membership should it be granted?
[20:09] I have signed it (prior to starting my role in the first place) and agree to be bound by it :)
[20:09] coolbeans.
[20:10] Board members, ask any questions you might have, and let me know when you're ready to vote.
[20:10] I think I am good to go with the information already provided and the glowing testimonials
[20:11] Me too, excellent testimonials and work done
[20:12] indeed, today's application looks very well done, full of endorsements as well (those have been getting rare in recent timesâ¦)
[20:13] local_optimum: In the event that Canonical employment is terminated, what is your vision to continue contributing to Ubuntu ?
[20:15] A good question, Ubuntu is a core part of my life and that's not going to change in terms of the ways I use it as a platform for most of my personal projects, I enjoy writing up the work I do and sharing it on my blog as I think there are lack of approachable guides that bring a lot of the different use-cases together. I would certainly hope to continue to be involved in community discussions, I can't
[20:15] imagine losing touch with the relationships I've built over the last few years. And to be honest I'd probably be able to contribute more code/snaps/applications to the ecosystem as it would certainly free-up some time. I have some v poorly maintained snaps I'd love to go back to.
[20:16] that's a good answer <3
[20:16] well said
[20:16] +1
[20:16] anyone else have any more questions or are we ready to vote?
[20:17] hear hear indeed. I'm good :)
[20:17] none here ty
[20:17] ready
[20:17] ready 2
[20:17] #vote Oliver Smith's Ubuntu Membership application
[20:17] Please vote on: Oliver Smith's Ubuntu Membership application
[20:18] Public votes can be registered by saying +1, -1 or +0 in channel (for private voting, private message me with 'vote +1|-1|+0 #channelname')
[20:18] #voters lucyllewy- Wild_Man mapreri Kilos Bashing-om
[20:18] Current voters: Bashing-om, Kilos, Wild_Man, lucyllewy-, mapreri
[20:18] +1
[20:18] +1 received from Kilos
[20:18] +1
[20:18] +1 received from Bashing-om
[20:18] +1
[20:18] +1 received from Wild_Man
[20:18] +1 aye!
[20:18] +1 aye! received from mapreri
[20:18] +1 Very thorough application, I love the glowing testimonials, and you are clearly committed to the community. I wholeheartedly give my +1
[20:18] +1 Very thorough application, I love the glowing testimonials, and you are clearly committed to the community. I wholeheartedly give my +1 received from lucyllewy-
[20:18] #endvote
[20:18] Voting ended on: Oliver Smith's Ubuntu Membership application
[20:18] Votes for: 5, Votes against: 0, Abstentions: 0
[20:19] Motion carried
[20:19] Congratulations Oliver!
[20:19] just gimme a second to post some info for you
[20:19] Congrats local_optimumkeep up the good work . I am happy to have you on board
[20:19] Awesome, thanks very much all :) it genuinely is a real personal achievement to become a member and means a lot.
[20:19] Congratulations local_optimum
[20:19] local_optimum: \o/ - congrats!
[20:19] Congratulations to all the new members. Don't forget to check the perks at https://wiki.ubuntu.com/Membership#The_Perks and once you've been added to the members group remember to apply for your certificate at https://forms.canonical.com/certificate/ (1/2)
[20:19] Your @ubuntu.com email address will go live within 48 hours. Do NOT set it as your primary launchpad.net email address because that will cause emails to loop forever and you'll never receive them! (2/2)
[20:20] With that I can end the meeting... Thank you for coming everyone <3 I look forward to seeing those of you who are coming to the Ubuntu Summit in three weeks
[20:20] See you there!
[20:20] local_optimum: now do remember the promised beers in 3 weeks! :P
[20:21] all bribes to be paid in full ;)
[20:21] thanks for chairing lucyllewy-
[20:21] #endmeeting
[20:21] Meeting ended at 20:21:11 UTC. Minutes at https://ubottu.com/meetingology/logs/ubuntu-meeting/2024/ubuntu-meeting.2024-10-03-20.03.moin.txt
[20:21] thank you all for coming!
[20:22] so great to see the ubuntu spirit flying high
[20:22] Take care folks!
[20:22] you too ty

item.title: 01.10.2024: ubuntu-security, ubuntu-meeting
item.description:
# UBUNTU-SECURITY

# UBUNTU-MEETING

[14:31] o/
[14:31] o/
[14:31] just a sec
[14:32] good morning
[14:32] o/
[14:32] #startmeeting Weekly Main Inclusion Requests status
[14:32] Meeting started at 14:32:41 UTC. The chair is cpaelzer_. Information about MeetBot at https://wiki.ubuntu.com/meetingology
[14:32] Available commands: action, commands, idea, info, link, nick
[14:32] Ping for MIR meeting - didrocks joalif slyon sarnold cpaelzer jamespage ( eslerm dviererbe )
[14:33] o/
[14:33] almost everyone said hi while I was still fetchign the commands
[14:33] so let us go on
[14:33] #topic current component mismatches
[14:33] Mission: Identify required actions and spread the load among the teams
[14:33] #link https://people.canonical.com/~ubuntu-archive/component-mismatches-proposed.svg
[14:33] #link https://people.canonical.com/~ubuntu-archive/component-mismatches.svg
[14:33] nothing entirely new
[14:33] which is good given the time in the cycle
[14:33] going on ...
[14:34] #topic New MIRs
[14:34] Mission: ensure to assign all incoming reviews for fast processing
[14:34] #link https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/?field.searchtext=&orderby=-date_last_updated&field.status%3Alist=NEW&field.status%3Alist=CONFIRMED&assignee_option=none&field.assignee=&field.subscriber=ubuntu-mir
[14:34] a few things unblocked and looked for a reviewer
[14:34] https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/highway/+bug/2070807
[14:34] -ubottu:#ubuntu-meeting- Launchpad bug 2070807 in highway (Ubuntu) "[MIR] highway" [Undecided, New]
[14:34] https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/rpds-py/+bug/2072621
[14:34] -ubottu:#ubuntu-meeting- Launchpad bug 2072621 in rpds-py (Ubuntu) "[MIR] rpds-py" [Undecided, New]
[14:34] https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/linuxptp/+bug/2071717
[14:34] -ubottu:#ubuntu-meeting- Launchpad bug 2071717 in linuxptp (Ubuntu) "[MIR] linuxptp" [Undecided, New]
[14:34] actually
[14:34] at least for the last I know this has gone back to new
[14:34] due to security review being done
[14:34] so let us look into what exactly those cases need
[14:35] 2071717 has security ack now
[14:35] but I have not yet seen any response to my 2 mandatory and 5 recommended tasks
[14:35] so I'd assign that to the reporter and mark incomplete
[14:38] https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/rpds-py/+bug/2072621
[14:38] -ubottu:#ubuntu-meeting- Launchpad bug 2072621 in rpds-py (Ubuntu) "[MIR] rpds-py" [Undecided, New]
[14:38] ack by Slyon, with conditions
[14:38] security ack
[14:38] https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/rpds-py/+bug/2072621/comments/7
[14:38] says
[14:38] 've implemented the required changes and added a bug subscriber as requested.
[14:39] and exactly as james already said
[14:39] slyon: would you like todo the honours from the MIR team perspective and add your final approval now that we've had a security review please!
[14:39] that is the way we usually do (let the one having the request to judge)
[14:39] I assigned it to slyon to represent that as he is not around today
[14:40] jamespage: if that is ASAP Oracular - we might need to pick someone else to do that, let us know in that case
[14:40] last
[14:40] https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/highway/+bug/2070807
[14:40] -ubottu:#ubuntu-meeting- Launchpad bug 2070807 in highway (Ubuntu) "[MIR] highway" [Undecided, New]
[14:40] Desktop won't be promoting jpeg-xl/highway until 25.04 cycle
[14:41] thank you
[14:41] I'd assign to you until all is in place then?
[14:41] ok
[14:42] #topic Incomplete bugs / questions
[14:42] Mission: Identify required actions and spread the load among the teams
[14:42] #link https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/?field.searchtext=&orderby=-date_last_updated&field.status%3Alist=INCOMPLETE_WITH_RESPONSE&field.status%3Alist=INCOMPLETE_WITHOUT_RESPONSE&field.subscriber=ubuntu-mir
[14:44] cpaelzer_: I'd like to get that in for oracular if poss - just needs someone other than me to ack the MIR :)
[14:44] https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/lenovo-wwan-unlock/+bug/2058192
[14:44] -ubottu:#ubuntu-meeting- Launchpad bug 2058192 in OEM Priority Project "[MIR] lenovo-wwan-unlock" [Critical, Confirmed]
[14:45] lenovo-wwan-unlock is a weird one, we don't move packages to restricted often, I'm not sure what precedents we've got to compare against
[14:46] me neither
[14:46] but the recent updates there are between slyon and them and I'd keep it with him for context awareness
[14:46] jamespage: I've seen you , I'll have a look tomorrow
[14:46] the security team really can't do much with it because it's a big binary blob, except for hoping that it's what the users would actually want. and a distro package putting things into /opt is weird, dunno about that.
[14:47] architecture-properties is an ongoing discussion and was here last weeks meeting
[14:47] but if that's how that hardware manufacturer has chosen to make things work, and there's no foss way to make it work, maybe it's not the end of the world to put it into restricted.
[14:47] I've been part of some discusison, nothing to re-act today on architecture-properties
[14:48] yes sarnold, definetly not the normal foss pockets
[14:48] is there any way to at least know if they are valid
[14:48] heh, as in, *test* it and see that it does what it says it does?
[14:48] a blob where you at least know who it is from is a bit less evil than random-blob
=== JanC_ is now known as JanC
[14:49] no more like at least a strong chain of trust that allows e.g. the SRU team on an update to know this is not the next xz-utils but "official"
[14:49] it lives on https://github.com/lenovo/lenovo-wwan-unlock -- how much do we trust that that's actually lenovo folks?
[14:49] yep, questions like this is what I mean
[14:50] but there are enough things open on the case that we neither can't nor should final decide right now
[14:50] for progress I'd go on, ...
[14:50] #topic Process/Documentation improvements
[14:50] Mission: Review pending process/documentation pull-requests or issues
[14:50] #link https://github.com/canonical/ubuntu-mir/pulls
[14:50] #link https://github.com/canonical/ubuntu-mir/issues
[14:51] I've participated in discussions about https://github.com/canonical/ubuntu-mir/issues/69
[14:51] -ubottu:#ubuntu-meeting- Issue 69 in canonical/ubuntu-mir "Do we benefit from having the dev binary packages promoted?" [Open]
[14:51] the rest is even older
[14:51] nothing new to act
[14:51] #topic MIR related Security Review Queue
[14:51] Mission: Check on progress, do deadlines seem doable?
[14:51] Some clients can only work with one, some with the other escaping - the URLs point to the same place.
[14:51] #link https://bugs.launchpad.net/~ubuntu-security/+bugs?field.searchtext=%5BMIR%5D&assignee_option=choose&field.assignee=ubuntu-security&field.bug_reporter=&field.bug_commenter=&field.subscriber=ubuntu-mir
[14:51] #link https://bugs.launchpad.net/~ubuntu-security/+bugs?field.searchtext=[MIR]&assignee_option=choose&field.assignee=ubuntu-security&field.bug_reporter=&field.bug_commenter=&field.subscriber=ubuntu-mir
[14:51] Internal link
[14:51] - ensure your teams items are prioritized among each other as you'd expect
[14:51] - ensure community requests do not get stomped by teams calling for favors too much
[14:51] #link https://warthogs.atlassian.net/jira/software/c/projects/SEC/boards/594
[14:51] I've seen things land, so thank you sarnold and friends
[14:52] sarnold: linuxptp was done but stays in TODO ?
[14:52] probably just an oversight
[14:53] np
=== cpaelzer_ is now known as cpaelzer
[14:53] is the rest looking reasonable to you sarnold?
[14:53] yes, the rest of it looks about like what I'd expect
[14:55] great
[14:55] #topic Any other business?
[14:55] Would you be interested in migrating the existing MIR documentation to the newer Canonical ReadTheDocs style?
[14:55] See for example, the SRU documentation (currently also gets migrated): https://canonical-sru-docs.readthedocs-hosted.com/en/latest/
[14:55] nothing from me (too busy to remember)
[14:56] I'd like to kick lenovo-wwan-unlock closer to its resolution if we can
[14:56] dviererbe: I was indirectly part of the SRU migration and would like that to be the same in general
[14:56] dviererbe: there is a problem i see though
[14:56] dviererbe: this all comes with diataxis which is nice for huge things to split by structure
[14:57] dviererbe: but this will end up being a doc page looking very lonely with 2x howto (the templates) and 1x reference (the rest)
[14:57] dviererbe: thereby I feel this isn't a good candidate
[14:57] dviererbe: happy to be convinced, not against it just not seeing the worth in this case
[14:57] dviererbe: unsure. what we've got now fits our needs nicely and I don't see a huge benefit to moving, beyond making it easier to find if that's a thing with read the docs, but it doeswn't feel like that is
[14:57] dviererbe: I'd feel more like all (SRU + MIR + AA doce + ...) to converge on one "archive operations" or so
[14:58] dviererbe: is that just an idea of yours or are you driving such with others?
[14:58] diataxising these sounds like a lot of pain for negative gain
[14:58] It's just an idea from me
[14:58] in this case yes, pain no gain
[14:58] I see your concers with diataxis
[14:58] ok, so for now the two people speaking up say "maybe better not"
[14:59] my proposal would be the mentioned level up of SRU into archive-operations docs
[14:59] there it will then fit together
[14:59] my intention was to bring more consistency into our documentation
[14:59] a good goal :)
[14:59] ack
[14:59] but not at making it worse
[14:59] we could write 4x more content, then it would not look awkward
[14:59] but what would that be?
[15:00] here is the thing
[15:00] can we make it stay single-page but render in the same style?
[15:00] that would work for this case
[15:00] dviererbe: if you do not happen to know I can ask Sally, but you might already know
[15:00] I think the idea of a combined SRU/MIR/AA doc is interesting
[15:01] single page is probably okay for the TA's, but they are instructed to enforce diataxis, so they probably will say no
[15:01] I'll chase that down dviererbe
[15:01] ack
[15:01] sarnold: you wanted to talk about https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/lenovo-wwan-unlock/+bug/2058192
[15:01] -ubottu:#ubuntu-meeting- Launchpad bug 2058192 in OEM Priority Project "[MIR] lenovo-wwan-unlock" [Critical, Confirmed]
[15:01] do we have time for that?
[15:02] dunno :/
[15:02] but a nudge even towards resolutions feels like it'd be nice
[15:03] that is too much for me to handle right now
[15:03] ack
[15:03] should we try to use next meeting for just that to ahve a better chance at progress?
[15:04] ah sorry, I really would want to get this closer - but I fel unable right now and so might others who have likely dropped off since we are after time :-/
[15:04] closing with a sad face instead of nice numbers
[15:04] #endmeeting
[15:04] aww
[15:04] Thank you everyone!
[15:04] thanks cpaelzer, dviererbe, all :)
[15:05] #endmeeting
[15:05] Meeting ended at 15:05:16 UTC. Minutes at https://ubottu.com/meetingology/logs/ubuntu-meeting/2024/ubuntu-meeting.2024-10-01-14.32.moin.txt

item.title: 30.09.2024: ubuntu-security, ubuntu-meeting
item.description:
# UBUNTU-SECURITY

[13:23] -R requiring a file seems to be documented
=== Juesto is now known as Juest
=== Juesto is now known as Juest
=== Juesto is now known as Juest

# UBUNTU-MEETING

=== dviererbe1 is now known as dviererbe
[19:00] \o
[19:00] o/
[19:00] o/
[19:00] o/
[19:06] Who's chairing?
[19:07] the agenda says utkarsh2102
[19:09] #startmeeting Developer Membership Board
[19:09] Meeting started at 19:09:00 UTC. The chair is rbasak. Information about MeetBot at https://wiki.ubuntu.com/meetingology
[19:09] Available commands: action, commands, idea, info, link, nick
[19:09] #topic Review of previous action items
[19:09] teward follow up to get all application process wiki/docs to explain the process to be able to edit wiki pages, for applicants who don't yet have wiki edit access (carried over)
[19:09] teward isn't here so we'll carry over
[19:09] #action teward to follow up to get all application process wiki/docs to explain the process to be able to edit wiki pages, for applicants who don't yet have wiki edit access (carried over)
[19:09] ACTION: teward to follow up to get all application process wiki/docs to explain the process to be able to edit wiki pages, for applicants who don't yet have wiki edit access (carried over)
[19:09] rbasak to start a ML thread to find consensus on whether to allow PPU applications for "core" packages (done)
[19:10] This is done and is awaiting input from others
[19:10] #topic SRU Developer Applications
[19:10] #subtopic SRU Developer application by Matthew Ruffell at DMB meeting 2024-09-30 (due to APAC NZST timezone).
[19:10] mruffell: o/
[19:10] hello everyone
[19:10] rbasak: bug me when we get to AOB
[19:11] (my availability is only as long as my Verizon connection doesn't dip out, looks like they're having cellular issues and i'm travelling today)
[19:12] Questions for mruffell?
[19:12] rbasak: link to their appliclation since wiki and agenda are slow as sin today?
[19:12] application*
[19:12] https://wiki.ubuntu.com/mruffell/SRUDeveloperApplication
[19:12] Thanks
[19:12] #link https://wiki.ubuntu.com/mruffell/SRUDeveloperApplication
[19:15] * teward staring at the application wondering what APAC is, and then realizes he's just undercaffeinated and that this is representation for the Asia/Pacific region
[19:18] mruffell: do you have / remember any recent examples of turning someone else's contribution into an SRU ready to upload? This isn't a hard requirement but would be nice to see if you do.
[19:19] Meanwhile, bug 2059197 is a nice example of dealing with a regression - thank you!
[19:19] -ubottu:#ubuntu-meeting- Bug 2059197 in nfs-utils (Ubuntu Focal) "mount.nfs: Fix minor version parsing when '-t nfs4' and '-o vers=4.x' are used together" [Medium, Fix Released] https://launchpad.net/bugs/2059197
[19:20] I believe I have tidied up someones patches for SRU, but it is at most once or twice.... I'm trying to figure out what one it was...
[19:20] but I normally delete superseeded patches from the LP bug to tidy it up to not confuse my sponsors, so finding them is hard
[19:20] OK don't worry
[19:21] and yeah, I do try my best to talk to community users and correct any regressions as fast as possible
[19:21] We don't get many SRU developer applications. I don't have a set of standard questions ready to ask!
[19:22] to avoid needing to clean-up the bug report, you could name the patches $name_v1.patch, $name_v2.patch and so on. then it's clear what is the latest one.
[19:22] From your application and endorsements I agree with ddstreet that you have been ready for a while, and you're well past the line in terms of volume and quality of work.
[19:22] but sometimes v1 is fine for focal, but jammy gets superseeded with a security upload, so jammy has a v2... but then they ask, where's focal v2?
[19:23] So I just try keep everything in lockstep to not be confusing
[19:23] I can't see anything in your recent SRU history that I might want to expand upon by asking questions, so I think I have no questions to ask.
[19:23] Does anyone else have questions or should we move on to vote?
[19:23] it's hard to come up with questions since your work would answer a lot of them (like regression handling, etc)
[19:24] I'm not sure a vote can be quorate today but we can make some progress towards that at least.
[19:24] mruffell: not really for your application, but I'd appreciate feedback on the new docs and how you've found them!
[19:24] I have read them! https://canonical-sru-docs.readthedocs-hosted.com/en/latest/
[19:24] If there are no objections I'll start voting now then.
[19:25] #vote Grant mruffell SRU Developer membership
[19:25] Please vote on: Grant mruffell SRU Developer membership
[19:25] Public votes can be registered by saying +1, -1 or +0 in channel (for private voting, private message me with 'vote +1|-1|+0 #channelname')
[19:25] +1 comments as above. Thank you for your excellent work!
[19:25] +1 comments as above. Thank you for your excellent work! received from rbasak
[19:25] +1
[19:25] +1 received from bdrung
[19:25] +1
[19:25] +1 received from teward
[19:26] bdmurray: around?
[19:26] (since I saw you enquiring earlier)
[19:26] Anyone else?
[19:27] #endvote
[19:27] Voting ended on: Grant mruffell SRU Developer membership
[19:27] Votes for: 3, Votes against: 0, Abstentions: 0
[19:27] Motion carried
[19:27] Sorry we need at least another vote
[19:27] I'll ask on the ML
[19:27] great, thanks
[19:28] Please also schedule another meeting date, in case we need it to chase for a final vote. There are reduced quorum rules for a second meeting if it becomes necessary
[19:28] rbasak, one comment on https://canonical-sru-docs.readthedocs-hosted.com/en/latest/ - it would be nice to have a one-page version of it (to make searching in it easier)
[19:29] bdrung: is https://canonical-sru-docs.readthedocs-hosted.com/_/downloads/en/latest/pdf/ enough?
[19:30] that'll do it as well
[19:30] #topic Ubuntu Core Developer Applications
[19:30] #subtopic Ubuntu Core Developer application by Chris Peterson at DMB meeting 2024-11-25 (I will also join the 2024-09-30 meeting in case there is extra time, pending confirmation if this is ok.)
[19:30] Hey there o/
[19:30] cpete: we can see how far we get in the next half hour
[19:31] cpete: but as above a vote today won't be quorate, so you may have to reschedule anyway. Do you want to continue regardless?
[19:31] Yeah let's do it please
[19:32] #link https://wiki.ubuntu.com/cpete/CoreDev
[19:33] Questions for cpete?
[19:34] I suppose I'll introduce myself too. Hi, name is Chris Peterson and I work for Canonical on the Foundations team. I primarily work on Subiquity and other installer related areas. Although as part of my Founations responsibilities I may work in other areas as well.
[19:34] (also, hi!!!)
[19:35] Sorry I was preoccupied reading your application. I hadn't realised there was a second one until just earlier. Hello :)
[19:38] cpete: OK I'll start then I guess. If you were considering uploading a new upstream version of a package today, for Oracular, what would you need to check before upload?
[19:40] There are various freezes to be aware of, such as featurefreeze, betafreeze etc. For Oracular, you can find the effective dates here: https://discourse.ubuntu.com/t/oracular-oriole-release-schedule/36460
[19:41] cpete: did you get my question?
[19:41] Currently, we are past FeatureFreeze so I wouldn't be considering a new upstream release unless it only contained critical bug fixes necessary for the final release.
[19:41] OK. How does feature freeze apply if the new upstream version is a "microrelease" (eg. 1.2.3 -> 1.2.4)?
[19:41] sorry, my client disconnected
[19:42] utkarsh2102 no sorry
[19:42] q: what if you have package version 1.2.3 in ALL the current stable releases and the current DEVEL release. you're exactly where you are in the cycle as of today. you have notified of a grave bug and you have a patch ready. what versions will you upload and what should you take care before uploading?
[19:42] tell me the versions and the precautions for ALL the stable releases and the devel release
[19:42] answer once you've answered the current question
[19:43] rbasak: version strings aren't the most reliable way to tell what's changed. It's a good indicator, but you'd have to look at the real source changes to be sure if it's a bug fix or not.
[19:43] cpete: OK, thanks.
[19:44] rbasak: is it possible for you to paste the scrollback for today's meeting, please?
[19:44] https://irclogs.ubuntu.com/2024/09/30/%23ubuntu-meeting.html will take time to sync
[19:45] utkarsh2102: https://pastebin.ubuntu.com/p/7pttVVttM5/
[19:47] thank you!
[19:47] cpete: ??
[19:47] utkarsh2102: The new version would be 1.2.3-0ubuntu1. I would be first uploading to devel, and I would need to then prepare SRUs for applying the patch to previous versions. SRU version strings can be hard, I'd need a second to double check the guidance on that. I imagine in this case 1.2.3-0ubuntu1 would be fine, but all of my SRUs have already had the version numbers handy :)
[19:48] utkarsh2102: taking "grave" to mean critical but maybe not a security bug
[19:48] yes, a regular bug
[19:49] cpete: will you directly upload to devel? no precautions?
[19:49] cpete: so 1.2.3-0ubuntu1 will work for what all releases, please name them?
[19:50] utkarsh2102: ah certainly not. I would first build and test the new version locally and make sure autopkgtests pass. (I have done this so far with the majority of my uploads with PPA builds to demonstrate this to my sponsors)
[19:53] utkarsh2102: Well it will certainly work for devel. The SRU version string is important that's greater than any version in any of that releases pockets e.g. jammy jammy-updates, jammy-security. Since you say that's the version in all releases that should be fine as well. But we'd have to check each release
[19:54] jammy-release jammy-updats jammy-security
[19:55] cpete: I had added "you're exactly where you are in the cycle as of today." - which applies to devel. what do you think you should do more, if anything?
[19:55] cpete: 1.2.3 is the highest version in noble, jammy, focal
[19:55] i don't think you really have to go through each pocket of the release to check :)
[19:56] We're nearly out of time
[19:56] Ah well I would probably contact a release team member and make them aware of the bug.
[19:56] cpete: "The SRU version string is important that's greater than any version in any of that releases pockets" why?
[19:57] rbasak: I can vote on mruffell's application now and make it quorate, right?
[19:57] utkarsh2102: yes
[19:57] (if you vote +1)
[19:57] A -1 wouldn't be quorate
[19:57] ok, +1 for mruffell!!!
[19:57] Congrats mruffell :)
[19:57] yay!
[19:57] Thanks! I'm very happy
[19:57] congrats!
[19:58] I had further questions too, so I think we'll need to postpone. Sorry cpete
[19:58] I can finally retry autopkgtests now without bothering m-f-o or h-a-l-v-e-s =p
[19:58] utkarsh2102: so they get the new version of the package when updating it
[19:58] rbasak: no worries, thanks for the time everyone
[19:58] right, so what about f -> j upgrades?
[19:58] If anybody would like to continue, feel free and I'll check the logs later
[19:58] and j - n ?
[19:58] I think that might be utkarsh2102 volunteering :)
[19:58] #chair utkarsh2102
[19:59] Current chairs: rbasak, utkarsh2102
[19:59] rbasak: i don't think we should half half applications
[19:59] that is so sub-optimal
[19:59] #chair bdrung
[19:59] utkarsh2102: fair. Do you want to continue with this line of questions then?
[19:59] also
[19:59] Current chairs: bdrung, rbasak, utkarsh2102
[19:59] rbasak: yes, I can. bdrung, are you around for a bit more?
[20:00] yes
[20:00] are you okay to continue then?
[20:00] yes
[20:00] perf!
[20:00] utkarsh2102: afterwards, please switch to an AOB topic and assign the two necessary actions for mruffell's application, to keep the automatic minutes straight
[20:00] o/
[20:00] congrats, mruffell! o/ (3-min delayed)
[20:00] rbasak: will do, thanks! o/
[20:01] cpete: waiting on you to answer my question currently
[20:01] *waves*
[20:01] * bdrung grabs some snacks to be able to continue
[20:01] i'm still here but my internet's fuzzy because Verizon is having some internet problems right now on cell service
[20:01] great, thanks teward
[20:01] #chair teward
[20:01] Current chairs: bdrung, rbasak, teward, utkarsh2102
[20:01] utkarsh2102: Ah right, we don't want users to upgrade and regress. This is why it's important to SRU to each release, and each version string is usually release specific
[20:02] *knows too much about meetingology*
[20:02] lmao
[20:02] cpete: okay, soooo?
[20:02] wdym by "upgrade and regress"?
[20:04] utkarsh2102: So if 1.2.3 is the highest version in each release, then 1.2.3-0ubuntu1 is probably fine for each version you would just need to SRU it back to each. By "upgrade and regress" we don't want users to upgrade to a newer version of ubuntu and reintroduce bugs. This is why we make sure to land patches in devel before SRUing them.
[20:04] got it
[20:05] cpete: have you done an SRU before?
[20:05] last question around this: when you update to 1.2.3-0ubuntu1 to focal, jammy, and noble. does this cause any problem?
[20:05] mruffell: I have done 3 yes. Here is one example for livecd-rootfs https://bugs.launchpad.net/subiquity/+bug/1974483
[20:05] -ubottu:#ubuntu-meeting- Launchpad bug 1974483 in subiquity "autoinstall ssh:install-server:false is misleading in 22.04" [High, Fix Released]
[20:07] utkarsh2102: I'm not sure I understand the question
[20:08] cpete: per your last answer above - you said "1.2.3-0ubuntu1 is probably fine for each version [...]"
[20:08] so when you've done that
[20:09] and let's say focal, jammy, noble is at "1.2.3-0ubuntu1" - does everything work fine? and can we call the bug closed? or is there something we should still do? or?
[20:11] utkarsh2102: we could only close the bug after SRU verification. It will then phase from -proposed to -updates and as long as no errors are reported it will fully phase and we could call it done. If that's what you're getting at.
[20:12] ok, i'll move on, thank you :)
[20:12] cpete: I was trying to get at the upgrade story from focal -> jammy; jammy -> noble.
[20:13] cpete: q: what happens when you upload a package to the devel release. where does it go? is there any other step you need to take care as an uploader?
[20:15] utkarsh2102: It will land in -proposed and await migration until the package's and its rev-dpes autopkgtests pass. The uploader is responsible for seeing the package migrate into -release. This is setting aside times from freezes, say beta freeze, where the upload may require additional approval in the queue before landing into -proposed.
[20:16] mruffell: hey, btw, i've added you to the right ACL and announced your application already!!! o/
[20:16] cpete: thanks, what if all autopkgtests pass and yet the package doesn't migrate?
[20:16] utkarsh2102: thanks, I got the ACL email and the announcement =)
[20:17] cpete, Imagine a user detects a bug in droopy in jammy and provides a patch. You want to sponsor the fix. What would you upload (version numbers and releases)?
[20:18] utkarsh2102: there may be other reasons for the package not migrating. update_excuses output is helpful here
[20:18] cpete: suppose there's nothing in update_excuses, all autopkgtests pass, yet the package doesn't migrate
[20:18] what next?
[20:21] utkarsh2102: hmmm reasons for this scenario don't immediately come to mind. (is there a block-proposed tag for devel series?) I would probably head over to ubuntu-devel or ubuntu-release and ask
[20:21] no tags, that'd show up in update_excuses
[20:22] utkarsh2102: and if it were waiting for another package to migrate it would show up there too. So I don't know here
[20:22] got it, thanks o/
[20:23] i was trying to get at uninstallability issues :)
[20:23] Ah, I feeel like I usually see those in autopkgtest before they dissapear from update_excuses
[20:24] update_output tells you about them! :)
[20:24] update_output.txt
[20:24] cpete: i'll let you answer bdrung's question next
[20:24] Ahh. Another useful tool of the ubuntu archive toolbox
[20:24] cpete, Imagine a user detects a bug in droopy in jammy and provides a patch. You want to sponsor the fix. What would you upload (version numbers and releases) in case you are a core-dev?
[20:27] bdrung: sorry for the delay. Looking at droopy. I see that for Jammy, Noble, and Oracular are all the same version. I would first upload their patch to oracular-devel as 0.20160830-5ubuntu1
[20:27] good and then?
[20:29] Considering all is well and they have SRU templates for Noble and Jammy, I would upload 0.20160830-5ubuntu1 to Jammy and Noble. Although my intuition is telling me to make it ...-5ubuntu1.0, but again I need to look up the versioning string guidance.
[20:30] uh, what?
[20:30] cpete, could you upload 0.20160830-5ubuntu1 to jammy and noble or what would happen?
[20:30] -5ubuntu1.0 to SRU and -5ubuntu1 to devel is already contradicting what you said earlier
[20:32] bdrung: thinking. utkarsh2102: that was more of an incomplete thought thinking about the right versioning scheme, not to say that would be right process there
[20:32] cpete, what constraints do the version numbers need to follow?
[20:33] bdrung: The version number in noble-updates needs to be higher than the version in noble-release.
[20:34] since there's no -security upload there
[20:34] cpete, are there more contraints for the noble upload?
[20:36] I suppose it would need to be less than the version in oracular.
[20:36] yes
[20:37] ok, I am serverely over time, it's 2 AM here and I'll need to conclude soon
[20:37] bdrung: are you ready to vote?
[20:37] teward: ^?
[20:37] i have no questions, ready to vote
[20:38] perf
[20:38] okay, ready
[20:38] perf
[20:38] #ubuntu-devel Chris to get core-dev rights
[20:38] ooof
[20:38] libera
[20:39] #vote Chris to get core-dev rights
[20:39] Please vote on: Chris to get core-dev rights
[20:39] Public votes can be registered by saying +1, -1 or +0 in channel (for private voting, private message me with 'vote +1|-1|+0 #channelname')
[20:39] #voters bdrung teward utkarsh2102 rbasak bdmurray tsimonq2 schopin
[20:39] Warning: 'schopin' not in channel
[20:39] Current voters: bdmurray, bdrung, rbasak, schopin, teward, tsimonq2, utkarsh2102
[20:39] ok, go
[20:42] +1 the application is still on the thin side and some more areas to dive in (like versioning of SRUs) but I have worked with cpete and are confident that he will follow his statement "I certainly still expect to ask for review and thoroughly test changes before committing something I'm not 100% certain about."
[20:42] +1 the application is still on the thin side and some more areas to dive in (like versioning of SRUs) but I have worked with cpete and are confident that he will follow his statement "I certainly still expect to ask for review and thoroughly test changes before committing something I'm not 100% certain about." received from bdrung
[20:43] -1; apologies, I think Chris is great & I really appreciate his work and whilst he's got strong endorsements, they didn't answer the last three questions quite correctly. versioning is quite an important subject and I think that is where I go from +1 to -1. :(
[20:43] -1; apologies, I think Chris is great & I really appreciate his work and whilst he's got strong endorsements, they didn't answer the last three questions quite correctly. versioning is quite an important subject and I think that is where I go from +1 to -1. :( received from utkarsh2102
[20:45] teward: ?
[20:45] sorry my connection is slow
[20:46] -1 I believe that you have more to learn and prove knowledge of before we can give you core dev levels of access. Versioning is critical in Ubuntu and not understanding that in and of itself is a necessary skill that you don't currently have, therefore I must provide a -1 vote.
[20:46] -1 I believe that you have more to learn and prove knowledge of before we can give you core dev levels of access. Versioning is critical in Ubuntu and not understanding that in and of itself is a necessary skill that you don't currently have, therefore I must provide a -1 vote. received from teward
[20:47] #endvote
[20:47] Voting ended on: Chris to get core-dev rights
[20:47] Votes for: 1, Votes against: 2, Abstentions: 0
[20:47] Motion denied
[20:48] i'll carry it to the ML
[20:48] Ack. Thanks for your time all. I'll brush up so I can give better answers for the next go around.
[20:48] cpete: apologies we can't complete the voting yet.
[20:49] cpete: whilst you have a phenomenal set of people (foundations!!!) to help you through, please feel free to reach out if you need help at any point!
[20:50] utkarsh2102: I certainly will! Thanks :)
[20:50] cpete: i hope you get your rights sooner but one quick thing I'd like to see is cross-team interaction. All your endorsers are Foundations
[20:50] regarding quorum: Vote is between -5 and 3, outcome unknown as quorum was not reached
[20:50] I'd like to see you get more involved with others
[20:51] +1 on more cross-team interactions
[20:51] bdrung: oh wait, even if it's 3, it's still quorum not reached, right?
[20:52] that's a.....denied?
[20:52] we're 7, quorum is 4
[20:53] utkarsh2102, we are currently at -1, but the votes of the other can move it to -5 (denied) or 3 (accepted)
[20:53] but that's what I am saying
[20:53] 3 is not accepted
[20:53] 4 is accepted, isn't it?
[20:53] or have I gotten it wrong? I should sleep soon, oof
[20:53] anyway, I'll take it to the ML and conclude here for now
[20:53] #topic AOB
[20:54] utkarsh2102 already added mruffell to the right teams and announced the application
[20:54] #action utkarsh2102 to take cpete's application to ML
[20:54] ACTION: utkarsh2102 to take cpete's application to ML
[20:54] teward: AOB from your side?
[20:54] utkarsh2102, four +1 are enough because the remaining members can only decrease it to 1 (by voting 3x -1).
[20:55] the sum of the votes only need to be positive
[20:55] utkarsh2102: not enough connection strength to state it and get a reply too
[20:55] gotcha
[20:55] so i'll just send to the ML for that
[20:55] teward: okeydoke, yes, thank you!
[20:55] #endmeeting
[20:55] Meeting ended at 20:55:28 UTC. Minutes at https://ubottu.com/meetingology/logs/ubuntu-meeting/2024/ubuntu-meeting.2024-09-30-19.09.moin.txt
[20:55] and that's a wrap!
[20:55] thank you, everyone!
[20:55] apologies, cpete :(
[20:56] utkarsh2102: all good. Thanks for staying longer for me
[20:56] <3
[20:56] okay, gotta drop

item.title: 26.09.2024: ubuntu-security, ubuntu-meeting
item.description:
# UBUNTU-SECURITY

=== Juesto is now known as Juest
=== hwpplayer1 is now known as pinkychocolate
=== pinkychocolate is now known as hwpplayer1
[16:11] Hey, I have a question regarding vulnerabilities on ubuntu. For example, for https://ubuntu.com/security/CVE-2022-3597 the security advisory notes the "4.4.0-6ubuntu1" version as the fix version in Ubuntu lunar, and "4.4.0-4ubuntu3.1" as the fix version for Ubuntu kinetic. However, https://answers.launchpad.net/ubuntu/lunar/amd64/libtiff5-dev/4.4.0-4ubuntu3.1 lists that the
[16:11] -ubottu:#ubuntu-security- LibTIFF 4.4.0 has an out-of-bounds write in _TIFFmemcpy in libtiff/tif_unix.c:346 when called from extractImageSection, tools/tiffcrop.c:6826, allowing attackers to cause a denial-of-service via a crafted tiff file. For users that compile libtiff from sources, the fix is available with commit 236b7191.
[16:11] "4.4.0-4ubuntu3.1" version was released in Ubuntu lunar. Does that mean that for Ubuntu lunar the version "4.4.0-4ubuntu3.1" is vulnerable to the CVE, while for ubuntu kinetic the same version fixes the vulnerability?
[16:11] Also, more generalized - does it ever occur that the same source package version can be considered vulnerable on one distro version, but not the other? If so, can you provide any examples?
[16:16] the 4.4.0-4ubuntu3.1 package never made it's way out of lunar-proposed, so it was never actually in lunar before it got replaced https://launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/tiff/+publishinghistory?batch=75&memo=75&start=75
[16:16] laki: different distros build software with different build options and different patches, it's quite possible a vulnerability affets one distro but not another for the same version
[16:20] Thank you. So I should disregard the Proposed pocket, understood. I can ask the same thing regarding CVE-2023-4693. Here, it notes that for noble the 1.199 version is the fix version, while for mantic the version 1.197 is the fix version. However, from what I can tell, the version 1.197 was released in noble in the Release pocket. Does that mean that 1.197 is vulnerable on noble, but not
[16:20] -ubottu:#ubuntu-security- An out-of-bounds read flaw was found on grub2's NTFS filesystem driver. This issue may allow a physically present attacker to present a specially crafted NTFS file system image to read arbitrary memory locations. A successful attack allows sensitive data cached in memory or EFI variable values to be leaked, presenting a high Confidentiality risk.
[16:20] on mantic?
[16:21] I'm sorry for the barrage of questions, but I'm trying to understand how it all fits together. But yeah, it's what I assumed regarding build options, and different linked libraries which might make the vulnerability a non-issue. However, can one source package version contain different patches on different distro releases? I assumed not?
[16:27] Also, from the top off your head, do you perchance have an example of a vulnerability which was not applicable on one distro, but not the other, for the same version?
=== Juesto is now known as Juest
[18:43] somewhat hope i'm not the first to post this here - https://xcancel.com/evilsocket/status/1839361276813902240
[18:44] instead of 30 sept to distros@openwall and 6 oct public, he's going all out in 75 minutes with the announced 'CVSS 9.9 RCE in a lot of systems'
[18:53] Habbie: thanks, we are aware.
[18:53] good. i knew you were aware of things before this tweet, to be clear :)
[18:54] Yeah, to be explicit, we are aware of the CRD change.
[18:54] CR.. Disclosure? i don't know the acronym
[18:56] yeah, disclosure
[18:57] Or actually, Coordinated Release Date.
[18:58] ah right
[18:58] i filed a security issue with a project today, was going to tell distros about it tomorrow, but i'll wait one hour now to see if there's still any point in it :>
=== Juesto is now known as Juest
[20:00] can anyone comment on this? i head there will be full disclosure within 10 minutes? https://threadreaderapp.com/thread/1838169889330135132.html
[20:01] s/ head / hear /
[20:01] the writeup is on their website now
[20:01] thanks, got it
[20:07] publishing updates now
[20:08] so one wants to check for non-firewalled cups-browsed on 631/udp
[20:10] yes
[20:10] just systemctl disable --now it
[20:10] you don't need to discover printers today :)
[20:25] Don't feed stray printers!
[20:27] mdeslaur, what if they really need cat fuel
[21:54] https://www.evilsocket.net/2024/09/26/Attacking-UNIX-systems-via-CUPS-Part-I/
[21:54] usns are being published now
[21:58] just wanted to link to the actual disclosure mentioned earlier for those who didn't see it yet :)
[21:59] is there a reason why this is running all the time BTW?
[22:04] you mean the open port?
[22:04] the whole daemon?
[22:05] well, if you want to see network printers, it needs to listen to dns-sd messages
[22:05] sounds like this is something that (at least by default) should only be running on-demand while you have a printer dialog open or the like?
[22:05] the open port was for a legacy cups sharing service...these updates disable that
[22:06] yes, ideally the printer dialogs should use the new cups 2.x apis for doing it on demand instead of having a daemon create local printers, unfortunately all the different printer dialogs (gtk, qt, etc.) haven't implemented that yet (AFAIK)
[22:06] ugh
[22:06] browsed was supposed to be a stop-gap measure
[22:07] it seems like browsed can shut down automatically after a time-out
[22:15] would be nice if it could somehow be started "on-demand" & shut down after a time-out when it's no longer used/needed
[22:15] just to minimise exposure :)
[23:04] the auto-startup and shutdown is to only be active when avahi is active, but avahi is always running, so it wouldn't get us much
[23:05] the print dialogs in the various toolkits need to integrate proper cups browsing support so we stop creating local printers for no reason, that's the proper fix
[23:06] of course the browsers now also have their own print dialogs
[23:06] so I guess they need fixing too
[23:07] so.many.print.dialogs
[23:14] based on the comments in cups-browsed.conf it can shut down when there are no jobs or queues also
[23:16] mdeslaur: there are probably applications with custom ones too :)
[23:18] so you would have to make sure your printer is turned on before you turn on your computer? if you do the opposite it would shutdown and the printer would never get created?
[23:18] that's where the "launch when needed" comes into play :)
[23:18] ah, except how do you know when you need it?
[23:19] like, when you open a print dialog or the printer setup panel
[23:19] yeah, so if we do that, might as well just use the cups api to do that and bypass the browse daemon entirely
[23:20] I guess it might be simpler *shrug*
[23:20] well, sounds like triggering it at that point might be easier, but dunno
[23:20] at least as a temporary thing until it's fixed properly
[23:21] and/or to fix custom print dialogs :)
[23:23] maybe browsed shouldn't be running as root also...
[23:24] all of cups really

[15:26] -ubottu:#ubuntu-meeting- Launchpad bug 2046174 in update-notifier (Ubuntu) "update-notifier crashed with SIGSEGV in g_hash_table_lookup_node()" [Medium, Confirmed] https://launchpad.net/bugs/2046174
[15:26] believe this to be for desktop
[15:26] #link http://reports.qa.ubuntu.com/reports/rls-mgr/rls-nn-incoming-bug-tasks.html#foundations-bugs
[15:26] LP: #2046174
[15:27] http://launchpad.net/bugs/2046174
[15:27] -ubottu:#ubuntu-meeting- Launchpad bug 2046174 in update-notifier (Ubuntu) "update-notifier crashed with SIGSEGV in g_hash_table_lookup_node()" [Medium, Confirmed]
[15:27] LP: #2078579
[15:27] -ubottu:#ubuntu-meeting- Launchpad bug 2078579 in ubuntu-release-upgrader (Ubuntu) "Holding Back libpcap0.8t64:amd64 rather than change libibverbs1:amd64" [Undecided, Triaged] https://launchpad.net/bugs/2078579
[15:29] LP:#2078573
[15:29] -ubottu:#ubuntu-meeting- Launchpad bug 2078573 in initramfs-tools (Ubuntu) "I can no longer boot from my Thunderbolt disk" [Undecided, Confirmed] https://launchpad.net/bugs/2078573
[15:30] let's discuss the thunderbolt one
[15:32] tagging
[15:33] bdrung: please investigate ^
[15:34] LP: #2078579
[15:34] -ubottu:#ubuntu-meeting- Launchpad bug 2078579 in ubuntu-release-upgrader (Ubuntu) "Holding Back libpcap0.8t64:amd64 rather than change libibverbs1:amd64" [Undecided, Triaged] https://launchpad.net/bugs/2078579
[15:35] skipping
[15:36] mm,jj,ff are empty
[15:36] #topic Team proposed-migration report
[15:36] #link https://ubuntu-archive-team.ubuntu.com/proposed-migration/update_excuses_by_team.html#foundations-bugs
[15:37] why is lintian being merged post-FF
[15:38] and llvm-toolchain-19 just needs to finish building on riscv64
[15:38] cpete already has lintian, the post-FF question is a good one
[15:39] might be because it's in the FTBFS report?
[15:40] (this one: https://people.canonical.com/~ginggs/ftbfs-report/test-rebuild-20240912-oracular-oracular.html#foundations-bugs-team)
[15:40] well the merge didn't fix the build failure :).
[15:40] right there are two things here, the merge and the ftbfs report
[15:40] cpete had it from the ftbfs report
[15:41] slyon: please investigate livecd-rootfs proposed-migration even though only 2 days old
[15:42] I'm out next week...
[15:42] missing build on ppc64el without log, I beat you to the retry button
[15:42] slyon: we would want it migrated this week
[15:42] danilogondolfo: livecd-rootfs, thanks
[15:42] ack
[15:42] thanks!
[15:42] #topic AOB
[15:43] i'm on holiday next week
[15:44] I'm out tomorrow and all of next week, back for release week

[15:45] Meeting ended at 15:45:19 UTC. Minutes at https://ubottu.com/meetingology/logs/ubuntu-meeting/2024/ubuntu-meeting.2024-09-26-15.02.moin.txt
[15:46] livecd-rootfs/ppc64el passed the build :)
[15:49] the default-bootstraps test is also interesting though, claims python3-gdbm is not installable
