[19:00] o/
[19:00] o/
[19:05] * vorlon waves
[19:07] vorlon, according to the agenda it looks like you are on backup for chair, and since seb doesn't seem to be around, would you be happy to kick things off?
[19:09] yes, marshalling myself to do so, sorry
[19:10] want to stick another item on the agenda first, one sec :)
[19:10] #startmeeting
[19:10] Meeting started at 19:10:53 UTC. The chair is vorlon. Information about MeetBot at https://wiki.ubuntu.com/meetingology
[19:10] Available commands: action, commands, idea, info, link, nick
[19:11] #apologies
[19:11] seb128 and sil2100 absent; no apologies noted on the mailing list
[19:11] [topic] apologies
[19:11] #topic action review
[19:11] ACTION: rbasak to draft a proposal of the DMB-proposed inactivity expiration policy for TB ratification
[19:11] rbasak: ?
[19:11] Carry over please
[19:12] I've been focused on my other item
[19:12] [action] rbasak to draft a proposal of the DMB-proposed inactivity expiration policy for TB ratification
[19:12] ACTION: rbasak to draft a proposal of the DMB-proposed inactivity expiration policy for TB ratification
[19:12] This is done
[19:12] [action] rbasak to open wider discussion on third-party repo policy
[19:12] ACTION: rbasak to open wider discussion on third-party repo policy
[19:12] eh oops
[19:12] We have one item of beedback
[19:12] feeback
[19:12] #undo
[19:12] Removing item from minutes: ACTION
[19:12] ACTION: rbasak to open wider discussion on third-party repo policy
[19:12] I'll follow up on Discourse
[19:12] rbasak: you're saying this is the action that's done?
[19:12] [link] https://discourse.ubuntu.com/t/technical-board-feedback-requested-draft-policy-on-third-party-software-sources-included-by-ubuntu/46849
[19:12] Yes
[19:12] ok
[19:13] If there's no further feedback, I expect to ask the TB to ratify the draft soon
[19:13] my late-added agenda item is related to this, but we'll get to that :)
[19:13] ACTION: vorlon to look into scripting for packages in flavor-specific overlays
[19:13] carry over
[19:13] [action] vorlon to look into scripting for packages in flavor-specific overlays
[19:13] ACTION: vorlon to look into scripting for packages in flavor-specific overlays
[19:13] ACTION: seb128 to continue working with SRU, AA, Release, Backporters and Security teams to document their membership process and link to it from https://wiki.ubuntu.com/TechnicalBoard#Team_Delegations
[19:13] carry over
[19:13] [action] seb128 to continue working with SRU, AA, Release, Backporters and Security teams to document their membership process and link to it from https://wiki.ubuntu.com/TechnicalBoard#Team_Delegations
[19:13] ACTION: seb128 to continue working with SRU, AA, Release, Backporters and Security teams to document their membership process and link to it from https://wiki.ubuntu.com/TechnicalBoard#Team_Delegations
[19:13] ACTION: sil2100 to follow up on the Cinnamon 24.04 LTS Qualification re the number of contacts listed for the flavor
[19:13] carry over
[19:13] [action] sil2100 to follow up on the Cinnamon 24.04 LTS Qualification re the number of contacts listed for the flavor
[19:13] ACTION: sil2100 to follow up on the Cinnamon 24.04 LTS Qualification re the number of contacts listed for the flavor
[19:14] ACTION: vorlon to follow up on Ubuntu Mate lead contact by email
[19:14] I believe I got this done and there was a satisfactory resolution with answers from the Mate folks
[19:14] looks like that's all the actions from last time
[19:14] #topic seeded snaps policy, snap channels, and things moving fast?
[19:14] so, related to the draft policy :)
[19:16] it appears that Oliver, on behalf of the Ubuntu Desktop team, has been pushing hard to get some changes made to how snaps are seeded on the Ubuntu image; using snap tracks that would align to major upstream versions of the software included in a given Ubuntu release, as opposed to the policy we've had up to now which is effectively latest/stable/ubuntu-XX.YY
[19:16] That's part of the draft policy
[19:16] I can see the motivation for such a change, and it's mentioned in the draft policy
[19:17] Sorry I'll let you finish
[19:17] however, when I looked at draft policy, this seemed to be covered only in an appendix which was not part of what I recalled having been asked to review as part of the normative language to be adopted by the TB
[19:18] and things are going full speed ahead, with Oliver working with sil2100 to actually make changes to the snap channels used in the install media for 24.04.1
[19:18] (which was originally scheduled for this week and is now pushed out 2 weeks)
[19:18] so I wanted to flag this and see if it was my misunderstanding, that I hadn't spent appropriate time on the appendix, or if others had a similar disconnect?
[19:19] I think there's possibly a misunderstanding here.
[19:19] Let me try describing my perspective.
[19:19] Principle 1 of the draft policy (in the main text, not an appendix) requires stability of behaviour.
[19:20] As written, that rules out things like firefox following a "latest" snap track
[19:21] So therefore, setting aside exceptions for the moment, the implementation of Principle 1 in snaps *requires* the following of a snap track that isn't "latest", but instead some track that is mapped from an Ubuntu release.
[19:21] "latest" then is only used when the TB grants an exception, or a historical one is implied, such as for Firefox
[19:22] Therefore, I don't see a need for changing the main body of the text. The appendix describes how snaps implement the principles as well as how an exception to principle 1 is handled.
[19:22] understood
[19:22]
[19:22] How does that fit with your concern?
[19:24] FWIW, when I spoke to Oliver about this, his concern was the current _inability_ to use not-latest snap tracks in the current implementation.
[19:24] I personally think that latest/stable/ does not give a guarantee either direction and that it would not be against the intent of this policy to use it, especially given that the exists to be an escape hatch
[19:24] But what he wanted to achieve seemed exactly aligned with our draft.
[19:24] and I want to unblock this as an option for them
[19:24] I'm not sure if I think it should go in the normative text
[19:25] but there's 3 of us here which means provided amurray agrees that this plan is fine, I think we can move forward?
[19:25] I think it's OK, if the latest track is expected to be stable in behaviour and meeting Principle 1, to consider use of the latest track to be compliant with the draft policy.
[19:25] I just didn't want it to happen by accident in case my misunderstanding of the draft was shared
[19:26] didn't want it to happen by accident> define "it", please?
[19:27] so my understanding is that the desktop team is not using latest here but versioned tracks like '1' or '2' etc - but I also think the current policy doesn't preclude the use of latest - and nor should it - but I think this should very much be an exception, as I suspect it could be easy to accidentally abuse it
[19:27] rbasak: that we were changing the de facto policy for seeded snaps on the images, based on a bit of the draft that you had written and of course endorse but that I wasn't sure the rest of the TB had actually read
[19:27] (read and considered)
[19:27] Ah, OK
[19:28] amurray: today it's actually using latest, they want to move to versioned tracks effective 24.04.1
[19:28] I was under the impression that the TB were OK with the direction, so didn't see the need to ask for anything to be held pending ratification
[19:29] vorlon - yes, sorry I should have clarified - I meant the desktop team is planning to use versioned tracks - and by abuse it I mean that if a publisher uses latest they would potentially be more likely to ship new features / introduce regressions etc
[19:29] * vorlon nods
[19:29] but in this case the use of a branch along with latest should make this less of a risk
[19:29] ok then I think that's enough to move forward with, thanks
[19:30] Are there any changes you'd like to make to the draft on this point?
[19:30] it's likely that sil2100, having been the one moving forward with implementation, also agrees with this but I hadn't had a chance to talk to him about it yet :)
[19:30] rbasak: not at this time but I'm going to try to give it a look later today, thanks
[19:30] ack. Thanks!
[19:30] (no action for the meeting because if I don't get to it it doesn't need to become a meeting nag point)
[19:31] #agreed use of explicit tracks instead of 'latest' for seeded snaps, as described in Appendix A of https://discourse.ubuntu.com/t/technical-board-feedback-requested-draft-policy-on-third-party-software-sources-included-by-ubuntu/46849/1, is acceptable
[19:31] AGREED: use of explicit tracks instead of 'latest' for seeded snaps, as described in Appendix A of https://discourse.ubuntu.com/t/technical-board-feedback-requested-draft-policy-on-third-party-software-sources-included-by-ubuntu/46849/1, is acceptable
[19:31] #topic Scan the mailing list archive for anything we missed (standing item)
[19:31] thanks for raising this issue vorlon, I think it was good to clarify it :)
[19:32] https://lists.ubuntu.com/archives/technical-board/2024-August/ completely nonexistent
[19:32] so I guess we're in the clear here
[19:32] #topic Check up on community bugs and techboard bugs
[19:32] [link] https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu-community/+bugs?field.assignee=techboard
[19:32] 0
[19:32] [link] https://bugs.launchpad.net/techboard
[19:33] maybe the first of these, about the snap policy, should be moved to 'fix committed'? :)
[19:33] otherwise, nothing new, so moving on
[19:33] :)
[19:33] #topic Select a chair for the next meeting (next from https://launchpad.net/~techboard/+members)
[19:33] I don't mind. I'll mark it Fix Released when it gets ratified.
[19:34] looks like seb128 with sil2100 as backup
[19:36] #agreed seb128 as next chair with sil2100 as backup
[19:36] AGREED: seb128 as next chair with sil2100 as backup
[19:36] #topic AOB
[19:36] anything else?
[19:36] nothing from me
[19:36] Nothing from me.
[19:37] #endmeeting
[19:37] Meeting ended at 19:37:33 UTC. Minutes at https://ubottu.com/meetingology/logs/ubuntu-meeting/2024/ubuntu-meeting.2024-08-13-19.10.moin.txt
[19:37] rbasak, amurray: thanks!
[19:37] thanks for chairing vorlon

[15:18] -ubottu:#ubuntu-meeting- Bug 2062119 in libtracefs (Ubuntu) "autopkgtests fail on ppc64el" [Undecided, New] https://launchpad.net/bugs/2062119
[15:19] I guess we can take them all but also Adrien is out this month
[15:19] He tagged them back in April, I think we just never noticed until now?
[15:20] Well yes
[15:20] But I guess he could fix them in September too

[15:21] Anyway, I say add them to the backlog and let adrien follow up on them :)

[15:23] This sounds awkward but also not reproducible
[15:24] It does seem _somehow_ the password was deleted for the user
[15:25] I can consistently reproduce this
[15:25] is it through pam or passwd?
[15:26] OK; then I guess can take this for further investigation
[15:26] I guess we need to simply do a diff after the upgrade of a "broken vs after-passwd" and see what changed
[15:26] schopin: I think it's pam because it happens on graphical login, non-graphical, or attempting to use passwd to reset the password
[15:26] And see if shadow file changed between upgrade
[15:27] Sadly ugh this will fall on enr0n I guess
[15:27] or we do "pair reproducing"

[15:28] I don
[15:28] bug 2075969
[15:28] I don't necessarily have time to try on a bunch of flavors. Help appreciated there
[15:28] -ubottu:#ubuntu-meeting- Bug 2075969 in ubuntu-release-upgrader (Ubuntu) "kinetic/lunar releases unable to do-release-upgrade to jammy" [High, Triaged] https://launchpad.net/bugs/2075969
[15:29] This seems like a bunch of effort to get right vs requiring multiple upgrades on old-releases IMO
[15:29] this should say "to noble"
[15:30] We'd need to do like upgrade tests for full desktop installs too
[15:30] Our intent for years has been this upgrade path to work.
[15:30] i.e. from K to N
[15:31] or e.g.
[15:31] So we need to restore the files from interim releases, then merge in any changes needed from .jammy/.mantic
[15:31] And AFAIK there no issue with the interim releases between B and F
[15:32] We can fix this but that's for after the point release I'd say
[15:32] So I am going to tag it todo, this can be done next pulse
[15:33] #link http://reports.qa.ubuntu.com/reports/rls-mgr/rls-jj-incoming-bug-tasks.html#foundations-bugs
[15:33] empty

[15:35] it is with anderson123 now

[15:36] The JIRA still says Adrien
[15:36] *andersson123
[15:36] there is an MP from andersson123 linked to update-excuse bug
[15:36] I see
[15:36] Well I'll reassign the jira
[15:37] rust-defaults vs rustc is with dv
[15:37] * dviererbe
[15:38] glibc blocking linux-meta with schopin

[15:39] patches for the regression packages for golang-defaults/1.23 are on the way, no need to assign currently.

[15:41] initramfs-tools blocking iproute2: bdrung probably wants this, but I'd be happy to assign to paride too
[15:42] juliank, this should resolve itself. i just retrigged the tests against the fixed initramfs-tools/0.142ubuntu31
[15:42] ok
[15:42] ack, thanks bdrung
[15:42] nvme-cli ftbfs paride
[15:42] libxs-parse-keyword-perl remains with waveform
[15:43] adduser vs show remains with tobhe
[15:43] ack

[15:45] apt blocking systemd: juliank
[15:45] Weird apt test suite failures

[15:46] juliank: ack
[15:46] boost1.83
[15:47] I think doing a blanket assign there
[15:47] tobhe: on the shadow thing ping me if you need a hand, I sponsored the merge
[15:47] juliank: I can take boost
[15:47] ok, thx! The adduser fallout is pretty obvious
[15:48] boost1.83: schopin
[15:48] ok if you want too
[15:48] it seems badpkg
[15:48] xfsdump: liushuyu
[15:49] libheif: andersson123
[15:49] zlib: doko?
[15:50] I mean he uploaded it
[15:50] juliank: andersson123 already has pyopenssl
[15:50] cmake is with vpa1977
[15:50] ginggs: yes we sorted that out a while ago
[15:51] golang-defaults is in progress and zhsj doesn't want it assigned

[15:51] ginggs: ah I see

[Medium, Triaged] https://launchpad.net/bugs/2058648

[21:19] the CrowdStrike post mortem is interesting reading...
[21:25] does it say more than just "it's all deltas fault"?
[21:26] basically, their in-kernel interpreter that runs regex patterns over certain inputs had no input validation
[21:27] ah, that sounds entirely sane
[21:29] https://www.crowdstrike.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/08/Channel-File-291-Incident-Root-Cause-Analysis-08.06.2024.pdf
[21:32] well, at least they provided details, that's more than most other companies this size would have done.
[21:34] I wonder how many more bugs there are in that thing

item.title: 06.08.2024: ubuntu-security, ubuntu-meeting
item.description:
# UBUNTU-SECURITY

[00:14] amurray: Loved the analysis of Ubuntu update testing in the light of CrowdStrike. Do you happen to know if there's a written summary that covers the same ground?
[00:17] blahdeblah: thanks - the expected testing is documented in https://git.launchpad.net/qa-regression-testing/tree/README.testing
=== chris14_ is now known as chris14
=== pwlkaasmhtyyqkmg is now known as dsbvpzisvhldqcgr
=== dsbvpzisvhldqcgr is now known as georgiag
=== cpaelzer_ is now known as cpaelzer

# UBUNTU-MEETING

[14:30] o/
[14:30] hey o/
[14:32] good morning
[14:33] if no-one is around, let me host this one too
[14:33] #startmeeting Weekly Main Inclusion Requests status
[14:33] Meeting started at 14:33:44 UTC. The chair is didrocks. Information about MeetBot at https://wiki.ubuntu.com/meetingology
[14:33] Available commands: action, commands, idea, info, link, nick
[14:33] Ping for MIR meeting - didrocks joalif slyon sarnold cpaelzer jamespage ( eslerm dviererbe )
[14:33] #topic current component mismatches
[14:33] Mission: Identify required actions and spread the load among the teams
[14:33] #link https://people.canonical.com/~ubuntu-archive/component-mismatches-proposed.svg
[14:33] #link https://people.canonical.com/~ubuntu-archive/component-mismatches.svg
[14:34] o/
[14:34] soâ¦ it seems we have gtk4 -> with the i386 deps
[14:34] jbicha kindly pre-warned me about it
[14:34] and will reach to get the i386 binary being built
[14:35] the cpdb stuff was in main for mantic but dropped for noble in part because it wasn't needed but we do need it going forward
[14:35] jbicha: do you mind opening a MIR bug with that single statement? That would help tracking the re-promotion
[14:35] ok
[14:35] and will be linked into that diagram
[14:35] thanks!
[14:35] mutter -> libdisplay-info
[14:36] jbicha: not the first time we have that IIRC, but I donât remember the reasoning? ^
[14:36] could someone else take a look at libdisplay-info since I think slyon is still out. I'd like to get it cleared up to smooth landing mutter/gnome-shell 46
[14:36] I think the MIR was approved but needs someone to double check and set the status correctly (and/or promotion to main)
[14:36] bug 2071396
[14:36] -ubottu:#ubuntu-meeting- Bug 2071396 in libdisplay-info (Ubuntu) "[MIR] libdisplay-info" [Undecided, New] https://launchpad.net/bugs/2071396
[14:37] Iâll have a double check then
[14:37] for cpdb, the .svg is already linked to approved MIRs. Do you want a replacement minimal MIR instead?
[14:38] jbicha: oh nice, you are right, just add a comment to it?
[14:38] (an additional comment)
[14:38] (previous correction: land gnome-shell 47)
[14:38] the only one which is not tracked is autopkgtest -> retry
[14:39] I think slyon will be back soon, and it sounds foundation-related
[14:39] letâs park it there for now
[14:39] #topic New MIRs
[14:39] Mission: ensure to assign all incoming reviews for fast processing
[14:39] #link https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/?field.searchtext=&orderby=-date_last_updated&field.status%3Alist=NEW&field.status%3Alist=CONFIRMED&assignee_option=none&field.assignee=&field.subscriber=ubuntu-mir
[14:40] the page was soooooo empty that it took a while to load here :)
[14:40] "this can't be right..."
[14:40] #topic Incomplete bugs / questions
[14:40] Mission: Identify required actions and spread the load among the teams
[14:40] #link https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/?field.searchtext=&orderby=-date_last_updated&field.status%3Alist=INCOMPLETE_WITH_RESPONSE&field.status%3Alist=INCOMPLETE_WITHOUT_RESPONSE&field.subscriber=ubuntu-mir
[14:40] sarnold: my first reaction :)
[14:41] didrocks: mine too :)
[14:41] especially with FF comingâ¦
[14:41] ok, it seems nothing in incomplete is pending on us
[14:42] #topic Process/Documentation improvements
[14:42] Mission: Review pending process/documentation pull-requests or issues
[14:42] #link https://github.com/canonical/ubuntu-mir/pulls
[14:42] #link https://github.com/canonical/ubuntu-mir/issues
[14:42] so, one PR pending
[14:42] (well, one new)
[14:42] based on the discussion we had last week (or was it the week before?)
[14:42] who even knows any more..
[14:42] "history" :p
[14:43] if you can review/give your 2 cents, I was the only one to ack it
[14:43] apart from that, it seems we are in a good position :)
[14:43] #topic MIR related Security Review Queue
[14:43] Mission: Check on progress, do deadlines seem doable?
[14:43] Some clients can only work with one, some with the other escaping - the URLs point to the same place.
[14:43] #link https://bugs.launchpad.net/~ubuntu-security/+bugs?field.searchtext=%5BMIR%5D&assignee_option=choose&field.assignee=ubuntu-security&field.bug_reporter=&field.bug_commenter=&field.subscriber=ubuntu-mir
[14:43] #link https://bugs.launchpad.net/~ubuntu-security/+bugs?field.searchtext=[MIR]&assignee_option=choose&field.assignee=ubuntu-security&field.bug_reporter=&field.bug_commenter=&field.subscriber=ubuntu-mir
[14:43] Internal link
[14:43] - ensure your teams items are prioritized among each other as you'd expect
[14:43] - ensure community requests do not get stomped by teams calling for favors too much
[14:43] #link https://warthogs.atlassian.net/jira/software/c/projects/SEC/boards/594
[14:43] stage is yours sarnold :)
[14:44] arr, I'm here
[14:44] sorry, meeting overload
[14:44] there's good news here, but not great news
[14:44] reading backlog and chiming in then
[14:44] a familiar lament ;(
[14:44] good is still better than no or bad news :)
[14:44] some of the MIRs have been started but nothing pushed through to completion yet
[14:45] so i'm feeling less dispondent than usual
[14:45] despondent? yeah probably that
[14:45] * didrocks learnt a new word
[14:45] unsure I want to it often :)
[14:46] read - ack to all above
[14:46] I also found a spare three uninterrupted hours last week to work on bringing up a new machine for improvement of our mir process. that felt good. it's not amazing or anything but it felt good to actually knock off an item.
[14:46] ack, well, anyway, thatâs progress and luckily, we donât have that many new MIRs
[14:46] yeah, surprisingly quiet cycle
[14:46] let us clouse out and merge https://github.com/canonical/ubuntu-mir/pull/62 in AOB if sarnold is ok
[14:46] -ubottu:#ubuntu-meeting- Pull 62 in canonical/ubuntu-mir "Clarify exotic hardware requirements" [Open]
[14:46] sarnold: \o/
[14:46] sarnold: it is not that quiet
[14:46] oh
[14:46] if you look at the component mismatch
[14:47] there are so many stubs filed to be processed
[14:47] I expect these to land in a while
[14:47] and then we have reivews to do
[14:47] and then subsequently should expect security reivews too
[14:47] the "new 386 builds" has me a bit worried..
[14:47] six more to come according to https://ubuntu-archive-team.ubuntu.com/component-mismatches-proposed.svg
[14:47] cpaelzer_: yeah, the empty "New" one is a little bit of a falacyâ¦ and maybe rather than teams doing more requests in advance, they are lateâ¦
[14:48] didrocks: I think it is both - the conscious ones early. And now the piled up sync late
[14:48] cpaelzer_: hum, 2 of them are already in progress or almost done?
[14:48] but yeah, letâs see once the list is cleared up
[14:48] ack
[14:48] and now, merging time apparently!
[14:48] #topic Any other business?
[14:49] none here
[14:49] could we have a look at https://github.com/canonical/ubuntu-mir/pull/62 and I merge it if you are ok
[14:49] -ubottu:#ubuntu-meeting- Pull 62 in canonical/ubuntu-mir "Clarify exotic hardware requirements" [Open]
[14:49] didrocks: said ok
[14:49] sarnold: I'll look at your style thing
[14:49] ph
[14:49] oh
[14:49] this isn't a new policy, just clarification, i think two acks separate from the proposer is probably fine
[14:50] sarnold: the sentence is meant to continue
[14:50] ahhh, I was expecting perhaps several of them to remain
[14:50] as people leave just the one that applies
[14:50] one or more, not exactly one
[14:50] it could be >=1
[14:50] or 0 and we will reject :-)
[14:50] :D
[14:50] yeah, we should need to develop an app to file it :p
[14:50] NO!
[14:50] with multi-choices and nested widgets
[14:51] :)
[14:51] NOÂ²
[14:51] we try to help
[14:51] it just felt like a bug when I got to the end of the line and the line type changes but the sentence hadn't ended, heh
[14:51] but not that :-P
[14:51] sarnold: I have the same feeling on the " maintained the package"
[14:51] in the existing template
[14:51] I'll add colon and make it work
[14:51] and then merge
[14:51] and then, you get used to it, but I agree, some parts can be puzzling at first like the multi-lines ones
[14:52] to both
[14:52] no other AOB topic for me
[14:52] "â¦" <- feel free to pick it :)
[14:52] nothing else either
[14:52] #endmeeting
[14:52] Meeting ended at 14:52:42 UTC. Minutes at https://ubottu.com/meetingology/logs/ubuntu-meeting/2024/ubuntu-meeting.2024-08-06-14.33.moin.txt
[14:52] thanks everyone!
[14:52] didrocks: heh yeah, I can see that, I guess i'm in the "used to it phase" there :)
[14:52] thanks didrocks, all :)
[14:52] thanks for driving as I was unplanned-late :-/
[14:53] bonus ++ to didrocks
[14:53] no worry!

[15:39] ahasenack: do you plan on returing to it tomorrow?
[15:39] yes
[15:40] okay, we'll leave it with you then
[15:40] k

[15:43] xypron: livecd-rootfs

[15:44] ack
[15:44] juliank: apt
[15:44] I'm retrying the armhf build of libgcrypt
[15:45] mateus-morais: python-docutils
[15:45] bdmurray ack
[15:45] tobhe: adduser
[15:45] ack
[15:45] which is tied in with shadow
[15:45] and that's that
[15:46] #topic AOB
[15:46] bdmurray: about https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/snapd/+bug/2043820
[15:46] -ubottu:#ubuntu-meeting- Launchpad bug 2043820 in firefox (Ubuntu Noble) "Unable to contact snap store on Xubuntu from Jammy to Noble" [High, Confirmed]
[15:46] The problem is that systemd-resolved is it's own binary package after Jammy
[15:47] And while it will be installed during the upgrade, it is not yet installed at the time that the preinst runs for thunderbird et al (which have the snap store connectivity check)
[15:48] My thought is to do quick SRUs adding Pre-Depends: systemd-resolved to the "deb to snap" transitional packages
[15:48] E.g. firefox, thunderbird, chromium-browser (are there others?)
[15:49] This would ensure that systemd-resolved is back at the time those packages do their connectivity check
[15:49] What about a PostUpgradeInstall section in distupgrade.cfg?
[15:49] That's way too late
[15:50] The problem is not that systemd-resolved won't get installed at all during the upgrade. It's just that the ordering is something like:
[15:50] 1. unpack new systemd (meaning systemd-resolved goes away)
[15:50] The documentation says "action right after the upgrade was calculated in the cache"
[15:50] 2. unpack e.g thunderbird.
[15:51] (meaning snap store check)
[15:51] 3. unpack systemd-resolved
[15:51] bdmurray: hm, well it only *marks* for install at that stage IIUC, it does not actually perform it
[15:51] and NB that we already have PostUpgradeInstall=systemd-resolved in place for upgrades from Jammy to Noble
[15:52] okay
[15:54] Well if its not working then lets go with the alternate solution.
[15:55] Anything else?
[15:55] I've started trying to get statistics on publishing delays in my PPAs after a ~3 hour cycle yesterday
[15:55] https://gist.github.com/Chris-Peterson444/a477f5b7356007caf2653079eb183635
[15:57] I'd look at seeded snaps via the manifests to figure out which transitional packages to update
[15:57] thanks cpete, I'll use the script on my next ppa build
[15:58] #endmeeting
[15:58] Meeting ended at 15:58:08 UTC. Minutes at https://ubottu.com/meetingology/logs/ubuntu-meeting/2024/ubuntu-meeting.2024-08-01-15.02.moin.txt

[14:51] "engineering sample in $name's home on $team, manager $name"
[14:51] instead of the hardware
[14:51] good point
[14:52] indeed
[14:52] we can fix this in one go
[14:52] thank you both, let me make a PR once I find 10 minutes with that as the start
[14:52] but I agree too with the examples, that would be good illustrations and shows what the "it" refers too (probably 2 sentences)
[14:52] thanks cpaelzer!
[14:52] BTW I'm not too happy at the "home HW" maybe i should order them by "ok'ness' :-)
[14:53] heh :-)
[14:53] good idea

item.title: 26.07.2024: ubuntu-security
item.description:
# UBUNTU-SECURITY

=== chris14_ is now known as chris14
[04:17] umm, can canonical remove unwanted keys from the ubuntu hkp server?
[04:19] Hello Juest, do you maintain the hkp server?
[04:21] sudhackar: i am just a user asking about the server
[04:21] interesting, was that a highlight word for the right people?
[04:21] sorry I was just trying to understand the rationale behind the demand
[04:22] sudhackar: to answer your question, no, but i am just wondering about whatever exceptions are done with possible high risk cases of compromised keys
[04:22] well i know its just public keys but yeah
[04:22] is it not possible to accidentally upload private keys, correct?
[04:23] excuse my stupidity, i should know this, i was just asking to double check something of my own
[04:24] its a hockeypuck server - You can always read their doc
[04:24] can others sync with the hkp server? i am not saying its happening right now but im wondering if its possible to have a malicious scenario where syncing would cause a wipe
[04:32] I think its valid to treat it with such threat model but both hockeypuck and `gpg --keyserver .... --send-keys ....` can be checked
[04:40] :)
[04:41] was it thought before?
[04:42] sudhackar: so they already have checks to prevent such case?
[09:15] Juest: I'm not an expert on gpg keys and keyserver, but my understanding is that if there's a compromised key then the private key holder can issue a revocation, and that is then carried by keyservers. So keys are never deleted as such. On the Launchpad end, users list their keys, so to get Launchpad to stop treating a key as valid, the user can remove it. I don't know if Launchpad pays attention
[09:15] to key revocations or not (I'd hope it does!)
=== chris14_ is now known as chris14
[17:54] rbasak: ah right, thanks for your input :) i mean, what if someone is trying to erase their existence either because of their changed threat model or being a high risk person that is harassed
[19:02] if you have such a problem and if you can't remove your own keys using the protocol you can always contact Canonical directly under GDPR rules
=== Juesto is now known as Juest

[15:09] #startmeeting
[15:09] Meeting started at 15:09:09 UTC. The chair is bdmurray. Information about MeetBot at https://wiki.ubuntu.com/meetingology
[15:09] Available commands: action, commands, idea, info, link, nick
[15:09] #meetingtopic Status Updates
[15:09] https://discourse.ubuntu.com/t/foundations-team-updates-thursday-2024-07-25/46682
[15:10] #topic Status Updates
[15:10] Let's take a couple of minutes to finish reviewing the status updates
[15:13] schopin: can you tell me more about apport-retrace for not amd64?
[15:15] bdmurray: bdrung had the strange idea of actually writing tests for apport-retrace. That was the start of a long series of issues, mostly with the test assumptions but also with some of the code. bdrung probably kept better track of it.
[15:15] Okay
[15:16] Some optimisations both in CPU and memory usage should come out of this, though.
[15:17] #topic Release incoming bugs
[15:17] \o
[15:18] #link http://reports.qa.ubuntu.com/reports/rls-mgr/rls-oo-incoming-bug-tasks.html#foundations-bugs
[15:19] bug 1969394
[15:19] -ubottu:#ubuntu-meeting- Bug 1969394 in update-manager (Ubuntu) "'Settings & Livepatch' button opens 'settings' tab, not livepatch" [Low, Confirmed] https://launchpad.net/bugs/1969394
[15:19] Okay, it seems to be in the desktop team's backlog
[15:19] Let's target it to noble and oracular for them so it'll drop from the report
[15:20] bug 2073997
[15:20] -ubottu:#ubuntu-meeting- Bug 2073997 in netplan.io (Ubuntu) "netplan: routing autopkgtest fails on armhf" [Undecided, New] https://launchpad.net/bugs/2073997
[15:20] I thought we would have fixed that by having the 'vrf' module available on the autopkgtest hosts, but it seems to be flaky. CC Skia ?
[15:20] Also, an upstream fix is pending: https://github.com/canonical/netplan/commit/586694b6beb32e36be868dff0c88cc116bf2ed8b
[15:20] -ubottu:#ubuntu-meeting- Commit 586694b in canonical/netplan "test:routing: skip VRF test if kernel module is not available"
[15:21] I was about to suggest that approach :)
[15:21] I'm wondering if maybe the installed kernel modules do not always match the hosts kernel version?
[15:21] slyon: the module should be here, but some workers might have rebooted and lost it? I'll go check
[15:22] thanks. Anyway. It can be assigned to me and the tag dropped.
[15:22] Oh right because arm64 is sad
[15:22] that ^^^
[15:22] moving on then
[15:22] #link http://reports.qa.ubuntu.com/reports/rls-mgr/rls-nn-incoming-bug-tasks.html#foundations-bugs
[15:22] bug 2043820
[15:22] -ubottu:#ubuntu-meeting- Bug 2043820 in firefox (Ubuntu Noble) "Unable to contact snap store on Xubuntu from Jammy to Noble" [High, Confirmed] https://launchpad.net/bugs/2043820
[15:22] bdmurray, regarding apport-retrace: recently i spent most of my time on https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/apport/+bug/2073787
[15:22] enr0n: the point release is coming up soon
[15:22] -ubottu:#ubuntu-meeting- Launchpad bug 2073787 in apport (Ubuntu) "apport-retrace needs more than 1 GB" [High, Triaged]
[15:24] I will plan on working that upgrade bug next week
[15:24] Thanks!
[15:24] I'll remove the rls-nn-incoming tag then
[15:24] ff is empty so we are done there
[15:25] and I meant jj - too many LTSes
[15:25] #topic Team proposed-migration report
[15:26] #link https://ubuntu-archive-team.ubuntu.com/proposed-migration/update_excuses_by_team.html#foundations-bugs
[15:28] pyopenssl - mwhudson
[15:28] apport - bdrung
[15:28] ack, i haven't done much else :D
[15:29] uralt - bpftrace
[15:29] glibc - schopin
[15:31] setuptools - andersson123
[15:32] autodep8 - mateus-morais
[15:32] bdmurray ack
[15:33] setuptools is with vpa1977
[15:33] okay
[15:34] bdrung: initramfs-tools
[15:35] ack
[15:36] upils: pkgconf
[15:36] ack
[15:37] doko: python3.12
[15:37] enr0n: systemd
[15:37] ack
[15:38] vpa1977: bpfcc
[15:39] ogayot: python3-stdlib-extensions
[15:39] schopin it looks like gcc-14 striked again for pkgconf :D
[15:39] bdmurray: ack!
[15:39] slyon: mawk
[15:39] all of this investigation on libdmapsharing was not all for nothing!
[15:39] Aha, nice to hear ;)
[15:40] ack
[15:40] I've retried libgd-perl
[15:41] dbungert: python-dateutil
[15:41] bdmurray: python3-defaults (I suspect a bunch of these need retrying)
[15:42] ack for python-dateutil
=== pushkarnk1 is now known as pushkarnk
[15:43] waveform: binutils
[15:44] I think that's good
[15:44] #topic AOB
[15:45] I'm off to DebConf next week
[15:46] starting next Tuesday and for 10 days, I'll travelling, so mostly available to answer questions, but very asynchronously
[15:46] I'll be*
[15:46] debconf next week as well
[15:48] I'll be off for 4 weeks
[15:51] #endmeeting
[15:51] Meeting ended at 15:51:46 UTC. Minutes at https://ubottu.com/meetingology/logs/ubuntu-meeting/2024/ubuntu-meeting.2024-07-25-15.09.moin.txt

item.title: 24.07.2024: ubuntu-security, ubuntu-meeting
item.description:
# UBUNTU-SECURITY

=== chris14_ is now known as chris14
=== voeid5 is now known as voeid
=== ahasenack__ is now known as ahasenack
=== wete_ is now known as wete
=== wete_ is now known as wete
=== wete_ is now known as wete
=== wete_ is now known as wete
[20:42] hello
[20:42] sarnold: hello
[20:42] May I ask you a question about Canonical ? (I think that you work at Canonical)
[20:44] I'll ask later
[20:44] Thanks
[21:44] hwpplayer1: yes, I work at canonical; I'm happy to answer anything :)
[21:50] I want to work at Canonical
[21:50] For kernel engineer position
[21:50] do you have any suggestion in your mind ?
[21:51] I changed my mind
[21:53] sarnold: how are you doing by the way ?
[21:53] Sorry I directly asked my question
[21:53] my bad
[21:55] hwpplayer1: hey :) not bad not bad, I'm enjoying the cooler weather that we're having lately, it's been too hot for me most of the summer
[21:55] hwpplayer1: how's it going for you?
[21:56] I'm excited I started C++ course
[21:56] And also I have a relaxed mind
[21:56] Here is too hot same
[21:56] hwpplayer1: oo relaxed mind and a good course, sounds nice, except for the heat, hehe
[21:57] :D yes
[21:57] I have icecream to warm down
[21:57] \o/
[21:58] to become colder maybe better
[21:58] Do you run Emacs ?
[21:58] hwpplayer1: we've got a fairly large kernel team and I really only talk with a handful of kernel engineers where their work intersects with security .. so my insights into the team are a bit limited. generally speaking, I'd encourage making the most of the written essays, highlighting successes and trying to write with a 'voice'
[21:59] hwpplayer1: the essays are read by humans and if you keep that in mind it'll probably help out
[22:00] understood
[22:00] hwpplayer1: heh, I run vim .. back when I started, vi was everywhere, but emacs was only on some systems, so the choice was easy. today I might choose differently, the emacs users seem happier.
[22:00] I run vim/vi on BSD systems
[22:01] I don't struggle to install
[22:01] emacs
[22:01] how many computers and phones do you have ? I have one Debian machine and an Android
[22:02] what should I do to be elected to the kernel team ? how to start contributing ?
[22:03] Should I start by visiting kernel newbies upstream developers ?
[22:05] I will study hard this year until the 2025 / 2024 December and try my best
[22:05] heh, when I started, it was very common to use someone else's computer -- I'd dial in to my ISP and use the stock vi on the thing
[22:06] I interact with two android phones, one android table, very regularly, and have a handful of replaced android phones sitting around; I've got three ubuntu computers powered on at the moment; I've got one powered down right now because it generates a lot of heat, and two more that are less useful than I would like :(
[22:07] i've also got an ubuntu VM hosted in AWS for irc
[22:08] cool
[22:08] Do you have Ubuntu Pro
[22:08] I was using 22.04 LTS with Pro
[22:10] I'll be back soon to Ubuntu with the latest LTS
[22:11] Now I run Debian, my goal is to learn the Debian infrastructure the deb packaging I mean and the other things
[22:11] I run Emacs 29.4 with backports
[22:13] brb
[22:13] yes, I've got ubuntu pro enabled on most of my computers
[22:13] thanks
[22:13] That's good to hear
[22:13] I use the kernel livepatches on some of them, and universe updates on all of them
[22:13] I'm very interested in livepatch
[22:14] Did canonical start after Red Hat and Suse
[22:14] oh right, kernelnewbies .. it used to be much more active. there's still conversations in the irc channel; I haven't been on the mail list for a very long time, I'm not sure how healthy that is
[22:14] yes
[22:14] we got to benefit from their efforts, because we got to use the livepatching facility that was upstreamed into the kernel, while I believe both redhat and suse were using their own out-of-tree functionality that formed the basis of what got upstreamed
[22:15] But in my opinion Ubuntu is at the center between enterprise companies and individuals so it is better for me
[22:15] a better karma
[22:15] i'm not sure if red hat and suse are still using their own things or if they've been able to switch to the upstream implementation; I expect the process of preparing updates is pretty similar for all three approaches
[22:16] understood
[22:16] What do you think the position in the market of the Canonical's Ubuntu ? Like I tried to tell
[22:17] A better karma between companies and individuals
[22:17] Also has a phone still supported by UBports
[22:17] volla phone etc
[22:17] ubports is completely separate from canonical these days
[22:17] I'm interested in Purism also which is GTK and Debian based
[22:18] a group of enthusiasts have kept it alive
[22:18] yes I know
[22:18] okay good good
[22:18] But That thing ubuntu-touch still lives despite canonical left the project
[22:18] ubuntu is popular with both enterprises and enthusiasts, largely because a lot of things "just work"
[22:18] yes
[22:18] some very demanding workloads like SAP or Oracle DB might be hyper-tuned for RHEL or SLES
[22:19] understood
[22:19] and some very demanding enthusiasts might be a better fit for arch :)
[22:19] I don't know about arch
[22:19] I didn't try it
[22:19] our packages come through debian unstable before they enter our devel release, and every six months we ship it. arch may do a better job of providing very fresh versions of a wider variety of packages.
[22:20] I've never tried it either :( I think we'd like it, if only we'd try it, hehe
[22:20] yes maybe blackarch :D
[22:20] tons of tools
[22:21] do you contribute to any spesific security tool like wireshark or any other /
[22:21] apparmor, though it's been a while since I contributed in any significant way
[22:24] hmm let me check the source code
[22:26] do you please give the repository link sarnold ?
[22:26] is it on GitLab ?
[22:26] https://gitlab.com/apparmor/apparmor
[22:28] https://apparmor.net/
[22:28] also
[22:29] okay cool Thanks
[22:34] hwpplayer1: heh yeah that's the one ;)
[22:40] great
[22:40] Do you have Zram on your Ubuntu machines ?
[22:41] I have 8(7.6 when calculated) GB RAM and 70 GB Zram
[22:41] 76 or 70 idk
[22:41] :D
[22:44] zounds :)
[22:44] I don't think I've got zram or zswap configured
[22:44] I keep meaning to give it a try but it's never a top priority for me
[22:45] what if system borks ans zram cannot write a log?
[22:45] I configured it for mobile development like Android Qt mobile and Ubuntu Touch
[22:45] ans/and
[22:45] I am totally new to this tech
[22:48] except when ubuntu constantly has issues, particularly livecds whereas debian is fine
[22:48] I run Debian 12
[22:49] I think that it crashes when GNOME extensions are enabled
[22:49] Same for Ubuntu 22.04
[22:49] yeah umm, this is a channel to discuss ubuntu security matters, do you have a on topic question?
[22:50] system crashes are on topic ?
[22:50] sounds like #linux or #ubuntu is a better fit for you. system crashes are more a support thing not security.
[22:51] thanks
[22:51] I'll stay here to be connected
[22:51] 'constantly has issues' .. lets talk about that
[22:51] well, you stay connected to the network server if you leave a channel
[22:52] I mean I'll read this channel's messages
[22:52] oerheks: im more talking past experiences really, its not as bad nowadays and frankly i do not interact too often with the live environment
[22:52] It is a buffer in Emacs
[22:52] cool
[22:53] if one needs a live environment, use a daily build
[22:53] oh so for installation/rescue/live is it preferred to use the bleeding edge isos?
[22:54] or what did you mean by daily build?
[22:55] https://cdimage.ubuntu.com/daily-live/current/ for desktop, sure you can find server and such
[22:56] thanks, oddly enough this is not recommended/noted anywhere
[22:58] one must have a reason to do so, i guess
[22:58] i see, i mean its not really advertised or anything, but good to know there's that choice for those who dont mind recycling isos
[22:58] hmm, cdimage.ubuntu seems to only contain desktop stuff?
[22:59] oh is probably in ubuntu-server
[22:59] i see that the spins folders are there on the root
[22:59] yes even cloud images https://cloud-images.ubuntu.com/buildd/daily/
[22:59] heh yeah we've got downloads scattered over so many domains :/
[23:00] but that is more likely
[23:00] s/domains/subdomains/
[23:01] oerheks: interesting, the buildd folder is not exposed in the homepage of cloud-images and it says in the description that its technically not supported for bug reports
[23:02] and oci is empty
[23:02] i think technically it is, as it contains the latest updates
[23:02] anyways, is there a better channel for this discussion other than here and ubuntu?
[23:02] this channel is fine
[23:02] the buildd folder says: These are not general-purpose images and their usage is not supported outside of Multipass or Launchpad. Bugs found on those platforms should be filed in the cloud-images project on Launchpad.net.
[23:03] jups, as regular update issue
[23:03] oh hmm, i see
[23:04] ah so its only supported in rolling update scenarios?
[23:05] one can see this as rolling, which is not true, still holding on to stable packages for lts
[23:05] yeah i understand that, sorry for the misnomer
[23:05] just bug fixes, not new features
[23:05] no, your question is valid.
[23:05] hence why i said rolling updates not release
[23:06] a rolling model for updates not for releases which the latter is more popular/common
[23:06] i used to wanna run latest, but i am back to solid lts
[23:06] ah interesting
[23:06] 22.04 for now
[23:06] hey at least its the little corner to chat with ubuntu people outside of the support channels :D
[23:07] appreciate the attention and time ^^
[23:07] sometimes it is minutes, sometimes it takes a year to meet and greet, Juest
[23:07] true
[23:07] have fun!
[23:07] nice to meet you likewise
[23:08] hmmmm just remained thinking....
[23:08] in shortl; i love a good argument
[23:09] oh btw i got the ubuntu installation booted in a isolated container with systemd init with success on connecting to systemd through a chroot after entering the namespace
[23:09] on a different non-systemd distro
[23:09] wow :)
[23:09] I thought that sounded like a pretty good challenge
[23:09] but im facing permission issues when it comes to processes creating a user namespace
[23:09] yeah it was sarnold :)
[23:10] i read the suggestions of phogg and tingo
[23:11] sarnold: Can I pm you :
[23:11] still not sure it can be done
[23:11] the better help came from the #systemd channel :)
[23:11] it can be done, you just have to be careful and mount everything correctly
[23:11] yes, but there are 2 parts missing something.
[23:11] oh? which?
[23:13] the issue is that if i use a isolated user namespace there's no privileges, causing cgroups to fail to be created, and basically no users other than the root mapping
[23:14] therefore one cannot mount anything in it.. yet
[23:14] something i wasnt doing before is making brand new mounts for /dev (shm, pts), and /run and /tmp
[23:15] the mount issue is fixed by adding --mount-proc, and the privileges can be partially resolved by mapping root to have privileges
[23:15] oerheks: you drop in a shell, do the necessary mounts and exec systemd and that works
[23:15] there must be a trick, avoiding or capsulation of namespace
[23:16] no idea, this goes over my heas :-D
[23:16] only ipc, pid, mount and uts are isolated
[23:17] before i was doing -i instead of each separate namespace spec
[23:17] so thats one part of the issue lol
[23:17] anyways
[23:18] each separate namespace spec .. ? from host and vm ?
[23:18] this is not a vm
[23:18] a backup
[23:18] nor runc based
[23:18] its a full-on linux partition install of ubuntu that i have
[23:18] im doing this method because i dont want to reboot the whole computer to perform updates
[23:19] hwpplayer1: sure
[23:19] you made a genuine copy, now trying to keep it updated, without systemd involved, i understand
[23:19] and the reason why chroot doesnt cut it is because i need the systemd stack to run snapd socket properly for the sake of running snap refresh
[23:20] oerheks: its not a copy lol, just a ubuntu installation that actually can boot on the same computer without issues :)
[23:20] im not trying to kexec (replace the booted system) nor use more resources through virtualization or container runtimes
[23:20] ai, snap refresh.. time to run your own snap mirror
[23:21] the problem is that snap cannot connect to snapd
[23:21] that gives double security
[23:21] also because of the chroot and not mounting /tmp, /dev, /run i have data in the partition on those folders lol
[23:22] heh, fun idea
[23:23] i was seeing issues where systemd sockets couldn't be reachable because it was a incoming private connection from a unknown client therefore not allowing it
[23:23] to enter the environment outside of the unshare shell once systemd is executed i have to chroot inside after running nsenter
[23:24] sudo journalctl --no-pager -u snapd
[23:24] https://snapcraft.io/docs/fix-common-issues
[23:24] Juest: hah, that sounds right
[23:24] now i am correctly able to connect to systemd
[23:24] yes, supposed so
[23:24] but the problem is that units do not have permission to use the user namespace
[23:25] so you need to, snapd ?
[23:25] err, question is: do you need to?
[23:25] oerheks: yes, i want to get snapd up and running because its required by snap to do any operations
[23:26] lxd can get 'ubuntu' things working in containers, so there's got to be a way for you to construct a similar enough environment by hand
[23:26] the whole reason im into this is because i wanted to do snap refresh
[23:26] sarnold: sure, maybe i could get somewhere with lxc, im not using lxd because its not light
[23:26] i have lxc but im not sure how to tell it to containerize a entire partition and boot that
[23:27] doing a volume sounds very risky because it could wipe it
[23:27] tar it up, ask it to boot the tarball? copy over the changed files by hand?
[23:27] i dont have storage for that
[23:28] i feel more comfortable with the unshare "example utility"
[23:31] okay im back to the same issue
[23:31] failed to get properties: transport endpoint is not connected
[23:32] hmmmm
[23:32] oh well
[23:33] oh lol i forgot to enter in the pid namespace
[23:33] Juest: maybe run dmesg -w ...
[23:33] doorbell
[23:33] food?
[23:34] 01:33 here
[23:34] oops security
[23:35] oh lol
[23:35] sarnold: i forgot to enter in the systemd namespace, i was in the unshare namespace instead :P
[23:36] hostname should not be of importance, unless ssh certs?
[23:36] issue now is dns resolver
[23:39] okay
[23:39] networkmanager has limited connectivity
[23:39] hmmmmm
[23:39] oh well
[23:39] oerheks, sarnold, where would it be preferred to discuss this in?
[23:47] Juest: aha, awesome! hard to know, maybe someone else in #ubuntu would have more ideas, but namespacing is kind of a security-ish thing? maybe #lxcontainers would have folks with more direct container experience? this is probably fine
[23:47] oerheks: heh, a new exercise bike
[23:48] :D
[23:48] i see
[23:48] well, its related because the target is a ubuntu system :P
[23:49] you mean #lxc maybe?
[23:50] i guess that #linux is fine as well
[23:51] sure, post on stack
[23:51] another little issue, it seems the gui started up but i dont see it, i should check the console
[23:55] well
[23:55] im having a issue refreshing the snap
[23:56] ill check the link

# UBUNTU-MEETING

[06:42] didrocks joalif slyon cpaelzer jamespage: here is the (hopefully you agree) trivial MIR that I mentioned will come https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/isa-support/+bug/2073895 . due to the expected virtual sprint and debconf downtime for many I'm reaching out here to maybe get it reviewed before two more weeks pass
[06:43] -ubottu:#ubuntu-meeting- Launchpad bug 2073895 in isa-support (Ubuntu) "[MIR] isa-support" [Undecided, New]

item.title: 23.07.2024: ubuntu-security, ubuntu-meeting
item.description:
# UBUNTU-SECURITY

=== chris14_ is now known as chris14

# UBUNTU-MEETING

=== pushkarnk1 is now known as pushkarnk
=== pushkarnk1 is now known as pushkarnk
=== pushkarnk1 is now known as pushkarnk
=== pushkarnk1 is now known as pushkarnk

[14:29] huhu
[14:30] #startmeeting Weekly Main Inclusion Requests status
[14:30] Meeting started at 14:30:29 UTC. The chair is cpaelzer. Information about MeetBot at https://wiki.ubuntu.com/meetingology
[14:30] Available commands: action, commands, idea, info, link, nick
[14:30] Ping for MIR meeting - didrocks joalif slyon sarnold cpaelzer jamespage ( eslerm dviererbe )
[14:30] o/
[14:30] hey o/
[14:31] o/
[14:31] #topic current component mismatches
[14:31] Mission: Identify required actions and spread the load among the teams
[14:31] #link https://people.canonical.com/~ubuntu-archive/component-mismatches-proposed.svg
[14:31] #link https://people.canonical.com/~ubuntu-archive/component-mismatches.svg
[14:31] cpaelzer: did you already run any demotion on rustc-1.76-doc?
[14:31] o/
[14:32] slyon: I did the promotions on those that were not in, but no demotions
[14:32] let me look at it in excuses
[14:32] yeah not there
[14:32] but here for the docs
[14:32] handling that now ...
[14:33] thx!
[14:33] look at the other cases in that time
[14:33] libimobiledivce is new IIRC and is for the desktop team to investigate. didrocks
[14:33] dpdk is new IIRC and for the server team to investigate. cpaelzer
[14:34] yeah, itâs new, Iâll pass the message, but be aware that the integration desktop team is for most of them at GUADEC
[14:34] the others seem to be handling (having a bug report assigned)
[14:34] so probably wonât be solved by next week. Iâll still ensure itâs logged though
[14:34] thanks!
[14:35] slyon: cargo-1.76-doc is also in there
[14:35] slyon: but missing in the Extra Exclude
[14:35] cargo-1.76-doc recommends rust-1.76-doc
[14:35] I can add the extra-exclude
[14:35] so it will still trigger
[14:35] I can demote them now
[14:35] thanks for adding the matching exclude
[14:36] demotion done
[14:36] I can talk about dpdk->isa-support
[14:36] That was me doing that in Debian and not thinking that I need a MIR
[14:36] That will be super duper trivial
[14:36] as it has no content, it is only dependency magic
[14:37] I'll do the paperwork but then will reach out for someone to do a review
[14:37] anyone willing to sign up to be pinged by me on that?
[14:37] I'll be travelling for the next 2 weeks. So I'm probably not the best choice :)
[14:38] Well, it isn't urgent - worst case it will be here next week as bug that needs an owner
[14:38] while saying next week - I'll be on the mid cycle sprint then
[14:39] I'll be at DebConf
[14:39] yep
[14:39] anyone else mentally getting ready to lead this next week?
[14:39] we can anser this in AOB
[14:39] going on for now
[14:39] so MIR meeting attendance might be low
[14:39] s/anser/answer/
[14:39] it surely will be
[14:40] good morning
[14:40] I might just ping all of you for a reivew directly then
[14:40] and we have a light or skipped meeting
[14:40] let us see who is available then
[14:40] #topic New MIRs
[14:40] Mission: ensure to assign all incoming reviews for fast processing
[14:40] #link https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/?field.searchtext=&orderby=-date_last_updated&field.status%3Alist=NEW&field.status%3Alist=CONFIRMED&assignee_option=none&field.assignee=&field.subscriber=ubuntu-mir
[14:40] empty
[14:40] #topic Incomplete bugs / questions
[14:40] Mission: Identify required actions and spread the load among the teams
[14:40] #link https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/?field.searchtext=&orderby=-date_last_updated&field.status%3Alist=INCOMPLETE_WITH_RESPONSE&field.status%3Alist=INCOMPLETE_WITHOUT_RESPONSE&field.subscriber=ubuntu-mir
[14:41] There is a barrage on 18th of July
[14:41] all around the openstack driven MIRs
[14:41] alas, not much happy news to report here
[14:41] that is ok, they will mark it for us once ready
[14:41] #topic Process/Documentation improvements
[14:41] Mission: Review pending process/documentation pull-requests or issues
[14:41] #link https://github.com/canonical/ubuntu-mir/pulls
[14:41] ah sorry I jumped the gun :) I saw long urls, heh
[14:41] #link https://github.com/canonical/ubuntu-mir/issues
[14:41] np sarnold
[14:41] nothing here either
[14:41] #topic MIR related Security Review Queue
[14:41] Mission: Check on progress, do deadlines seem doable?
[14:41] Some clients can only work with one, some with the other escaping - the URLs point to the same place.
[14:41] #link https://bugs.launchpad.net/~ubuntu-security/+bugs?field.searchtext=%5BMIR%5D&assignee_option=choose&field.assignee=ubuntu-security&field.bug_reporter=&field.bug_commenter=&field.subscriber=ubuntu-mir
[14:41] #link https://bugs.launchpad.net/~ubuntu-security/+bugs?field.searchtext=[MIR]&assignee_option=choose&field.assignee=ubuntu-security&field.bug_reporter=&field.bug_commenter=&field.subscriber=ubuntu-mir
[14:41] Internal link
[14:41] - ensure your teams items are prioritized among each other as you'd expect
[14:42] - ensure community requests do not get stomped by teams calling for favors too much
[14:42] #link https://warthogs.atlassian.net/jira/software/c/projects/SEC/boards/594
[14:42] sarnold: you say nothing to report, but last time you said there will be more talks on getting resources here
[14:42] and since then the backlog increased a bit
[14:42] once these python things we just saw in incomplete hit (5 IIRC) they will go there too
[14:42] zounds
[14:42] heh
[14:42] this is new for security (as of today): https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/highway/+bug/2070807
[14:42] -ubottu:#ubuntu-meeting- Launchpad bug 2070807 in highway (Ubuntu) "[MIR] highway" [Undecided, New]
[14:43] needs to be added to Jira
[14:43] sarnold: please map that to Jira
[14:43] https://warthogs.atlassian.net/browse/SEC-4768
[14:43] sarnold: give me either a) some hope this will work out b) a call that I should escalate things
[14:44] sarnold: in the past you said discussions go on and I'm more than happy to leave this to you. Unless IF you want me to push for it as well
[14:45] cpaelzer: well, the most recent conversation I had with aburrage, he was of the opinion that it would be easier / less scary / more welcoming to onboard the completely new folks if I work on my almost-roadmap-items of making easier onboarding tools and documentation improvements
[14:45] sarnold: ok I guess, I count this as hope then
[14:45] cpaelzer: so perhaps it's on me to try to improve the early onboarding experiences
[14:46] ok
[14:46] #topic Any other business?
[14:46] I double checked, I can lead next week at 25% brain power
[14:46] since we expect low attendence thta might be ok
[14:46] nothing for me, but ditto for next week, can attend with parallel meetings
[14:46] the other 75% go to plenary sessions
[14:46] nothing else from me
[14:47] nothing here
[14:47] I probably cannot attend next week (and the week after)
[14:47] nothing else from me
[14:47] nothing here
[14:47] similar story for all debconf/demcamp/virtual-sprint folks
[14:47] thank you all
[14:47] thank you!
[14:47] today countdown is based on https://www.americanscientist.org/sites/americanscientist.org/files/20144141249210337-2014-05TechnologueFp170.jpg
[14:47] thanks all!
[14:47] 9
[14:47] 9
[14:47] 9
[14:47] 9
[14:47] 9
[14:47] #endmeeting
[14:48] Meeting ended at 14:48:00 UTC. Minutes at https://ubottu.com/meetingology/logs/ubuntu-meeting/2024/ubuntu-meeting.2024-07-23-14.30.moin.txt
[14:48] oo debcamp / debconf :) have fun :)
[14:48] lol
[14:48] heh
[14:48] didnât know that one :)
[14:48] thanks!

item.title: 22.07.2024: ubuntu-meeting
item.description:
# UBUNTU-MEETING

=== blackboxsw_away is now known as blackboxsw
=== pushkarnk1 is now known as pushkarnk
[16:00] \o
[16:00] o/
[16:00] o/
[16:02] o/
[16:03] tsimonq2, your list on https://wiki.ubuntu.com/mkukri/BootPpuApplication might be wrong. for example, ayatana-indicator-datetime 23.6.0-1 is from Mike Gabriel.
[16:03] i think that was a sync from debian
[16:04] shows up as "sru" on the sponsorship miner for some reason
[16:04] (and actual srus dont list sru on there)
[16:04] found it (it was a sync): https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/ayatana-indicator-datetime/+bug/2045041
[16:04] -ubottu:#ubuntu-meeting- Launchpad bug 2045041 in ayatana-indicator-datetime (Ubuntu) "Sync ayatana-indicator-datetime 23.6.0-1 (universe) from Debian unstable (main)" [Wishlist, Fix Released]
[16:06] o/ (I'm 5 minutes late due to having to kick my internet what'd I miss?)
[16:06] not much :)
[16:07] I guess I'll chair since nobody else is?
[16:07] #startmeeting Developer Membership Board
[16:07] Meeting started at 16:07:14 UTC. The chair is rbasak. Information about MeetBot at https://wiki.ubuntu.com/meetingology
[16:07] Available commands: action, commands, idea, info, link, nick
[16:07] #topic Review of previous action items
[16:07] Utkarsh to review the tasks for a DMB election and decide if he can take that on. If not we should choose somebody to run the election.
[16:07] The election happaned, so I guess that can be dropped?
[16:07] #topic teward follow up to get all application process wiki/docs to explain the process to be able to edit wiki pages, for applicants who don't yet have wiki edit access (carried over)
[16:08] that still needs to persist, but i'm never getting enough cycles to do it (support welcome!)
[16:08] #undo
[16:08] Removing item from minutes: TOPIC
[16:08] #action teward follow up to get all application process wiki/docs to explain the process to be able to edit wiki pages, for applicants who don't yet have wiki edit access (carried over)
[16:08] ACTION: teward follow up to get all application process wiki/docs to explain the process to be able to edit wiki pages, for applicants who don't yet have wiki edit access (carried over)
[16:08] #topic Package Set/Per Package Uploader Applications
[16:08] #subtopic 2024-07-22 Mate Kukri Boot PPU Application
[16:08] mkukri: welcome!
[16:08] hello
[16:08] #link https://wiki.ubuntu.com/mkukri/BootPpuApplication
[16:09] Any questions for mkukri on his application?
[16:10] None from me.
[16:11] In addition to my usual questions which I can ask later, there are a couple of things that come to mind for a PPU request for these packages.
[16:11] First, to be clear, this is a reasonable thing to request.
[16:12] However, notably this is new ground for us. I'm not aware that we've approved many (any?) PPU for core packages such as these.
[16:12] So one question for the DMB: is PPU appropriate for these packages at all?
[16:13] Second question: I appreciate mkukri documenting the very special publication process for these packages in his application. But, don't these need AA approval to land? I see no endorsements from AAs who have reviewed these.
[16:14] I think the reason we consider things "core" is why Core Developer exists. On the sole basis that one wrong move on these core packages, and there can be major problems.
[16:14] juliank's endorsement says: "Given the way these updates are published with external signing PPAs, and Mate already having access to request signing and unembargo those we already trust him arguably more than the PPU" - so what's the story there? Has an AA already granted mkukri some level of access for these?
[16:14] i believe the signing is done via ~canonical-signing-jobs and a private signing PPA. i have submitted many signing requests myself via that
[16:15] i think after that the packages get binary copied to the archive. i am not aware of extra AA approval after that, but i could be wrong (as obviously those copies were dont by juliank to this point)
[16:15] I agree with Robie, wouldn't that binary copy need special AA handling?
[16:15] So on my second question, I'm not comfortable approving PPU without an AA coming along and agreeing that this makes sense to do, and that they're happy with mkukri's handling of the special process in terms of review submissions, etc.
[16:16] I know that special AA handling is required for SRUs. I'm not sure about the development release.
[16:16] It may be that it isn't required, but I think it should be regardless!
[16:17] I looked at https://launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/grub2/+publishinghistory as an example. I see entries like "Copied from ubuntu oracular in Ubuntu UEFI build PPA by Julian Andres Klode"
[16:18] grub2 isnt signed
[16:18] If it's going via the unapproved queue (whether for source or binaries) then my understanding of Launchpad's model is that it would say that regardless. I don't know of a publicly accessible audit log of queue accepts.
[16:18] the signed ones are copied from here https://launchpad.net/~ubuntu-uefi-team/+archive/ubuntu/proposed-public
[16:19] How would the other DMB members like to proceed?
[16:20] Regarding the first question, I think it's similar to the kernel, both in terms of the huge impact it can have but also the very specific expert knowledge needed.
[16:21] You don't need to understand how to handle library transitions to be a good maintainer of the boot stack, and the SRU process for it is very specific.
[16:21] The kernel has an advantage that it is well abstracted from everything else though. With these packages there are deep interactions that extend well beyond these packages.
[16:22] So no need to understand library transitions, no, but I get the impression differently deep packaging knowledge is needed.
[16:22] Just for context later on, we're talking about the following packages: grub2, grub2-unsigned, grub2-signed, shim, shim-signed, ubuntu-boot-test, python-uefivars, efivar, efibootmgr
[16:23] rbasak, do we have a list of PPU sets and which contain packages from main?
[16:23] I can't think of a way to extract that quickly unfortunately.
[16:25] rbasak, do you have the reference to all PPU sets that we have?
[16:25] The best way I think think of is to iterate over ~ubuntu-dev and/or ~ubuntu-uploaders and run edit-acl over each person.
[16:26] For packagesets we have https://ubuntu-archive-team.ubuntu.com/packagesets/
[16:26] But that doesn't cover PPU
[16:26] There's no concept of a "PPU set". Just what individual ACLs have been granted to individuals.
[16:27] thanks. bookmarked. With "PPU set" I meant more or less package sets - or the superset of package sets and individual PPUs.
[16:29] rbasak: I fail to understand how these packages have that much more interactions with the rest of the system than the kernel, really.
[16:29] The only recent "core" type package we granted PPU to was livecd-rootfs. In that case I was also doubtful about the appropriateness to grant it to a non-core-dev, and asked for a peer review commitment from a core dev in mitigation, which was agreed. However I was later pressured to retract that request.
[16:29] rbasak: pressured from where?
[16:29] I can't think of any other relevant existing permissions.
[16:30] teward: by other Ubuntu developers, privately, who thought it was an unreasonable "restriction" given that the DMB had agreed that this person could have PPU to livecd-rootfs.
[16:30] However it wasn't formally a restriction by the DMB in my understanding - just a request.
[16:32] schopin: well for example I had a long discussion with mkukri and others recently about bug 1635181. That to me is a complex packaging interaction with cloud images.
[16:32] -ubottu:#ubuntu-meeting- Bug 1635181 in grub2 (Ubuntu) "Curtin sneaks config into /etc/default/grub.d/" [Undecided, Triaged] https://launchpad.net/bugs/1635181
[16:33] schopin: usually PPU has been for leaf packages where if a PPU uploader were to make a decision about that kind of bug, it wouldn't impact anything but the users of that leaf package.
[16:33] i cannot disagree with the "complex interactions" thing either
[16:33] But here, decisions made there would have much wider reach - to every cloud user.
[16:34] and with the requested set in this request, *every* user
[16:34] cloud or otherwise (just putting that as a point of statement/fact)
[16:34] To be clear, I'm not judging mkukri's abilities here. My interactions with him have been excellent.
[16:35] But the *principle* of granting PPU at all for "core" packages is what I'm questioning. It wouldn't be a "leaf" activity like it is for regular PPU requests.
[16:36] I'm not saying there aren't complex interactions, mind you, it's just the kernel comparison that strike me.
[16:37] I think the DMB needs to decide whether PPU for these packages is suitable at all, or not.
[16:37] I think I'm still willing to be persuaded otherwise. I do think it's a problem that needs addressing.
[16:38] As developers are getting more specialised within Canonical now, we're getting PPU requests whereas previously they'd just have become core devs without particuarly setting out to achieve that just because their work was more broad.
[16:38] Is it a decision that can be taken by the DMB though?
[16:38] I think so
[16:38] I looked for similar cases in https://ubuntu-archive-team.ubuntu.com/packagesets/oracular/ that could be an argument for core package PPUs, but found none except the kernel case.
[16:39] It's up to the DMB to decide whether to grant PPU or not. If the DMB were to decide that some packages aren't suitable to ever have PPU, then from a governance perspective I think that would be valid.
[16:39] based on my understanding of the layout of the permissions, DMB is given the task to decide on membership rights, etc. including what packages we can grant individual PPUs on or not. Since it's a delegated permission from the TB to the DMB. That's my understanding of the delegation
[16:39] (and therefore governance)
[16:39] s/permissions/delegation of powers/
[16:39] i think for the early boot part, the kernel is the best comparison. for the complex collection of arcane userspace scripts and utilities, there is probably none
[16:40] Another view might be that for core packages, we expect candidates to have a wide set of experience over the archive, and therefore it's reasonable and we actually _want_ applicants to have "done the rounds" before applying. I realise that this imposes some more work, but I don't think it'd be a bad thing.
[16:41] mkukri: unfortunately I see the packages as a combination of both.
[16:41] mkukri: if you were to need to patch the upstream code to fix a bug, then I think your application makes it clear that it'd be appropriate for you to upload without requiring further core dev review.
[16:42] mkukri: but the packaging has complexity beyond that, with very widespread ramifications, which arguably should be reviewed by someone with wide experience. Which could be you, but that would require a core dev application to demonstrate.
[16:43] i am not disputing the fact the grub uploads need review, i think grub uploads by coredevs should *also* be reviewed by at least another person
[16:44] Ideas have been floated around an alternative path which focuses on peer review rather than granting access to individuals to upload subsets of the archive "without supervision", which is what the ACLs we have today do.
[16:44] I really like the idea but don't have the capacity to drive it right now :-/
[16:45] So how do we proceed?
[16:45] I think it'd be nice to have DMB consensus on this point, rather than doing it piecemeal through votes on every PPU application.
[16:45] So I can start a thread on the ML I guess?
[16:46] Yes, I think deferring to the ML would be best.
[16:46] I haven't made up my mind about whether or not DMB should grant PPU rights on core package or not.
[16:46] However, if you want to proceed anyway, I would not stop you (but my vote would be -1 for the reasons above - nothing to do with mkukri's application itself, but that I see this as a new category of request for which we do not have consensus on how to handle)
[16:48] We should agree on granting / not granting PPU rights on core package before discussing mkukri's application
[16:48] OK, so let me start an ML thread, and then I guess we'll need to defer reviewing mkukri's application until after either 1) we've reached consensus; or 2) DMB members want to skip that and move to a vote regardless. I favour the former, to be clear; I'm just making sure to state the latter option to make sure that there's no doubt from a governance perspective.
[16:49] Does that sound OK to everyone?
[16:49] yes
[16:49] Yes.
[16:50] #action rbasak to start a ML thread to find consensus on whether to allow PPU applications for "core" packages
[16:50] ACTION: rbasak to start a ML thread to find consensus on whether to allow PPU applications for "core" packages
[16:50] Sorry mkukri that we couldn't handle your request in this meeting.
[16:50] #topic Outstanding mailing list requests to assign
[16:50] i'll have a comment for mkukri. let me write it down.
[16:51] mkukri: on my second question above, I wonder if you could please get an endorsement from an AA who has handled your uploads? I know that they do for SRUs at least. That would give me confidence in a future review of your application.
[16:52] schopin: the "DMB Meeting hours revision" thread looks like it's still outstanding. Are you planning to drive that?
[16:52] Depending on the process, mkukri might not *know* which AA handled his upload.
[16:52] Indeed.
[16:52] i have had essentially zero personalized interaction with AAs despite having produced almost all the GRUB uploads in ubuntu over the last ~11 months. beyond regular SRU review i am not entirely sure about their part in this to be perfectly honest
[16:52] But he has colleagues who can help him figure that out :)
[16:53] mkukri: it was probably the SRU team members who are also AAs who accepted your SRU into -proposed and made that initial template bug comment
[16:54] He does, but it seems weird to require endorsement from them in these circumstances.
[16:54] I don't see any other outstanding ML threads.
[16:54] i think there is a major bottleneck in the SRU process w.r.t grub, and we have even complained about this on the ML
[16:54] it seems like essentially no one besides vorlon touches shim/grub srus
[16:54] rbasak: re the Hours thing, I was hoping I'd get more input, especially from bdmurray given his TZ.
[16:55] I'll try nudging the ball forward.
[16:55] Thanks!
[16:55] I wrote up https://wiki.ubuntu.com/StableReleaseUpdates/Grub after a discussion with Steve
[16:55] However I cannot do any more without documentation or training from someone who does know the process.
[16:56] mkukri, I looked at https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/bpftrace/+bug/2073485 this morning and at https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/bpftrace/+bug/2060766 from your application. They could have more documentation. Patches that disable failing test could state the reason (e.g. test env kernel too old, etc) or point to a bug report that reports the failures to get them fixed in the future. The latter package
[16:56] changes d/rules without stating the reason in d/changelog.
[16:56] -ubottu:#ubuntu-meeting- Launchpad bug 2073485 in bpftrace (Ubuntu) "bpftrace autopkgtest failure" [Undecided, New]
[16:56] -ubottu:#ubuntu-meeting- Launchpad bug 2060766 in bpftrace (Ubuntu) "Can't run bpftrace , ERROR: too many arguments" [Critical, Fix Released]
[16:56] i am admiteddly not an expert in the bpf tooling and i picked bpfcc and bpftrace up to get them to shape enough for canonical's effort to mir them for noble
[16:57] #topic Open TB bugs
[16:57] unfortunately the bpf expert has not shown up as of yet to take over :)
[16:57] #info No open TB bugs
[16:57] #topic Select a chair for the next meeting (next from https://launchpad.net/~developer-membership-board/+members)
[16:57] Well I wasn't nominated chair, and just did it because nobody else was.
[16:57] Shall I pick one randomly?
[16:57] Excluding me...
[16:58] Do we have a script for the meeting?
[16:58] It's Utkarsh (he's not here).
[16:58] And let me pick a backup randomly
[16:58] IIRC we did some kind of round robin for the chair 10 years ago.
[16:58] That's teward
[16:59] Round robin didn't work because what would happen is that the chair would be absent for multiple meetings and then nobody knew who would chair instead.
[16:59] blah i hate it when the internet is unstable (just got my net back)
[16:59] teward: you've been randomly chosen as backup chair for next meeting.
[16:59] Unless there are objections, based on my random choices to get this restarted, I'm picking Utkarsh as chair, and teward is he is absent.
[16:59] ah ok
[16:59] if he is absent
[17:00] fine with that
[17:00] #info Utkarsh will chair with Thomas as backup
[17:00] #topic AOB
[17:00] AOB?
[17:00] #endmeeting
[17:00] Meeting ended at 17:00:59 UTC. Minutes at https://ubottu.com/meetingology/logs/ubuntu-meeting/2024/ubuntu-meeting.2024-07-22-16.07.moin.txt

[15:17] -ubottu:#ubuntu-meeting- Bug 2043820 in firefox (Ubuntu Noble) "Unable to contact snap store on Xubuntu from Jammy to Noble" [High, Confirmed] https://launchpad.net/bugs/2043820
[15:17] This is targeted to the point release now
[15:17] #21 complains about broken resolved
[15:18] Yeah I have not had time to look in detail at this but its on my radar
[15:19] bug 2073278
[15:19] -ubottu:#ubuntu-meeting- Bug 2073278 in ubuntu-release-upgrader (Ubuntu) "I cant update to the newest version of ubuntu 24,04 LTS" [Undecided, New] https://launchpad.net/bugs/2073278
[15:20] 2024-07-16 18:05:11,520 DEBUG denylist expr '^postgresql-.*[0-9][0-9].*' matches 'postgresql-12'
[15:20] ravikant_ and I looked at this one earlier, and we saw at least a few other upgrades failing for similar reasons (postgresql- being on removal denylist)
[15:20] 2024-07-16 18:05:11,520 DEBUG The package 'postgresql-12' is marked for removal but it's in the removal deny list
[15:21] Yes
[15:21] I think the denylist is wrong? postgresql-12 is focal only IIUC, so it seems correct for this to be removed assuming the new one is installed
[15:21] Ah yes there was another one I believe
[15:21] * bdrung has to reboot his machine.
[15:21] but I need to look at the git history for that denylist entry
[15:21] I have some familiarity with it
[15:21] or had
[15:21] ;-)
[15:22] Well yes this needs to go
[15:22] This probably needs to go before the point release too. I imagine a lot of users would hit this
[15:23] It didn't used to be safe to upgrade postgres due to potential data loss
[15:24] bdmurray: well then we should tell the user instead of just logging it to main.log
[15:24] Oh, I do know this

[15:25] this seems to be a sponsorship request for python3.10
[15:25] Yeah I tagged this when I was on patch pilot. I thought foundations would want to be aware of / review any potential python3.10 SRU
[15:26] doko:
[15:28] or ginggs ^ (trying to ping Samir but he is not on IRC or I don't know his nick)

[15:39] Dominik Viererbe
[15:39] dash/0.5.12-6ubuntu6 proposed-migration
[15:39] Foundations Pulse 2024#14
[15:40] Done
[15:40] oh
[15:40] ok so dash: dbungert
[15:40] sigh
[15:40] ack
[15:40] dash: dviererbe
[15:40] no dbungert no
[15:40] lol
[15:40] gcc-14-cross we just leave with doko
[15:41] bpftrace goes to spyros
[15:41] \o/

[15:43] mkukri: to consult with spyros

[15:44] and that's all

[15:44] I'll be off tomorrow and Monday
[15:44] I'm in and out the next couple of days.
[15:45] I'm off next Monday

[14:37] ...

[14:52] nothing either. Iâll have some forwarding to do :)

[15:32] adrien, bdrung: so which of you is responsible :)
[15:32] I can't look at that but probably tomorrow morning
[15:32] vorlon, adrien and he can hand over the DEB_HOST_ARCH ones to me
[15:33] this is all very confusing and I have just gone ahead and run `retry-autopkgtest-regressions --blocks openssl --no-proposed` here
[15:34] anyway, that's everything for today then

[15:34] #topic AOB
